description: In this series, we will show you how to extend an on-premises Active Directory to Microsoft Azure. Extending Active Directory in Azure can be used for disaster recovery and supporting branch offices, to name a few. We will start at the beginning, by setting up our on-premises network, including Active Directory, DNS, and Routing and Remote Access. We will use the RRAS server as our VPN endpoint, which we will use to establish a site-to-site VPN tunnel to Azure. Then we will create our virtual network in Azure, including defining subnets, creating a gateway, and provisioning public IP addresses. Then we will create our Azure resources, including a virtual domain controller, storage accounts, and availability sets. Then we will verify that Active Directory is replicating properly. We will demonstrate using three different methods, with the classic portal, with the new portal and with Azure PowerShell.
name: Active Directory in Azure
subtitle: Cloud based directory and identity management

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Mike give a general overview of what you can expect in the upcoming episodes. They cover what the show's about, the target audience, what will be covered overall, and other topics.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike give a basic explanation of using Active Directory services in an Azure environment. They start by explaining the difference between Azure AD and AD in Azure. Next they explore some of the reasons why you would implement AD in Azure. This includes reasons like disaster recovery site and AD for mobile users. They also talk briefly about security in regards to an AD in Azure deployment.
episodes.title: Introduction
episodes.transcript:

1
00:00:00.360 --> 00:00:10.360
[MUSIC]

All I did was flip the words around,

AzureAD, AD in Azure

00:02:36.840 --> 00:02:40.430
When we talk about

45

And we get to take advantage of,

76

With Azure AD, we're not using

00:04:53.970 --> 00:04:57.200

88
00:04:57.200 --> 00:04:59.600
When we set up Active Directory in Azure,

I've got all those protocols

But we are getting, again,

And there's several different

the number one reason for going to
Active Directory in Azure or Azure,

96

>> Yeah, that's exactly right.

97
00:05:22.730 --> 00:05:24.970
The first thing that pops

00:05:24.970 --> 00:05:29.300
I can take a copy of my Active Directory

99
00:05:29.300 --> 00:05:31.510
Well, probably you're gonna
get some I don't know.

100

You're talking about my Active Directory.

00:05:33.180 --> 00:05:35.800
This is a very important
part of my infrastructure.

102

And you're telling me I'm gonna

103

104
00:05:40.030 --> 00:05:44.780
Cuz that's how you access stuff in the

105
00:05:44.780 --> 00:05:46.500
So that's what you want me to do?

106
00:05:46.500 --> 00:05:50.580
Okay, but obviously,
let's take a step back here.

107
00:05:50.580 --> 00:05:53.650
I'm gonna stick it out there so that I can
access it when I need it, but otherwise,

108
00:05:53.650 --> 00:05:54.900
it's gonna be shut off, right.

109
00:05:54.900 --> 00:05:56.900
We're just gonna keep it there,
keep it replicating,

110

so has a current copy it's more if this

Turn that on, open it up and

That's normally what people are gonna

00:06:14.270 --> 00:06:15.080

Normally, what would you have to do?

I'd have to go to a local utilities or

Remember, this has got to be off-site.

That's the whole purpose of a DR, right?

So that's what we wanna have happen.

I gotta go there, then I've gotta

Active Directory on it.

376
00:19:01.300 --> 00:19:04.150
We're gonna create a virtual network up
there and then we're gonna create that

377
00:19:04.150 --> 00:19:07.140
virtual server and
we're going to install Active Directory,

378
00:19:07.140 --> 00:19:09.870
as well as DNS is going
to be on that server.

379
00:19:09.870 --> 00:19:13.070
So you can think of it just like, and
like I said, almost like a branch office,

380
00:19:13.070 --> 00:19:16.680
it's another subnet on my network.

381
00:19:16.680 --> 00:19:19.960
And then there's gonna be that
site-to-site VPN between the two.

382
00:19:19.960 --> 00:19:24.878
And that's what's going to allow the
connectivity between my domain controller

383
00:19:24.878 --> 00:19:29.225
on the corporate network and my domain
controller out here in the cloud or

384
00:19:29.225 --> 00:19:30.200
on Azure.

385
00:19:30.200 --> 00:19:32.640
And they're gonna talk to each other, and

386
00:19:32.640 --> 00:19:35.560
it's not like Azure AD
where it's just port 80 and

387
00:19:35.560 --> 00:19:39.860
our web traffic, they're gonna be
replicating just like it was another site.

388
00:19:39.860 --> 00:19:42.700
Just like this was another
physical location,

389
00:19:42.700 --> 00:19:48.020
like I had another office in Dallas or out
in Seattle, it's gonna work the same way.

390
00:19:48.020 --> 00:19:51.240
We're actually gonna create
sites within Active Directory

391
00:19:51.240 --> 00:19:52.980
that represent the corporate office.

392
00:19:52.980 --> 00:19:55.920
We're gonna create a site in
Active Directory that represents

393
00:19:55.920 --> 00:19:58.770
the domain controller out there on Azure.

394
00:19:58.770 --> 00:20:00.495
And we're gonna be able to
control the replications.

395
00:20:00.495 --> 00:20:04.125
Just like we would normally do
in an on-premise where we had

396
00:20:04.125 --> 00:20:06.775
two different physical locations or
two different sites, right?

397
00:20:06.775 --> 00:20:11.545
Cuz it's replication between sites
instead of being on the same site.

398
00:20:11.545 --> 00:20:13.985
So we'll get all of that set up, and

399
00:20:13.985 --> 00:20:17.230
then once that's configured,
we should be good to go.

400
00:20:17.230 --> 00:20:22.000
We'll have it set up to where that branch
office, again, can use this as their

401
00:20:22.000 --> 00:20:25.470
Active Directory and they can connect
to that, they can resolve names, right?

402
00:20:25.470 --> 00:20:30.035
DNS is gonna be out there, so they'll be
able to resolve names of other resources

403
00:20:30.035 --> 00:20:33.655
on my internal and my on-premise network.

404
00:20:33.655 --> 00:20:36.567
I could have users that are floating
around out there in the cloud,

405
00:20:36.567 --> 00:20:39.745
cuz I've got a lot of users that do that.

406
00:20:39.745 --> 00:20:43.775
Like sales people that are on the road,
people that work from home,

407
00:20:43.775 --> 00:20:47.245
they're not at a branch office but
they still need access to the network.

408
00:20:47.245 --> 00:20:53.180
And again, the beautiful thing is we're
gonna be able to apply group policy and

409
00:20:53.180 --> 00:20:53.790
things like that.

410
00:20:53.790 --> 00:20:56.880
I can't do that with AzureAD.

411
00:20:56.880 --> 00:21:02.550
I still need these guys to connect the
Active Directory to retrieve group policy.

412
00:21:02.550 --> 00:21:05.660
We're gonna have that capability here.

413
00:21:05.660 --> 00:21:09.548
I think it's gonna be a great ride,
we're gonna get all this set up.

414
00:21:09.548 --> 00:21:13.850
Show you step-by-step how to set up
that on-premise Active Directory,

415
00:21:13.850 --> 00:21:18.290
how to get it ready to connect out
there to Active Directory in Azure.

416
00:21:18.290 --> 00:21:20.930
Then we're gonna set up out
in Active Directory Azure,

417
00:21:20.930 --> 00:21:22.650
we're gonna create our domain controllers.

418
00:21:22.650 --> 00:21:25.600
There is a couple of caveats when you're
setting up that machine that we'll have to

419
00:21:25.600 --> 00:21:26.670
pay attention to.

420
00:21:26.670 --> 00:21:28.730
We'll get Active Directory
installed on there.

421
00:21:28.730 --> 00:21:32.480
Then we'll set up that site-to-site VPN
connection, and we should be able to

422
00:21:32.480 --> 00:21:37.091
have those guys replicating just like
they were, well, not in the cloud.

423
00:21:37.091 --> 00:21:38.376
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and the cool thing about this,

424
00:21:38.376 --> 00:21:41.800
this series anyway, is that it's
a very practical series, right?

425
00:21:41.800 --> 00:21:46.600
This is an environment that is very
prevalent in today's IT environment.

426
00:21:46.600 --> 00:21:49.916
So if you can take this knowledge and
apply it directly to wherever you're

427
00:21:49.916 --> 00:21:53.819
working right now, or if you haven't got
into that yet, when you do, you'll say,

428
00:21:53.819 --> 00:21:57.426
yes, I've seen this model before,
I know exactly how it's supposed to work.

429
00:21:57.426 --> 00:22:02.143
And until everything goes to the cloud one
day, this is something we're gonna have to

430
00:22:02.143 --> 00:22:07.190
deal with that we have these on-premises,
hybrid-type models, on-premise devices,

431
00:22:07.190 --> 00:22:12.000
and specifically, Active Directory, trying
to talk to our cloud Active Directory.

432
00:22:12.000 --> 00:22:13.930
We try to keep it a little easier.

433
00:22:13.930 --> 00:22:15.650
To reference there in Azure, right.

434
00:22:15.650 --> 00:22:16.266
That's our cloud service.

435
00:22:16.266 --> 00:22:17.832
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] It is a mouth full to try

436
00:22:17.832 --> 00:22:19.280
to say to keep them straight.

437
00:22:19.280 --> 00:22:20.430
>> Yeah.
It really does.

438
00:22:20.430 --> 00:22:22.372
It starts to get confusing so
very, very quickly.

439
00:22:22.372 --> 00:22:24.680
>> It is.
>> All right, Micheal, that being said,

440
00:22:24.680 --> 00:22:25.590
we now have our road map.

441
00:22:25.590 --> 00:22:28.030
Is there anything else for
this episode that we need to cover?

442
00:22:28.030 --> 00:22:29.130
>> Nope.
I think we're good to go.

443
00:22:29.130 --> 00:22:32.160
I hope you guys are excited as
I am about getting starting and

444
00:22:32.160 --> 00:22:33.960
doing some Active Directory in Azure.

445
00:22:33.960 --> 00:22:36.140
>> Well, Mike I'm super,
super excited about this.

446
00:22:36.140 --> 00:22:37.160
I'm looking forward to it.

447
00:22:37.160 --> 00:22:38.700
We thank you for coming in here and

448
00:22:38.700 --> 00:22:42.220
lending that wonderful brain you have
there as far as Microsoft products go.

449
00:22:42.220 --> 00:22:43.660
Man knows his stuff.

450
00:22:43.660 --> 00:22:46.040
As for you guys out there, well,
we appreciate you watching.

451
00:22:46.040 --> 00:22:48.740
We're gonna go ahead and sign off for
this episode from my ITproTV.

452
00:22:48.740 --> 00:22:50.080
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

453
00:22:50.080 --> 00:22:51.110
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

454
00:22:51.110 --> 00:22:52.071
>> And we'll see you next time

455
00:22:52.071 --> 00:22:59.084
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike take you through installing Active Directory(AD) for your on-premises server(s). The purpose of this episode is to create an on-premises environment that we will later connect to an Azure cloud environment. Here we focus on installing AD, along with DNS, and promoting our server to be a Domain Controller.
episodes.title: Configure On-premises AD
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:02.110 --> 00:00:06.285
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.285 --> 00:00:10.676
All right greetings everyone and

3
00:00:10.676 --> 00:00:16.800
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.800 --> 00:00:20.016
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

5
00:00:20.016 --> 00:00:24.170
well we are moving on with our series
that we're working on with Azure AD,

6
00:00:24.170 --> 00:00:26.261
not Azure AD, AD and Azure, right?

7
00:00:26.261 --> 00:00:28.169
Listen, again,
we gotta keep that thing straight.

8
00:00:28.169 --> 00:00:31.384
Joining us yet again here in the studio
is our good friend Mr. Mike Rodrick.

9
00:00:31.384 --> 00:00:32.824
Mike, welcome back to the show sir.

10
00:00:32.824 --> 00:00:34.182
>> Hi, thanks for having me.

11
00:00:34.182 --> 00:00:35.285
Can't wait to get started.

12
00:00:35.285 --> 00:00:39.372
We are, as you said, continuing on with
our Active Directory in Azure, right?

13
00:00:39.372 --> 00:00:42.029
And I'll probably say it wrong
throughout half of these episodes.

14
00:00:42.029 --> 00:00:43.824
>> [LAUGH]
>> Remember, though,

15
00:00:43.824 --> 00:00:47.509
there is difference between
Active Directory in Azure and Azure AD.

16
00:00:47.509 --> 00:00:51.322
Azure AD being, software as a service
where we are just taking advantage of

17
00:00:51.322 --> 00:00:55.376
the identity management and the federation
that Microsoft has with all of these

18
00:00:55.376 --> 00:00:58.480
different organizations to
support that single sign-on.

19
00:00:58.480 --> 00:01:03.259
Active Directory in Azure, what we're
doing here is actually hosting a copy

20
00:01:03.259 --> 00:01:08.200
of my Active Directory, my organization's
Active Directory in the Cloud.

21
00:01:08.200 --> 00:01:11.020
Not just identities but
full blown Active Directory.

22
00:01:11.020 --> 00:01:14.790
Replication occurring between my
on-premises domain controllers and

23
00:01:14.790 --> 00:01:17.720
my domain controllers
out there in the Cloud,

24
00:01:17.720 --> 00:01:20.710
supporting all the protocols
that Active Directory uses.

25
00:01:20.710 --> 00:01:24.940
Not just using web traffic
to do some single sign-on.

26
00:01:24.940 --> 00:01:28.060
So that is the difference and
that's what we're gonna be doing today.

27
00:01:28.060 --> 00:01:31.050
So what we wanted to do though, is we
wanted to start from the very beginning.

28
00:01:31.050 --> 00:01:35.590
We didn't wanna assume anything so we're
gonna start with our on-premises network.

29
00:01:35.590 --> 00:01:38.210
We're gonna configure
Active Directory there.

30
00:01:38.210 --> 00:01:42.100
We'll get it installed and I will get
routing and remote access installed.

31
00:01:42.100 --> 00:01:43.790
We'll get DNS installed.

32
00:01:43.790 --> 00:01:45.840
We'll get everything installed
that we would need for

33
00:01:45.840 --> 00:01:48.110
a normal on-premises network, right.

34
00:01:48.110 --> 00:01:51.800
Then we're gonna go and
start extending that out in the Cloud.

35
00:01:51.800 --> 00:01:55.680
Rearranging some of our Active Directory,
or doing some configuration to

36
00:01:55.680 --> 00:02:01.040
Active Directory to support extending
it out in to the Cloud or in to Azure.

37
00:02:01.040 --> 00:02:05.140
So lets start by just getting
Active Directory installed.

38
00:02:05.140 --> 00:02:07.820
I've got my machine up and running here,
and a couple of things we wanna

39
00:02:07.820 --> 00:02:12.020
think about, again if you're newer to
Active Directory we definitely have a few

40
00:02:12.020 --> 00:02:16.360
shows in our course library that deal
with getting Active Directory installed.

41
00:02:16.360 --> 00:02:19.480
So if you want more detail than
what we're getting ready to do,

42
00:02:19.480 --> 00:02:21.130
make sure you go check those out.

43
00:02:21.130 --> 00:02:25.150
But as far as installing Active Directory
goes, you need a physical machine, right.

44
00:02:25.150 --> 00:02:27.450
Or I guess you could
use a virtual machine.

45
00:02:27.450 --> 00:02:29.540
I get hung up on the physical sometimes.

46
00:02:29.540 --> 00:02:31.660
Yeah, but you need a machine that
you're gonna install that on.

47
00:02:31.660 --> 00:02:35.530
You need your software,
I'm gonna be running 2012 R2.

48
00:02:35.530 --> 00:02:40.270
So the latest and greatest,
which is really a good thing to do,

49
00:02:40.270 --> 00:02:45.430
especially when we start virtualizing
these 2012 R2 is fully aware of

50
00:02:45.430 --> 00:02:49.600
being virtualized and has a lot of things
that can help me when I'm virtualizing.

51
00:02:49.600 --> 00:02:52.280
Especially virtualizing
domain controllers,

52
00:02:52.280 --> 00:02:55.980
cuz that's a tricky proposition or
can get you into a little bit of trouble

53
00:02:55.980 --> 00:02:59.330
if you start using checkpoints
on those domain controllers.

54
00:02:59.330 --> 00:03:03.100
So with that being said,
let's go ahead and start here.

55
00:03:03.100 --> 00:03:04.200
Installing Active Directory,

56
00:03:04.200 --> 00:03:07.440
what you wanna remember is it's
a two part process, right.

57
00:03:07.440 --> 00:03:13.300
I have to install the role itself, then I
have to go back and configure the role.

58
00:03:13.300 --> 00:03:16.370
A couple of things I'd wanna check
on this machine before I go and

59
00:03:16.370 --> 00:03:20.240
install Active Directory, really,
I need disk space to store

60
00:03:20.240 --> 00:03:24.240
the Active Directory database,
I need a static IP address.

61
00:03:24.240 --> 00:03:26.880
That's probably the biggest
thing I wanna worry about is

62
00:03:26.880 --> 00:03:29.670
making sure that I've got an IP
address that's not gonna change.

63
00:03:29.670 --> 00:03:34.000
A lot of records get registered, SRV
records, if we start changing IP address.

64
00:03:34.000 --> 00:03:38.110
It's supported, Microsoft will let you
change IP addresses of domain controllers.

65
00:03:38.110 --> 00:03:41.860
I don't know about you, Daniel,
I like to avoid it if at all possible.

66
00:03:41.860 --> 00:03:45.250
Seen too many things go
awry when I do that.

67
00:03:45.250 --> 00:03:45.830
So let's verify.

68
00:03:45.830 --> 00:03:48.670
I go over here to local server,
I've got my computer,

69
00:03:48.670 --> 00:03:54.340
it's currently named good old GNV-dc01 and
it's a member of a workgroup and

70
00:03:54.340 --> 00:03:59.785
it has a static IP address of 10.1.1.10.

71
00:03:59.785 --> 00:04:01.980
I also went out and got all of my updates.

72
00:04:01.980 --> 00:04:04.910
Now you'll see it says never check for
updates.

73
00:04:04.910 --> 00:04:06.970
Not a recommended practice, but for

74
00:04:06.970 --> 00:04:10.630
our lab environment I don't want
in the background it checking for

75
00:04:10.630 --> 00:04:13.050
updates, installing updates
in the middle of a show.

76
00:04:13.050 --> 00:04:16.660
So I went out, got all the latest
updates up until last night, and

77
00:04:16.660 --> 00:04:19.530
then I turned off automatic
updates just for the show.

78
00:04:19.530 --> 00:04:22.206
Keep in mind that is definitely
not a recommended practice.

79
00:04:22.206 --> 00:04:25.020
Got my time zones set, you know,

80
00:04:25.020 --> 00:04:29.060
all the normal things that you would do
after installing the operating system.

81
00:04:29.060 --> 00:04:31.490
So we are good to go there.

82
00:04:31.490 --> 00:04:34.760
So then we begin the process of
installing Active Directory.

83
00:04:34.760 --> 00:04:38.070
So I'm gonna flip back over to my
Dashboard and I've got the good old link,

84
00:04:38.070 --> 00:04:39.730
Add roles and features.

85
00:04:39.730 --> 00:04:42.580
And sometimes we get a little
dependent on this screen,

86
00:04:42.580 --> 00:04:46.040
remember this is a kind of
a welcome to Server Manager.

87
00:04:46.040 --> 00:04:48.760
It's got these little quick
start options over here.

88
00:04:48.760 --> 00:04:50.430
If this was not there.

89
00:04:50.430 --> 00:04:54.730
Which you might go to a machine and it's
not there, cuz they can hide this, right.

90
00:04:54.730 --> 00:04:59.630
Then you would go to Manage and
then Add Roles and Features.

91
00:04:59.630 --> 00:05:03.130
So either way, we're gonna start
the good old Add Roles and

92
00:05:03.130 --> 00:05:08.300
Features Wizard and it's going to walk me
through the process of installing a role.

93
00:05:08.300 --> 00:05:09.910
We'll click, Next.

94
00:05:09.910 --> 00:05:13.450
This is going to be a Role-based
installation, so, I'll click next.

95
00:05:14.690 --> 00:05:17.760
It has the right server selected
that I wanna add this role to.

96
00:05:17.760 --> 00:05:18.940
I'll click next.

97
00:05:18.940 --> 00:05:23.220
And then I'm gonna choose
the role I want in this case

98
00:05:23.220 --> 00:05:25.500
Active Directory Domains Services.

99
00:05:25.500 --> 00:05:28.170
And It tells me that if I'm
gonna install that role

100
00:05:28.170 --> 00:05:32.090
here are some features that are required
for Active Directory Domain Services.

101
00:05:32.090 --> 00:05:33.690
Would you like to add them?

102
00:05:33.690 --> 00:05:34.800
I like the way they ask me.

103
00:05:34.800 --> 00:05:37.590
It says it's required, but do you want to.

104
00:05:38.990 --> 00:05:39.695
No, I don't want to.

105
00:05:39.695 --> 00:05:40.970
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, who needs that, Mike?

106
00:05:40.970 --> 00:05:42.420
It's completely ludicrous,

107
00:05:42.420 --> 00:05:46.220
the fact that if I don't install these
features, you're not gonna get anywhere.

108
00:05:46.220 --> 00:05:47.780
You can't even install Active Directory.

109
00:05:47.780 --> 00:05:49.480
But I want Active Directory installed.

110
00:05:49.480 --> 00:05:52.791
Well then, yeah, I need,
you say these are requirements,

111
00:05:52.791 --> 00:05:58.280
the question where they ask you whether or
not you need this is superfluous.

112
00:05:58.280 --> 00:05:59.430
It's not even necessary.

113
00:05:59.430 --> 00:06:01.180
>> It really is.
The only thing I can possibly think

114
00:06:01.180 --> 00:06:04.130
is maybe you get here and
realize I didn't know it was gonna

115
00:06:04.130 --> 00:06:08.320
install the Active Directory module for
Windows PowerShell, never mind.

116
00:06:08.320 --> 00:06:08.890
Maybe.

117
00:06:08.890 --> 00:06:11.160
So you also get to include
the Management Tools, right.

118
00:06:11.160 --> 00:06:14.260
If we're gonna use that
graphical user interface, or

119
00:06:14.260 --> 00:06:18.400
Active Directory uses the computers and
all those snap-ins, we'll include those.

120
00:06:18.400 --> 00:06:21.534
I click Add Features and
then I click Next.

121
00:06:21.534 --> 00:06:23.514
I don't need anything else,

122
00:06:23.514 --> 00:06:28.100
so I'll just keep clicking Next and
intro screen for Active Directory.

123
00:06:28.100 --> 00:06:30.500
Take your time and
read that when you doing this on your on.

124
00:06:30.500 --> 00:06:33.040
I'll click Next, and
then I get my confirmation,

125
00:06:33.040 --> 00:06:36.060
and I've got the option
to restart if necessary.

126
00:06:36.060 --> 00:06:37.500
Remember, if you were doing this remotely,

127
00:06:37.500 --> 00:06:40.280
which you definitely can do with
Server Manager, if you're not there,

128
00:06:40.280 --> 00:06:44.480
you might wanna restart it, but this role,
in particular, does not require reboot.

129
00:06:44.480 --> 00:06:46.890
All right, so I happen to know
that just from experience, so

130
00:06:46.890 --> 00:06:48.440
I'm not gonna bother checking it.

131
00:06:48.440 --> 00:06:49.840
And I'll click Install.

132
00:06:49.840 --> 00:06:52.870
And this is gonna go through and
install the role.

133
00:06:52.870 --> 00:06:54.910
Now what we've got to remember
with Active Directory,

134
00:06:54.910 --> 00:06:57.600
though, it is a two step process.

135
00:06:57.600 --> 00:06:58.880
You install the role.

136
00:06:58.880 --> 00:07:02.410
When this finishes,
you do not have a domain controller.

137
00:07:02.410 --> 00:07:06.570
All the pieces necessary to make it
a domain controller are gonna be there.

138
00:07:06.570 --> 00:07:09.220
Well we still have to go
through the Active Directory

139
00:07:09.220 --> 00:07:13.380
configuration wizard to actually
set up Active Directory.

140
00:07:13.380 --> 00:07:18.420
Either create a new forest, or
add a new domain to an existing forest, or

141
00:07:18.420 --> 00:07:21.570
add a domain controller
to an existing domain.

142
00:07:21.570 --> 00:07:24.010
Set up all of it, and I'm gonna go
through these options again with you,

143
00:07:24.010 --> 00:07:27.080
but creating, are you gonna install DNS?

144
00:07:27.080 --> 00:07:31.730
Do you need the, where are you gonna

216
00:10:58.850 --> 00:11:02.030
Active Directory relies on DNS,
it has to have it

217
00:11:02.030 --> 00:11:06.440
because it has to create those SRV
records so that people can locate it.

218
00:11:06.440 --> 00:11:09.375
So if somebody goes to log on and
says, hey, who's running Kerberos?

219
00:11:09.375 --> 00:11:12.330

a few other things.

220
00:11:12.330 --> 00:11:14.780
So active directory requires DNS.

221
00:11:14.780 --> 00:11:18.160
You don't have to put it on the same
machine as the domain controller.

222
00:11:18.160 --> 00:11:20.900

some other reason.

223
00:11:20.900 --> 00:11:23.220
And you can just point

224
00:11:23.220 --> 00:11:27.550

225
00:11:27.550 --> 00:11:32.010

226
00:11:32.010 --> 00:11:35.440

00:25:14.695 --> 00:25:19.980

00:25:21.090 --> 00:25:22.980

00:25:34.252 --> 00:25:39.180

services are needed for that role.

00:25:39.180 --> 00:25:45.049

00:25:45.049 --> 00:25:49.033

00:25:49.033 --> 00:25:51.089

00:25:51.089 --> 00:25:54.600

00:25:54.600 --> 00:26:00.710
But it also creates SRV records for every
service it finds listed in that file so

530
00:26:00.710 --> 00:26:04.460
it should have listed those
Active Directory services in that file and

531
00:26:04.460 --> 00:26:07.780

532
00:26:07.780 --> 00:26:10.870

00:26:10.870 --> 00:26:16.270

00:26:16.270 --> 00:26:17.860

00:26:17.860 --> 00:26:19.590

00:26:20.910 --> 00:26:24.850

00:26:24.850 --> 00:26:29.420

00:26:29.420 --> 00:26:30.410

00:26:30.410 --> 00:26:33.990

00:26:33.990 --> 00:26:37.430

there is ntds.dit, that's the actual

00:29:41.340 --> 00:29:45.240
And all these other EDBs

00:29:47.210 --> 00:29:52.160

00:29:52.160 --> 00:29:55.940
So, that guy created and it's got all

like uses in computers and

There's my account for

GNV-DC01 is in my domain controllers OU.

00:30:18.920 --> 00:30:20.620
So that looks good there.

00:30:21.640 --> 00:30:23.550

00:30:38.255 --> 00:30:45.101
And if we go into there, I should see
Under TCP, there are my SRV records,

global catalog, kerberos,
kpasswd, and ldap.

00:30:50.350 --> 00:30:55.650

00:30:55.650 --> 00:30:57.630

And at that point, we've got Active

Now there are some things we're

But again, if you've already got

>> You'll be able to do this as well.

The next steps that we do, you'll be able

667
00:33:42.730 --> 00:33:43.800
>> Well, excellent stuff, Mike.

668
00:33:43.800 --> 00:33:46.720
I really look forward to this,
this has been a fun show, so far, and

00:33:46.720 --> 00:33:48.460

As far as this episode goes, Mike,

It's up and running, it's ready to roll.

672

Well, thank you so much for

And for anywhere,

00:34:16.842 --> 00:34:18.259

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike walk you through configuring your VPN endpoints which will be used to connect and encrypt your data between the on-premises site with your site in Azure. They begin by installing and configuring the Routing & Remote Access server which acts as the endpoint gateway. Then they configure Network Address Translation(NAT) so that the private internal network can send network traffic across the VPN and access the Internet.
episodes.title: Configure a VPN Endpoint
episodes.transcript:

00:17:02.990 --> 00:17:05.390
And then you're gonna have to come
back and run it again anyway,

362
00:17:05.390 --> 00:17:08.140
once you finally do statically
assign your IP addresses.

363
00:17:08.140 --> 00:17:10.350
I'll go ahead and click Next, and

364
00:17:10.350 --> 00:17:13.746
here's where I've got to tell it
what is it that I'm trying to do.

365
00:17:13.746 --> 00:17:17.550
Remote access, dial-up VPN, NAT, VPN and

366
00:17:17.550 --> 00:17:22.630
NAT, secure connection between two private
networks, or custom configuration.

367
00:17:22.630 --> 00:17:24.520
I'm going to do a couple.

368
00:17:24.520 --> 00:17:25.640
I want to do more than one.

369
00:17:25.640 --> 00:17:27.140
These are radio buttons.

370
00:17:27.140 --> 00:17:28.880
So I can only select one.

371
00:17:28.880 --> 00:17:32.320
So I'm going to do a custom configuration,
that's gonna allow me,

372
00:17:32.320 --> 00:17:35.970
I can zoom back out and
see my buttons here, click Next.

373
00:17:35.970 --> 00:17:39.450
Now I can choose any combination of,
rather than just a single one, so

374
00:17:39.450 --> 00:17:40.730
you just choose custom.

375
00:17:40.730 --> 00:17:45.100
And here I'm gonna do VPN,
and I'm gonna do LAN routing,

376
00:17:45.100 --> 00:17:48.730
that's what's gonna route the packets from
the public to the private, back and forth.

377
00:17:48.730 --> 00:17:51.790
We'll click Next, and then Finish.

378
00:17:52.830 --> 00:17:56.020
And it will take it a minute, and it will
tell me that it's ready to be started up.

379
00:17:56.020 --> 00:18:00.060
So we'll go ahead and
click Start Service, and

380
00:18:00.060 --> 00:18:05.560
we'll give it just a second to fire up,
and then we should be good to go.

381
00:18:08.600 --> 00:18:12.060
All right, Routing and Remote Access
is configured on this server.

382
00:18:12.060 --> 00:18:13.590
Normally that expands out on its own.

383
00:18:13.590 --> 00:18:15.322
I didn't wanna,
no we'll go ahead and do it.

384
00:18:15.322 --> 00:18:20.430
All right, and there we go, I can see
I now have my network interfaces,

385
00:18:20.430 --> 00:18:24.160
what else, you got your ports, and
we're not gonna go through all of this.

386
00:18:24.160 --> 00:18:28.820
This would be more important if you're
actually setting up a VPN server, choosing

387
00:18:28.820 --> 00:18:33.390
the protocol that you want to allow your
users to use to connect, things like that.

388
00:18:33.390 --> 00:18:38.040
Some of the important stuff in here,
see if I go under IPv4 in General,

389
00:18:38.040 --> 00:18:40.110
I can see it sees my two network adapters.

390
00:18:40.110 --> 00:18:43.460
It's got their IP addresses listed there,
and this is what I was saying earlier.

391
00:18:43.460 --> 00:18:47.630
If you didn't set those up, then it's not
gonna know which one's facing the public,

392
00:18:47.630 --> 00:18:48.780
which one's facing the private.

393
00:18:48.780 --> 00:18:53.400
It's gonna have to ask
you if these change.

394
00:18:53.400 --> 00:18:58.450
Just from personal experience, I have
found that if I change IP addresses,

395
00:18:58.450 --> 00:19:00.650
sometimes this console doesn't pick it up.

396
00:19:00.650 --> 00:19:04.420
And I basically have to un-configure
it and re-configure it.

397
00:19:04.420 --> 00:19:06.720
Which really isn't that hard,
it's just time.

398
00:19:06.720 --> 00:19:09.770
I can always come up here,
right-click > Disable.

399
00:19:09.770 --> 00:19:13.030
And what they would do is
blow away all configuration.

400
00:19:13.030 --> 00:19:15.980
And then it would have the little
red downward-pointing arrow again.

401
00:19:15.980 --> 00:19:18.530
I'd right-click, Configure Routing and
Remote Access, and

402
00:19:18.530 --> 00:19:19.470
I'd get to go through it again.

403
00:19:19.470 --> 00:19:21.280
So it's not the end of the world, but

404
00:19:21.280 --> 00:19:25.160
it is an extra step if you can
just set that up ahead of time,

405
00:19:25.160 --> 00:19:28.470
as far as your network adapters go,
and you don't have to worry about it.

406
00:19:28.470 --> 00:19:30.640
All right, so that is good to go.

407
00:19:30.640 --> 00:19:34.140
And then what we need to do is we need
to start testing some connectivity.

408
00:19:34.140 --> 00:19:37.730
Cuz there is one thing I left out, I don't
know if anybody's picked up on it yet.

409
00:19:37.730 --> 00:19:42.330
We'll find out here in just a second
if you guys know it in the chat room.

410
00:19:42.330 --> 00:19:43.360
Let's see what we can do.

411
00:19:44.470 --> 00:19:48.350
I'm going to open up a little
PowerShell prompt here.

412
00:19:48.350 --> 00:19:53.150
And I'll adjust that font real quick so
you guys can see what I'm typing.

413
00:19:55.500 --> 00:20:00.440
And I wanna see if I can ping my domain
controller, all right, 10.1.1.10.

414
00:20:00.440 --> 00:20:04.320
And I have adjusted
the firewalls by the way.

415
00:20:04.320 --> 00:20:09.150
Remember, 2012 R2 by default
does not allow the echo replies,

416
00:20:09.150 --> 00:20:10.860
or the echo requests I should say.

417
00:20:10.860 --> 00:20:12.550
So I have done that ahead of time.

418
00:20:12.550 --> 00:20:13.580
You guys didn't get to see that.

419
00:20:13.580 --> 00:20:15.880
So there you can see
I've got connectivity, so

420
00:20:15.880 --> 00:20:18.150
we go back over to the drawing,
that would be this right here, right?

421
00:20:18.150 --> 00:20:25.658
From the router to the domain controller,
from the router, can I ping 8.8.8.8?

422
00:20:25.658 --> 00:20:28.056
That'd be a public IP address for

423
00:20:28.056 --> 00:20:32.980
one of Google's DNS servers I believe,
if I'm not mistaken.

424
00:20:32.980 --> 00:20:37.380
And there I can see it, so now that
would be this direction here, right, so

425
00:20:37.380 --> 00:20:38.950
everything looks good.

426
00:20:38.950 --> 00:20:41.168
Then I'm gonna flip over
to my domain controller.

427
00:20:44.395 --> 00:20:48.455
So I'll go back over to DC01 and
I'm gonna unlock this guy.

428
00:20:48.455 --> 00:20:52.560
And you know what Daniel,
I didn't, see it doesn't work.

429
00:20:52.560 --> 00:20:59.280
I was looking up some shortcuts on
how to do that with nested VMs.

430
00:20:59.280 --> 00:21:01.980
There's just no way to get that
keystroke combination to be sent over

431
00:21:01.980 --> 00:21:03.812
there, evidently.

432
00:21:03.812 --> 00:21:05.320
Actually, you know what, I lied to you.

433
00:21:05.320 --> 00:21:07.819
I did find one way and
I just remembered it.

434
00:21:07.819 --> 00:21:08.895
[LAUGH]
>> [CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]

435
00:21:08.895 --> 00:21:10.735
>> I'll just show you next time, exactly.

436
00:21:10.735 --> 00:21:12.171
[LAUGH] Now everybody's going to be like,
what is he going to do?

437
00:21:12.171 --> 00:21:12.999
>> What is it?

438
00:21:12.999 --> 00:21:13.704
>> What is he gonna do?

439
00:21:13.704 --> 00:21:15.925
That'll make you come back and watch more.

440
00:21:15.925 --> 00:21:18.473
All right, so here I am on my
domain controller, same thing,

441
00:21:18.473 --> 00:21:20.360
I'm just gonna fire up PowerShell here.

442
00:21:20.360 --> 00:21:25.810
And I'm going to adjust that font so
everybody can read what I'm typing.

443
00:21:27.250 --> 00:21:33.560
And I wanna ping the router 10.1.1.1,
and that's replying.

444
00:21:33.560 --> 00:21:37.250
So again that's this direction here,
right?

445
00:21:37.250 --> 00:21:38.332
Then I want to try to ping 8.8.8.8.

446
00:21:39.790 --> 00:21:46.060
>> We've got a problem Houston.

447
00:21:46.060 --> 00:21:48.550
>> Yep, Houston we have a problem.

448
00:21:48.550 --> 00:21:54.010
I'm getting request timed out,
all right, but, that was to be expected.

449
00:21:54.010 --> 00:21:58.650
I did that intentionally,
because what's happening right now, and

450
00:21:58.650 --> 00:22:01.740
I didn't see anything in the chat room,
so either nobody's playing along or

451
00:22:01.740 --> 00:22:04.520
nobody picked up on it yet.

452
00:22:04.520 --> 00:22:07.900
These guys have private
IP addresses back here.

453
00:22:07.900 --> 00:22:10.870
Sometimes we just assume because we're so

454
00:22:10.870 --> 00:22:15.390
used to network address translation
being there for us, right.

455
00:22:15.390 --> 00:22:18.220
I bring my computer into work,
it gets a private IP address, but

456
00:22:18.220 --> 00:22:19.630
I can connect to the internet.

457
00:22:19.630 --> 00:22:21.120
We don't even think about it.

458
00:22:21.120 --> 00:22:25.022
Somebody had to make sure that that router
or something on the edge was doing network

459
00:22:25.022 --> 00:22:29.332
address translation, because you can't go
out to the internet with that 10.address.

460
00:22:29.332 --> 00:22:34.040
That's a private address, so let's fix
that real quick and it's a simple fix.

461
00:22:35.250 --> 00:22:39.380
We will flip back over to RTR, and

462
00:22:39.380 --> 00:22:43.490
one of the other things that I
could add to my router was NAT.

463
00:22:43.490 --> 00:22:45.260
I didn't check it during
that wizard write,

464
00:22:45.260 --> 00:22:48.580
just to kind of see if I could trip you
guys up a bit, but we're gonna do it now.

465
00:22:48.580 --> 00:22:53.060
So I'm gonna right-click, not on there,
but right below that on General, and

466
00:22:53.060 --> 00:22:54.450
choose New Routing Protocol.

467
00:22:55.600 --> 00:22:59.140
And we're gonna do NAT,
network address translation, and

468
00:22:59.140 --> 00:23:01.770
we'll click OK, and it takes it a minute.

469
00:23:01.770 --> 00:23:06.990
And we'll end up seeing NAT
pop up as another protocol

470
00:23:06.990 --> 00:23:10.700
that this guy's allowed to speak,
or now understands.

471
00:23:10.700 --> 00:23:11.600
But we're not done yet,

472
00:23:11.600 --> 00:23:16.410
we still have to configure the interfaces
to use network address translation.

473
00:23:16.410 --> 00:23:17.430
He has to listen, right, or

474
00:23:17.430 --> 00:23:20.690
he has to be ready when that packet
comes in with that private IP address.

475
00:23:20.690 --> 00:23:25.146
He has to go, I'm supposed to
do something with that, right?

476
00:23:25.146 --> 00:23:28.360
So trying to use the force here,
make it go a little faster.

477
00:23:28.360 --> 00:23:31.190
>> Throw some ash and
chicken bones at it or something.

478
00:23:31.190 --> 00:23:33.850
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH] So NAT'll pop up, and

479
00:23:33.850 --> 00:23:38.350
then it's simply telling it, again,
what network adapters are going to be

480
00:23:38.350 --> 00:23:41.410
performing the network
address translation.

481
00:23:41.410 --> 00:23:45.510
And in the end it's actually both,
right, which sometimes confuses people.

482
00:23:45.510 --> 00:23:47.800
So I'm gonna right-click on NAT and
choose New Interface.

483
00:23:47.800 --> 00:23:49.930
Notice none are listed by default.

484
00:23:49.930 --> 00:23:52.629
New Interface, and you know what?

485
00:23:52.629 --> 00:23:55.296
I've got to remember which one is which.

486
00:23:55.296 --> 00:23:57.046
So let's double check that real quick.

487
00:23:57.046 --> 00:24:00.170
Always better to double check
than to pick the wrong one.

488
00:24:00.170 --> 00:24:01.740
>> Measure twice, cut once they say.

489
00:24:01.740 --> 00:24:03.904
>> That's right.
So ethernet is my public,

490
00:24:03.904 --> 00:24:09.562
ethernet 2 is my private, all right, so
ethernet 2 is private, remember that.

491
00:24:09.562 --> 00:24:13.962
New interface, and we're going to take
that private one first, then click OK.

492
00:24:13.962 --> 00:24:16.355
It honestly wouldn't matter
what order you did it in,

493
00:24:16.355 --> 00:24:18.861
because you get to choose
right here what it's gonna do.

494
00:24:18.861 --> 00:24:22.251
And you can see private interface
connected to the private network.

495
00:24:22.251 --> 00:24:23.678
And I'll click OK.

496
00:24:23.678 --> 00:24:27.132
So now it knows which side is gonna
have the private IP addresses

497
00:24:27.132 --> 00:24:29.228
coming in that it needs to translate.

498
00:24:29.228 --> 00:24:33.176
Then we're gonna right-click on
that again, New Interface, and

499
00:24:33.176 --> 00:24:37.068
this time I'll choose ethernet,
which was my public facing one.

500
00:24:37.068 --> 00:24:39.696
And I'm gonna tell it this
is the public side, and

501
00:24:39.696 --> 00:24:42.387
I want to enable NAT on that interface,
all right,

502
00:24:42.387 --> 00:24:46.740
because the public side is where
the translation is actually occurring.

503
00:24:46.740 --> 00:24:48.040
We'll click OK.

504
00:24:48.040 --> 00:24:49.950
Now it knows what to do.

505
00:24:49.950 --> 00:24:52.620
And let's see if that solved our problem.

506
00:24:52.620 --> 00:24:55.930
We will flip back over to DC one.

507
00:24:57.720 --> 00:25:03.126
We're going to try to ping .8 .8 .8 again,
and it's like magic, it's working.

508
00:25:03.126 --> 00:25:04.338
>> Hercules.

509
00:25:04.338 --> 00:25:05.836
[LAUGH] Very good Mike.

510
00:25:05.836 --> 00:25:09.425
>> [LAUGH] So now we've got
routing remote access set up,

511
00:25:09.425 --> 00:25:14.287
it's ready to be a VPN end point,
I'm gonna go ahead and close that, and

512
00:25:14.287 --> 00:25:19.000
we'll flip back over to that
routing remote access server.

513
00:25:19.000 --> 00:25:20.690
So at this point it's ready to go.

514
00:25:20.690 --> 00:25:24.770
Now, again we really haven't
set up the VPN, right,

515
00:25:24.770 --> 00:25:26.420
because that's going to come later.

516
00:25:26.420 --> 00:25:30.980
As we progress through these episodes,
we're getting everything ready on our end

517
00:25:30.980 --> 00:25:34.200
so that by the time we do move
out to the cloud, and we say hey,

518
00:25:34.200 --> 00:25:39.120
we want to extend Active Directory out
there to Azure, it can see our network,

519
00:25:39.120 --> 00:25:41.190
it can create that site
to site to tunnel for

520
00:25:41.190 --> 00:25:45.020
me, it can find everything it needs,
and it just happens, right?

521
00:25:45.020 --> 00:25:49.460
You don't wanna do that part first,
have it not find anything, then come and

522
00:25:49.460 --> 00:25:52.700
set all this up and
then have to fix it, right?

523
00:25:52.700 --> 00:25:56.840
Get everything ready first,
then when you move to the cloud portion,

524
00:25:56.840 --> 00:26:00.940
everything should just fall in a place,
and it's gonna be a lot easier for

525
00:26:00.940 --> 00:26:04.352
you if you do it that way,
>> Yeah one of the definite benefits of

526
00:26:04.352 --> 00:26:08.367
us doing it that way, starting from
ground up, building the anchor directory,

527
00:26:08.367 --> 00:26:12.439
building routing remote access server,
I can say that, get that out of my mouth,

528
00:26:12.439 --> 00:26:16.158
is that not only are we making sure
that everything is set up correctly, but

529
00:26:16.158 --> 00:26:17.482
now we know this network.

530
00:26:17.482 --> 00:26:20.582
You as the viewer,
you're watching this happen in real time.

531
00:26:20.582 --> 00:26:23.948
We're using the same servers
throughout this series, so you can see,

532
00:26:23.948 --> 00:26:27.583
I know what's going on in that active
directory, I know what's going on in that

533
00:26:27.583 --> 00:26:31.540
routing remote access server, I know how
it's setup and I know how we got there.

534
00:26:31.540 --> 00:26:34.100
So everything starts to make sense,
we're kinda giving you a context

535
00:26:34.100 --> 00:26:37.700
along with it so it can be very,
very helpful in the learning phase.

536
00:26:37.700 --> 00:26:39.090
>> Absolutely.
>> So Mike, where are we at now?

537
00:26:39.090 --> 00:26:39.980
What else do we have to do?

538
00:26:39.980 --> 00:26:41.950
>> We're good to go,
I think, for this one.

539
00:26:41.950 --> 00:26:44.950
Our next episode we're gonna start
setting up Active Directory.

540
00:26:44.950 --> 00:26:48.320
Remember we've got it installed, but
we really haven't done much with it.

541
00:26:48.320 --> 00:26:49.840
I'll give you a little teaser.

542
00:26:49.840 --> 00:26:53.740
We're gonna dive in to Active Directory
sites and services and

543
00:26:53.740 --> 00:26:56.710
get that side ready for
this connection out to Azure.

544
00:26:56.710 --> 00:26:57.550
>> Looking forward to it.

545
00:26:57.550 --> 00:27:01.525
Thank you so much for stopping by and
showing these concepts to us,

546
00:27:01.525 --> 00:27:04.125
and showing us how to set
up the router server.

547
00:27:04.125 --> 00:27:05.915
That's always a good thing to know, and

548
00:27:05.915 --> 00:27:08.955
we're building up to getting
the site to site VPN and everything.

549
00:27:08.955 --> 00:27:10.365
It's going to be a lot of fun.

550
00:27:10.365 --> 00:27:11.655
We thank you guys for watching.

551
00:27:11.655 --> 00:27:13.795
We look forward to seeing you
on our upcoming episodes.

552
00:27:13.795 --> 00:27:16.199
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

553
00:27:16.199 --> 00:27:17.011
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

554
00:27:17.011 --> 00:27:19.136
>> And we'll see you next time.

555
00:27:19.136 --> 00:27:26.060
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike show you how to prepare your sites for replication from your on-premises Active Directory to your AD in Azure. They start by configuring the on-premises site and then repeat the process in their Azure environment. Finally they configure the site link which will be used to connect the two sites together.
episodes.title: Configuring AD Sites
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:10.002
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.001 --> 00:00:16.343
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.343 --> 00:00:19.763
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode, well,

4
00:00:19.763 --> 00:00:22.612
we're continuing on with our AD and
Azure series.

5
00:00:22.612 --> 00:00:26.268
Hopefully you guys have been enjoying this
so far and joining us back in the studio

6
00:00:26.268 --> 00:00:29.171
today, well he's the guy that's
been moving the plan along and

7
00:00:29.171 --> 00:00:31.200
that's our good friend Mr. Mike Rodrick.

8
00:00:31.200 --> 00:00:32.250
Mike, welcome back to the show.

9
00:00:32.250 --> 00:00:33.250
We're glad to have you.

10
00:00:33.250 --> 00:00:34.060
How you doing today?

11
00:00:34.060 --> 00:00:35.000
>> I'm doing fantastic.

12
00:00:35.000 --> 00:00:37.560
Excited as always cuz we're
talking about Active Directory,

13
00:00:37.560 --> 00:00:40.090
one of my favorite things and
as Daniel said,

14
00:00:40.090 --> 00:00:44.550
we're gonna be extending our on premises
active directory out to the cloud.

15
00:00:44.550 --> 00:00:47.910
So far we've gotten some of
the ground work laid to perform this.

16
00:00:47.910 --> 00:00:52.120
Right, we've got active directory
installed, in a previous episode we've got

17
00:00:52.120 --> 00:00:57.500
our routing remote access set up, so
our core print network now has Internet

18
00:00:57.500 --> 00:01:01.700
access, that routing remote access
server is performing the routing and

19
00:01:01.700 --> 00:01:05.300
it's performing the network address
translation, and it's also a VPN endpoint

20
00:01:05.300 --> 00:01:09.970
and that's gonna come into play in a

21
00:01:09.970 --> 00:01:14.360
As I've said a couple times, we're gonna
end up creating a site to site VPN

22
00:01:14.360 --> 00:01:18.350
out to Azure, which is gonna make, that
way that our domain control that we put

23
00:01:18.350 --> 00:01:22.150
out in our Azure can go across that site,
decide VPN, replicate with our on premises

24
00:01:22.150 --> 00:01:26.710
domain controllers, really just like it
was another one of our physical locations.

25
00:01:26.710 --> 00:01:31.380
I mean, that's really what it boils down
to is it becomes another location for

26
00:01:31.380 --> 00:01:32.030
your network.

00:01:32.030 --> 00:01:36.150
That's why we said you could do
basically disaster recovery, you know,

28
00:01:36.150 --> 00:01:40.190
and I think we've dispelled,
hopefully dispelled a lot of the fears

29
00:01:40.190 --> 00:01:42.970
about the security in putting
active directory out there.

30
00:01:42.970 --> 00:01:46.420
You know, again just to say it
one more time, I mean Microsoft's

31
00:01:46.420 --> 00:01:50.680
data centers have been certified by just

32
00:01:50.680 --> 00:01:53.680
These guys, I think even in one

33
00:01:53.680 --> 00:01:56.290
you know,
physical security that could stop a tank.

34
00:01:56.290 --> 00:01:59.350
So I think they probably have
better security than I do

35
00:01:59.350 --> 00:02:00.860
on my own corporate network.

36
00:02:00.860 --> 00:02:03.251
I would just probably not,
I shouldn't say that.

37
00:02:03.251 --> 00:02:04.444
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But

38
00:02:04.444 --> 00:02:07.400
a lot of times they've got the resources,

39
00:02:07.400 --> 00:02:08.570
Anyway, let's change subjects.

00:02:10.510 --> 00:02:13.820

00:02:13.820 --> 00:02:15.930
We've got our domain
controllers set up back here.

43
00:02:15.930 --> 00:02:18.340
So we've got our corporate network.

44
00:02:18.340 --> 00:02:20.460
We've got our routers set up.

45
00:02:20.460 --> 00:02:24.470
This is basically a 10.1.1.0/24 back here.

46
00:02:24.470 --> 00:02:28.810
We've got our routers set up and
it's acting as a VP and M point.

47
00:02:28.810 --> 00:02:31.560
Now we haven't done
anything out to Azure yet.

48
00:02:31.560 --> 00:02:36.140
We still have a couple of things that we
want to do internally before we reach out

49
00:02:36.140 --> 00:02:41.300
and touch the cloud and that is going
to be done on our domain controller and

50
00:02:41.300 --> 00:02:44.290
it's going to involve configuring sites.

51
00:02:44.290 --> 00:02:47.050
Now, if you're not familiar
with active directory and

52
00:02:47.050 --> 00:02:49.350
sites let's do a little
bit of a refresher.

53
00:02:49.350 --> 00:02:53.630
Right, when we talked about Active
Directory, Aftive Direc, blah, blah, blah,

54
00:02:53.630 --> 00:02:54.720
if I could that there [LAUGH].

55
00:02:54.720 --> 00:02:56.294
>> It's still Microsoft terminology, Mike.

56
00:02:56.294 --> 00:02:57.307
[LAUGH]
>> It is, right?

57
00:02:57.307 --> 00:03:02.397
[LAUGH] Active Directory is what we call,
it uses a multi-master with

58
00:03:02.397 --> 00:03:08.640
loose convergence for replication,
meaning that all copies are writable.

59
00:03:08.640 --> 00:03:10.620
Except for
the read only domain controllers right,

60
00:03:10.620 --> 00:03:12.160
we don't think about those guys.

61
00:03:12.160 --> 00:03:16.600
And they have replication, any changes
made on one domain controller are gonna

62
00:03:16.600 --> 00:03:19.210
replicate to all the other
domain controllers.

63
00:03:19.210 --> 00:03:23.220
And within a site, that's the knowledge
consistency checker that sets up

64
00:03:23.220 --> 00:03:26.100
the replication topology
between the domain controllers.

65
00:03:26.100 --> 00:03:29.910
As we add additional domain controllers,
it will reconfigure the topology,

66
00:03:29.910 --> 00:03:32.580
making sure that we have a fast and

67
00:03:32.580 --> 00:03:36.940
redundant revocation topology
between those domain controllers.

68
00:03:36.940 --> 00:03:39.210
And replication occurs very quickly.

69
00:03:39.210 --> 00:03:43.770
Change notification, you make a change
in Active Directory, it notifies its

70
00:03:43.770 --> 00:03:47.450
director application partners, and that
domain controller turns around and says,

71
00:03:47.450 --> 00:03:50.440
okay, I see you got some
changes that I don't have.

72
00:03:50.440 --> 00:03:55.020
Will you send them to me, and
that replication's gonna occur and

73
00:03:55.020 --> 00:03:58.930
there's no more than three hops
between any two domain controller's

74
00:03:58.930 --> 00:04:02.120
thanks to the KCC,
the knowledge consistency checker

75
00:04:02.120 --> 00:04:06.780
which means within a couple of minutes any
change that I make in active directory

76
00:04:06.780 --> 00:04:09.280
will be replicated to all of
the other domain controllers.

77
00:04:09.280 --> 00:04:10.490
It's very fast.

78
00:04:10.490 --> 00:04:14.740
And if it's on the local area network, if
we're all in the same local area network

79
00:04:14.740 --> 00:04:16.990
I'm okay with that, right,
I've got the bandwidth,

80
00:04:16.990 --> 00:04:20.530
I'm okay with replicating those
changes soon as they occur.

81
00:04:20.530 --> 00:04:25.180
We open up a second office across town or
in another city, another state,

82
00:04:25.180 --> 00:04:26.450
another country.

83
00:04:26.450 --> 00:04:28.530
I've got domain controllers over there.

84
00:04:28.530 --> 00:04:32.220
Well, we need replication to occur,
right, if I create a new user account

85
00:04:32.220 --> 00:04:35.220
it needs to be available on
those other domain controllers.

86
00:04:35.220 --> 00:04:38.240
But now we're going across
the to replicate, right?

87
00:04:38.240 --> 00:04:41.470
And I don't need, or
I usually can't afford that

88
00:04:41.470 --> 00:04:46.520
quick fast replication that occurs
within my local area network.

89
00:04:46.520 --> 00:04:49.100
So that's where sites come into play.

90
00:04:49.100 --> 00:04:54.790
In active directory, we use a site
to define boundaries on our network.

91
00:04:54.790 --> 00:04:58.300
That have high speed
reliable connectivity.

92
00:04:58.300 --> 00:05:01.070
Imagine us, we've got an office
here in Gainesville, Florida.

93
00:05:01.070 --> 00:05:05.140
I've got another office over there
in Pensacola, Florida, right?

94
00:05:05.140 --> 00:05:08.860
Within Gainesville,
good high speed connectivity, so

95
00:05:08.860 --> 00:05:12.930
I'm okay with those domain controllers
here replicating quickly and often.

96
00:05:12.930 --> 00:05:16.850
At the Pensacola location, good high
speed connectivity within that office.

97
00:05:16.850 --> 00:05:20.090
Those domain controllers, I've got two
domain controllers in each location, those

98
00:05:20.090 --> 00:05:24.250
two domain controllers they can replicate
with each quickly, often, that's fine.

99
00:05:24.250 --> 00:05:27.620
But when a change has to replicate
from Gainesville to Pensacola,

100
00:05:27.620 --> 00:05:29.880
that's the replication I need to control.

101
00:05:29.880 --> 00:05:34.180
Because, during the day, I've got
users using the Internet bandwidth,

102
00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:37.880
consuming that, needing to access
resources to perform their job.

103
00:05:37.880 --> 00:05:41.110
I can't have active directory
replication soaking up all of that

104
00:05:41.110 --> 00:05:42.350
available bandwidth.

105
00:05:42.350 --> 00:05:45.420
So, we define Gainesville as a site.

106
00:05:45.420 --> 00:05:48.310
We define Pensacola as a site.

107
00:05:48.310 --> 00:05:49.630
Now within the Gainesville site,

108
00:05:49.630 --> 00:05:51.990
those domain controllers can
replicate all they want.

109
00:05:51.990 --> 00:05:55.200
Within Pensacola site, those domain
controllers can replicate all they want.

110
00:05:55.200 --> 00:05:58.370
Between the sites,
it occurs when I say, right?

111
00:05:58.370 --> 00:06:02.410
I can tell it when it's allowed to
replicate, like not between 8 and 5,

112
00:06:02.410 --> 00:06:05.450
and I can also say how
often it replicates.

113
00:06:05.450 --> 00:06:10.010
By default, it's every 180
minutes every three hours and

114
00:06:10.010 --> 00:06:11.850
it doesn't use change notification.

115
00:06:11.850 --> 00:06:15.580
It waits for three hours and
then checks to see if there's any changes.

116
00:06:15.580 --> 00:06:19.110
So the changes don't replicate over
as fast, which might be a problem.

117
00:06:19.110 --> 00:06:21.380
You know it depends on your network and
your needs.

118
00:06:21.380 --> 00:06:23.430
So you can actually adjust those.

119
00:06:23.430 --> 00:06:27.240
But the point is within a site,
replication occurs frequently,

120
00:06:27.240 --> 00:06:28.620
often, very quickly.

121
00:06:28.620 --> 00:06:30.950
Between sites, we can control it.

122
00:06:30.950 --> 00:06:34.570
I can specify how often and
when they're allowed to do that.

123
00:06:34.570 --> 00:06:39.300
So that's what we're doing here is we're
creating a site for that Azure network.

124
00:06:39.300 --> 00:06:43.809
When we go up there and create a network
in Azure we're going to define that as

125
00:06:43.809 --> 00:06:47.122
a site as part of my active
directory domain services and

126
00:06:47.122 --> 00:06:51.915
I can control that replication between my
on premises domain controllers In that

127
00:06:51.915 --> 00:06:53.554
Azure domain controller.

128
00:06:53.554 --> 00:06:57.880
All right, and as I said earlier, we wanna
set this up before we touch the cloud.

129
00:06:57.880 --> 00:07:00.660
Notice we haven't done anything
out there in Azure just yet.

130
00:07:00.660 --> 00:07:03.680
And I'd be thinking, why the heck do they
call this show Active Directory in Azure?

131
00:07:03.680 --> 00:07:05.320
I haven't seen it at all.

132
00:07:05.320 --> 00:07:09.980
Well, we wanna get all this set up ahead
of time because once I go out to Azure and

133
00:07:09.980 --> 00:07:14.680
I create that domain controller,
as soon as I set all of that up, one,

134
00:07:14.680 --> 00:07:17.420
it's gonna need to talk to
my domain controller to add

135
00:07:17.420 --> 00:07:19.990
another domain controller
to an existing domain.

136
00:07:19.990 --> 00:07:24.220
Two, the KCC is gonna want to
set up replication topology.

137
00:07:24.220 --> 00:07:28.590
And in this case it's actually gonna
be the KCC calling upon the intersite

138
00:07:28.590 --> 00:07:31.930
topology generator because
it's gonna be between sites.

139
00:07:31.930 --> 00:07:34.620
But if that link isn't up yet,
then it's gonna fail, right,

140
00:07:34.620 --> 00:07:36.790
it's not gonna be able to
do what it wants to do.

141
00:07:36.790 --> 00:07:38.620
It's gonna throw all kinds of errors.

142
00:07:38.620 --> 00:07:42.300
We eventually get that set up and
we can get it fixed, but why?

143
00:07:42.300 --> 00:07:46.036
Why not have it all ready, that way when
you set up the domain controller it's

144
00:07:46.036 --> 00:07:48.755
happy as can be and
it just starts replicating, right?

145
00:07:48.755 --> 00:07:51.107
>> That's right, as they say,
there's many ways to skin a cat, and

146
00:07:51.107 --> 00:07:52.671
then there's the right
way to skin the cat.

147
00:07:52.671 --> 00:07:55.304
>> [LAUGH]
>> And in this case, that is setting up

148
00:07:55.304 --> 00:08:00.089
all this stuff Beforehand, put the cart
where the cart goes and the horse where

149
00:08:00.089 --> 00:08:05.110
the horse goes so that everything works
as well as possible, should I say.

150
00:08:05.110 --> 00:08:08.930
And we don't want to get to where we have
to try to go back and fix something.

151
00:08:08.930 --> 00:08:14.670
We want it all to work and if we have the
luxury of being ahead of the game, right?

152
00:08:14.670 --> 00:08:18.730
We can say, all right, we're not ready
to connect to the cloud and Azure,

153
00:08:18.730 --> 00:08:23.410
but we can go ahead and get out
on-premises equipment ready to go and

154
00:08:23.410 --> 00:08:25.200
that way everything just works
as smoothly as possible.

155
00:08:25.200 --> 00:08:29.130
That's what we're trying to setup for you,
and Mike, now that we're jumping into

156
00:08:29.130 --> 00:08:32.820
sizing servers this obviously is not
something that we tend to work a lot in.

157
00:08:32.820 --> 00:08:36.640
I've worked in Microsoft
administration for many years now and

158
00:08:36.640 --> 00:08:38.410
I hardly ever had to ever go to sites and
services.

159
00:08:38.410 --> 00:08:39.880
But this is one of those times.

160
00:08:39.880 --> 00:08:42.450
>> It really does depend
on your enterprise network.

161
00:08:42.450 --> 00:08:46.810
If you are a single location,
you'll never use sites and services.

162
00:08:46.810 --> 00:08:47.950
There's no need to.

163
00:08:47.950 --> 00:08:50.260
There's no need to
control that replication.

164
00:08:50.260 --> 00:08:54.160
As soon as you move to more than
one geographical location and

165
00:08:54.160 --> 00:08:56.950
you don't have a dedicated
fast link between the two,

166
00:08:56.950 --> 00:08:59.290
that's typically when we start
getting into sites and services.

167
00:08:59.290 --> 00:09:02.810
So let's take a peek and
see what we can do.

168
00:09:02.810 --> 00:09:04.450
I'm on my domain controller here.

169
00:09:04.450 --> 00:09:07.240
Good old DC1, and
I'm going to go to my Tools menu, and

170
00:09:07.240 --> 00:09:12.030
Server Manager, then open up
ActiveDirectory, Sites and Services.

171
00:09:12.030 --> 00:09:16.470
And we'll open this up, and even if like I
said if you're a single physical location,

172
00:09:16.470 --> 00:09:20.020
you might never even open this console up.

173
00:09:20.020 --> 00:09:23.540
But even if you never do,
you do have a site.

174
00:09:23.540 --> 00:09:27.730
When you install ActiveDirectory
it creates the first site, and

175
00:09:27.730 --> 00:09:31.240
every domain controller created
thereafter just goes into that site.

176
00:09:31.240 --> 00:09:34.960
And because you only have that one
physical location, you don't care.

177
00:09:34.960 --> 00:09:38.230
As soon as you bring up another location,
that's when we have to come in here and

178
00:09:38.230 --> 00:09:40.300
start moving things around,
and start defining.

179
00:09:40.300 --> 00:09:43.630
Letting ActiveDirectory know
our physical layout, right?

180
00:09:43.630 --> 00:09:46.980
Cuz remember,
a domain is a logical boundary.

181
00:09:46.980 --> 00:09:51.610
I can have a single domain that has
some people here in Gainesville,

182
00:09:51.610 --> 00:09:54.570
other people in Tampa,
other people in Tokyo.

183
00:09:54.570 --> 00:09:57.200
And all those people can be
a part of this same domain.

184
00:09:57.200 --> 00:09:59.180
They don't have to be
physically located together.

185
00:09:59.180 --> 00:10:01.110
A domain is a logical boundary.

186
00:10:01.110 --> 00:10:02.370
But there definitely is some differences.

187
00:10:02.370 --> 00:10:06.210
If I have a domain controller
here in Gainesville,

188
00:10:06.210 --> 00:10:09.920
those people in Tokyo, their traffic is
going to have to go all the way across

189
00:10:09.920 --> 00:10:12.050
that WAN to get to that domain controller.

190
00:10:12.050 --> 00:10:15.740
Or I can put a domain controller
over there in Tokyo but now, again,

191
00:10:15.740 --> 00:10:21.490
I've got to worry about the replication
because of the geographic distance or

192
00:10:21.490 --> 00:10:24.140
disparity between those
two physical locations.

193
00:10:24.140 --> 00:10:25.925
So all right, enough of that.

194
00:10:25.925 --> 00:10:29.419
Let's get, shut up Mike and
let's actually do it.

195
00:10:29.419 --> 00:10:34.730
So here I am in Active Directory,
Sites and Services.

196
00:10:34.730 --> 00:10:37.250
You'll see that there is
a Default-First-Site-Name.

197
00:10:37.250 --> 00:10:40.750
That is actually the name that
Microsoft gives your first site.

198
00:10:40.750 --> 00:10:45.350
It is the Default-First-Site-Name and
if we expand this out and

199
00:10:45.350 --> 00:10:49.140
I take a look at servers, I'll see
my domain controllers sitting there.

200
00:10:49.140 --> 00:10:52.770
If you had more than one,
they'd all be listed right here.

201
00:10:52.770 --> 00:10:56.340
Remember, sites and services is only
concerned with domain controllers.

202
00:10:56.340 --> 00:10:59.290
You won't see other member servers,
file server, print servers,

203
00:10:59.290 --> 00:11:02.200
things like that,
only the main control show up in here.

204
00:11:02.200 --> 00:11:05.730
So the first thing I'm going to do
is I'm gonna rename this because

205
00:11:05.730 --> 00:11:08.890
if I'm a single site,
I never open this console, I don't care.

206
00:11:08.890 --> 00:11:10.120
Call it what you want.

207
00:11:10.120 --> 00:11:11.610
Once I start adding multiple sites,

208
00:11:11.610 --> 00:11:13.970
though, I need to be able to
differentiate between them.

209
00:11:13.970 --> 00:11:18.510
I want it to make some sense to me, so
this does not make any sense to me.

210
00:11:18.510 --> 00:11:23.460
So I'm gonna rename that and
I'm gonna call this GNV.

211
00:11:23.460 --> 00:11:26.840
Now site names are registered
with DNS records.

212
00:11:26.840 --> 00:11:31.210
When you're, like, the main controllers
for example, register their SRV records,

213
00:11:31.210 --> 00:11:33.020
their service locator records.

214
00:11:33.020 --> 00:11:35.080
They register each service twice.

215
00:11:35.080 --> 00:11:37.770
Once just as hey, I'm DCO 1 and

216
00:11:37.770 --> 00:11:40.380
I'm running Kerberos,
make a DNS record for me.

217
00:11:40.380 --> 00:11:46.200
Again as hey, I'm DCO 1 in site GNV and
I'm running Kerberos, right?

218
00:11:46.200 --> 00:11:49.750
One record is generic,
one record is site specific.

219
00:11:49.750 --> 00:11:54.470
So because of that, your site names
do have to follow DNS rules, right?

220
00:11:54.470 --> 00:11:58.173
So that means no special characters,
no spaces.

221
00:11:58.173 --> 00:12:01.780
All right, so now I've got gnv,
we're good to go there.

222
00:12:01.780 --> 00:12:05.650
The next thing I need to do is
really create some sub nets.

223
00:12:05.650 --> 00:12:10.250
Because I can create the site gnv,
but how does the system know?

224
00:12:10.250 --> 00:12:13.580
How does Active Directory
know what GNV is?

225
00:12:13.580 --> 00:12:14.760
It doesn't have a map.

226
00:12:14.760 --> 00:12:16.620
It can't go look up
the state of Florida and

227
00:12:16.620 --> 00:12:19.010
see where Gainesville is and
go, there it is.

228
00:12:19.010 --> 00:12:22.060
We use subnets to define sites.

229
00:12:22.060 --> 00:12:27.010
So we will use different subnets
in different physical locations.

230
00:12:27.010 --> 00:12:29.260
Like my example earlier,
I've got an office in Gainesville and

231
00:12:29.260 --> 00:12:30.192
an office in Pensacola.

232
00:12:30.192 --> 00:12:37.156
Well, in Gainesville we might
use 10.1.1.0/24, 10.1.2.0/24.

233
00:12:37.156 --> 00:12:39.600
In Pensacola we use 10.1.3/24, right.

234
00:12:40.620 --> 00:12:42.790
And I define that in here and

235
00:12:42.790 --> 00:12:46.720
I let it know anything with a 10.1.3
address, that's the Pensacola site.

236
00:12:46.720 --> 00:12:50.835
If it has a 10.1.1, or a 10.1.2,
that's the Gainesville site.

237
00:12:50.835 --> 00:12:54.530
So your network does have to be
laid out properly to use sites.

238
00:12:54.530 --> 00:12:56.800
If we use 10.1.1.0/24 in both locations,

239
00:12:56.800 --> 00:13:02.480
it would have no way of differentiating
between the two locations.

240
00:13:02.480 --> 00:13:06.890
So, subnets are how you define
the sites within Active Directory.

241
00:13:06.890 --> 00:13:10.300
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna go into
subnets and I'm gonna create a new one.

242
00:13:10.300 --> 00:13:13.807
I'll zoom out just a wee bit here so
we have more room for

243
00:13:13.807 --> 00:13:16.946
the dialog and
I'm going to create a new subnet.

244
00:13:16.946 --> 00:13:18.506
I'll zoom out a little bit more.

245
00:13:18.506 --> 00:13:24.342
My prefix is going to be 10.1.1.0/.

246
00:13:24.342 --> 00:13:25.715
And let me just zoom out one more time.

247
00:13:25.715 --> 00:13:27.547
Notice I cannot click OK.

248
00:13:27.547 --> 00:13:30.623
I do need the subnet mask, /24.

00:13:30.623 --> 00:13:32.670
It's gonna be that siter notation.

Class list enter domain routing.

00:13:34.520 --> 00:13:39.490
And then I have to tell it what

So a subnet can only

If this is corporate office
I might have three or four,

For Pensacola my little branch
office there might be only one or

two subnets that I associate with that.

In this case though there's just that one,
so now it knows that Gainesville or

GNV is the 10.1.1 network.

All right,
now we're gonna create a new site.

00:14:05.170 --> 00:14:09.240
Remember I said the Azure is gonna
basically be another site within my

Active Directory domain services.

So I'm gonna come up to Sites,

Because my naming convention is basically,

That will be my first to main

If I add Pensacola and

then I'd be pns.dcl1, or
-dcl1, or what have you.

So I'm gonna say az, and I'm gonna

So I'm gonna go and create the site,

And then it tells me,
hey if you don't create subnets, and

if you don't link the sites,

I'm gonna click OK, and

I then need to create a subnet,

So I'm going to right-click, New subnet.

Now here, what do we put?

I know that up there in Azure I'm

network that's going to connect

I'm gonna do a 10.1.2.0 /24.

So a little bit of planning required here,

you have to kinda know where

As I said,
if I've got an office in Gainesville and

Right?

So, we have to define the path

In other words,

If I had three different sites.

So three different physical locations,

00:16:32.200 --> 00:16:36.610
Well, if Gainesville's my primary

00:16:43.010 --> 00:16:46.640
I don't really want replication going

00:16:46.640 --> 00:16:48.400
Those are two small branch offices.

00:16:48.400 --> 00:16:53.230
I want everything replication basically

314
00:16:53.230 --> 00:17:00.580
Well the site link defines where the ISTG
is allowed to make these replication link.

315
00:17:00.580 --> 00:17:05.140
If all three sites are in the same site
link it, then it can do whatever it wants.

316
00:17:05.140 --> 00:17:06.400
It can go Gainesville to Pensacola,

317
00:17:06.400 --> 00:17:09.960
Pensacola to Birmingham, Birmingham

00:17:09.960 --> 00:17:12.720
If we get rid of that and

00:17:12.720 --> 00:17:16.110
there's one site link between
Pensacola and Gainesville.

320
00:17:16.110 --> 00:17:19.260
There's another site link between
Birmingham and Gainesville.

321
00:17:19.260 --> 00:17:22.990
That's gonna limit what the ISTG can do.

322
00:17:22.990 --> 00:17:26.640
It'll only be able to
replicate across those paths.

323
00:17:26.640 --> 00:17:27.860
So hopefully that makes sense.

324
00:17:27.860 --> 00:17:31.680
If it doesn't, go back and watch some of
our active directory shows where I do some

00:17:31.680 --> 00:17:34.040
drawings and
we break that out in a little more detail.

326
00:17:35.220 --> 00:17:37.340
So now let's check it out here.

327
00:17:37.340 --> 00:17:39.710
We're We're gonna go to
Inter-Site Transports, and

00:17:39.710 --> 00:17:44.070
we're gonna be using IP because nobody
uses SMTP for intra-site replication.

329
00:17:44.070 --> 00:17:48.000
I explained that in the other shows too,
so we'll have to do that again.

330
00:17:48.000 --> 00:17:52.140
And what I'm gonna do is I'm just
gonna rename this site link.

331
00:17:52.140 --> 00:17:58.350
Okay, so I'm gonna rename it, and
I'm gonna call this my gmv-az site link.

00:17:58.350 --> 00:17:59.510
And I'm gonna make sure,

00:17:59.510 --> 00:18:05.500
when I pull up its properties that the two

00:18:05.500 --> 00:18:10.050
Now just for giggles, let me show you

New site, and

Oops, yeah.

00:18:15.590 --> 00:18:19.750
All right, and I'll dump it in there,

00:18:19.750 --> 00:18:24.110
All right, now we go back to
that site link you'll see

00:18:24.110 --> 00:18:28.090
that all three sites are listed in there,

00:18:28.090 --> 00:18:29.510
So it puts all three sites in there.

That means it can replicate

What you would normally do is

00:18:37.350 --> 00:18:40.820
So now I've got one site link

00:18:40.820 --> 00:18:43.620
then I would create a second site link.

345
00:18:43.620 --> 00:18:47.340
And I would add Gainesville and
Birmingham.

00:18:47.340 --> 00:18:51.170
So you see how I'm doing that?

Now I've got, did it not show up?

Either I clicked cancel that didn't work,

00:19:07.778 --> 00:19:09.030
[LAUGH] Oops.

Yeah let's do -bhm and

00:19:17.680 --> 00:19:20.940
Now I've got two, and now you can see what
I'm talking about, kind of like a hub and

00:19:20.940 --> 00:19:21.450
spoke right?

00:19:21.450 --> 00:19:26.200
Gainesville's the center It can replicate
azure from against gav Birmingham but

not between Birmingham and and azure.

00:19:28.620 --> 00:19:29.330
All right.

I'm just trying to explain

So, I'm going to go ahead and just remove

[LAUGH]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike guide you through working with Microsoft Azure. They start by looking at the free subscription the Microsoft offers and what that entails. Then they look over the different Azure portals which includes the New and Classic portals. Finally they show you how to prepare the PowerShell for connecting to your Azure environment.
episodes.title: Getting Started with Azure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike show you how to prepare your Azure environment for connecting to your on-premises network. They begin by registering the on-premises and Azure DNS servers in Azure networking. Then they create a virtual network in Azure and prepare the site-to-site VPN so that both environments can start accessing each other.
episodes.title: Build an Azure Virtual Network

73
00:04:03.740 --> 00:04:08.010
they get their TCP/IP
configuration through DHCP.

74
00:04:08.010 --> 00:04:11.310
And so it's gonna pass them out
their IP address, their subnet mask,

75
00:04:11.310 --> 00:04:15.470

preferred and alternate DNS servers.

76
00:04:15.470 --> 00:04:19.074
So that's the first thing we need to do so
that when we build these VMs,

77
00:04:19.074 --> 00:04:20.550
they get that information.

78
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:25.780
Because DHCP in Azure is a little bit
different from DHCP that we're used to.

79
00:04:25.780 --> 00:04:31.480
It's still dynamic, the machine boots
up and it requests an IP address.

80
00:04:31.480 --> 00:04:35.720
DHCP hears that request and
is going to provide that information.

81
00:04:35.720 --> 00:04:36.548
But once it does,

82
00:04:36.548 --> 00:04:39.988
actually that information is persistent
throughout the life of that VM.

83
00:04:39.988 --> 00:04:44.466
As long as you don't decommission that VM,
it'll maintain or

84
00:04:44.466 --> 00:04:46.640
keep that same IP address.

85
00:04:46.640 --> 00:04:50.595
So dynamic in the assignment, but
it's almost like a reservation,

86
00:04:50.595 --> 00:04:53.268
is really what it's
doing in the background.

87
00:04:53.268 --> 00:04:56.451
Which is a good thing because,
like domain controllers, they

00:04:56.451 --> 00:05:00.910

don't want their IP address ever changing.

00:05:00.910 --> 00:05:03.620
My DNS servers,
their IP addresses shouldn't change.

00:05:03.620 --> 00:05:07.050

gonna do that if you're using DHCP?

00:05:07.050 --> 00:05:10.780
Because it does reservations and
they maintain that throughout, it's okay.

00:05:10.780 --> 00:05:12.450
They get assigned it dynamically but

00:05:12.450 --> 00:05:14.730

00:05:14.730 --> 00:05:17.170
Again, as long as you don't
decommission those VMs.

ping up there and talk to it and

Thank you, guys, for joining us today.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike walk you through creating a Virtual Machine in Azure for the purposes of installing Windows Server 2012 R2 as a replica Domain Controller. They take you step-by-step to create the VM and then show you how to get connected to it with Remote Desktop. Finally they attach a secondary drive for installing Active Directory.
episodes.title: Install a Replica DC in Azure

controllers real quick, it is definitely

And it's fantastic, and

check out some of our other courses.

00:03:16.500 --> 00:03:18.890
We talk about green IT and

Virtualization is the way

64

All of this is possible

65

Microsoft doesn't have physical

Well I guess I can't say they

67
00:03:29.480 --> 00:03:33.060
they're not giving me access to a single

It's all virtualized, and it's fantastic.

70
00:03:36.980 --> 00:03:39.180
But when it comes to

71
