Active Directory,
virtualization can cause some problems.

72
00:03:43.660 --> 00:03:47.470
What we have, what happens in
the past was if you use snapshots or

73
00:03:47.470 --> 00:03:51.200
checkpoints or whatever you want
to call them now Microsoft,

74
00:03:51.200 --> 00:03:55.600
if we use that as a method to keep our
machines, I don't want to say safe but

75
00:03:55.600 --> 00:03:59.070
let's say we're getting ready to make
a change, we'll take a quick checkpoint.

76
00:03:59.070 --> 00:04:00.820
If that change didn't work out,

77
00:04:00.820 --> 00:04:04.540
we could roll it back on a normal server,
no big deal.

78
00:04:04.540 --> 00:04:08.180
If we did that on a domain
controller in 2008,

79
00:04:08.180 --> 00:04:10.370
2008 R2,
we could have some serious problems.

80
00:04:10.370 --> 00:04:15.580
Because of the replication that occurs
between those domain controllers and

81
00:04:15.580 --> 00:04:17.020
the process that it goes through.

82
00:04:17.020 --> 00:04:20.000
Again I'm not gonna dive into
update sequence numbers and

83
00:04:20.000 --> 00:04:22.910
all that fun stuff in
this particular episode,

84
00:04:22.910 --> 00:04:25.370
but check out some of our
others we've got that in there.

85
00:04:25.370 --> 00:04:27.530
The problem is things get goofed up right?

86
00:04:27.530 --> 00:04:32.180
Because you're rolling that guide back in
time and those numbers get incremented as

87
00:04:32.180 --> 00:04:36.460
changes occur and that's how they
can tell whether they're current or

88
00:04:36.460 --> 00:04:40.240
whether their replication partner if
they need to replicate those changes.

89
00:04:40.240 --> 00:04:45.020
So if I roll him back in time it goofs
all of that up because he loses track.

90
00:04:45.020 --> 00:04:47.460
Everybody else that they'll
stop replicating with, or

91
00:04:47.460 --> 00:04:50.560
he'll stop replicating with everybody
else, it just causes problems.

92
00:04:50.560 --> 00:04:53.950
Other problems that can occur
the relative identifiers, all right.

93
00:04:53.950 --> 00:04:56.940
We've learned about that in
basic Active Directory 101.

94
00:04:56.940 --> 00:04:59.890
That's a unique number that
never ever gets reused.

95
00:04:59.890 --> 00:05:02.870
It gets plugged in with the domain
identifier to generate the SID,

96
00:05:02.870 --> 00:05:06.110
the security identifier
that makes all objects,

97
00:05:06.110 --> 00:05:08.610
security principles anyway, unique.

98
00:05:08.610 --> 00:05:12.290
Well, if he's keeping track
of what RIDs he's used, and

99
00:05:12.290 --> 00:05:16.610
I roll him back in time,
he's forgetting what RIDs he's used.

100
00:05:16.610 --> 00:05:19.490
And he could attempt to
use those RIDs again and

101
00:05:19.490 --> 00:05:22.600
start generating objects
that have duplicate SIDs.

102
00:05:22.600 --> 00:05:24.020
And that's a no-no, right?

103
00:05:24.020 --> 00:05:29.230
So bad things happened when we tried
to roll back domain controllers.

104
00:05:29.230 --> 00:05:30.820
2012 R2 changes all that, all right.

105
00:05:30.820 --> 00:05:32.500
It's aware of virtualization.

106
00:05:32.500 --> 00:05:36.320
It understands that it's
a virtualized domain controller.

107
00:05:36.320 --> 00:05:41.450
And there's processes in place that will
prevent those bad things from happening.

108
00:05:41.450 --> 00:05:45.700
It uses a VM generation ID and
when that no longer matches,

109
00:05:45.700 --> 00:05:49.920
when you roll it back in time,
it basically gets rid of its RID pool.

110
00:05:49.920 --> 00:05:53.710
It does some things with its update
sequence number to make it look like

111
00:05:53.710 --> 00:05:57.000
a brand new domain controller to
the rest of the replication partners so

112
00:05:57.000 --> 00:05:59.800
they all replicate with him again,
bring it up to speed.

113
00:05:59.800 --> 00:06:01.200
It works out great.

114
00:06:01.200 --> 00:06:06.109
But if you're not using 2012 R2 one
that uses those VM generation IDs isn't

115
00:06:06.109 --> 00:06:09.440
aware of virtualization,
get yourself in trouble really fast.

116
00:06:09.440 --> 00:06:12.933
If you happen to use a check
point on a domain controller, and

117
00:06:12.933 --> 00:06:14.107
try to roll it back.

118
00:06:14.107 --> 00:06:15.400
So you can still do it.

119
00:06:15.400 --> 00:06:20.126
Right, you can use other operating
systems, don't use checkpoints if you are,

120
00:06:20.126 --> 00:06:20.970
all right?

121
00:06:20.970 --> 00:06:22.990
>> Mike, you should teach this stuff.

>> You sound like you know a little bit

00:06:24.826 --> 00:06:25.435

[LAUGH]

00:06:27.660 --> 00:06:31.022

You get into the Ds and again, this isn't

If I try to do pa$$, something like that.

Now a Cloud service is really what's going

A Cloud service as a container for

You can create a Cloud service for

00:10:06.678 --> 00:10:11.520
multiple virtual machines by placing them
in the same Cloud service, all right?

187
00:10:11.520 --> 00:10:15.510
So you typically create a VM or I'm sorry,
a Cloud service like I would create one

00:10:15.510 --> 00:10:18.738
for, if I was gonna have more than
one domain controller up here,

and put both of those VMs in there.

Cloud service name, you can see it's

Remember, these are global.

These have to be unique globally.

00:10:37.260 --> 00:10:42.200
Somebody else has stole my
naming convention, dang them.

So I'm gonna come in here and just add
a little bit to this Cloud service name.

00:10:46.350 --> 00:10:49.880
I'm gonna just do a -cs for Cloud service.

198
00:10:51.420 --> 00:10:53.310
So I can keep it straight.

199

I'll zoom back out a little bit, and there

00:10:56.960 --> 00:10:59.250
I am good to go, it is unique.

My region affinity group virtual network.

Be really careful here, right?

Easy to go East US.

That's what I've been using for

You would be wrong.

You're not gonna be

cuz what's gonna happen is it will work.

address like 100 dot something,
it's not gonna be what you want, right?

440
00:23:49.710 --> 00:23:50.763
It is actually out there.

441
00:23:50.763 --> 00:23:54.873
Microsoft's hardware, Microsoft's taking
care of every bit of that infrastructure.

442
00:23:54.873 --> 00:23:59.236
All we did is create a tunnel
between the two actual places.

443
00:23:59.236 --> 00:24:00.537
And let them start talking.

444
00:24:00.537 --> 00:24:04.403
>> That's it, and looking at this
response times, I mean, I'm looking 31ms.

445
00:24:04.403 --> 00:24:05.090
>> That's not bad.

446
00:24:05.090 --> 00:24:07.140
>> That is not bad at all, right?

447
00:24:07.140 --> 00:24:09.750
All right so let me close that down,
and what we're going to do,

448
00:24:09.750 --> 00:24:11.420
I know that we're getting
a little low on time,

449
00:24:11.420 --> 00:24:14.910
you know we want to install Active
Directory but, there's a couple of, one

450
00:24:14.910 --> 00:24:19.000
more thing I need to do before I go in and
install that Active Directory onto here.

451
00:24:19.000 --> 00:24:23.650
And that is because of the way these
virtual machines hard drive work.

452
00:24:23.650 --> 00:24:24.180
All right?

453
00:24:24.180 --> 00:24:29.530
We need to add a second disc to this
virtual machine, and I'll example as I go.

454
00:24:29.530 --> 00:24:31.950
So, I'm going to flip back

455
00:24:31.950 --> 00:24:35.590
I'm going to go ahead and
disconnect from my remote desktop session.

456
00:24:35.590 --> 00:24:38.010
All right.

457
00:24:38.010 --> 00:24:41.250
And I'm going to go back over
to my management portal.

458
00:24:41.250 --> 00:24:47.320
I'll click okay on that message,
and with my Azure dc01 selected.

459
00:24:47.320 --> 00:24:51.810
I'm in virtual machines,
Azure dco1 dashboard.

460
00:24:51.810 --> 00:24:57.850
I'm going to come down here and
click attach empty disc, all right?

461
00:24:57.850 --> 00:24:58.830
You could change the name.

462
00:24:58.830 --> 00:25:01.680
It knows what machine,
because that's the one I have selected.

463
00:25:01.680 --> 00:25:04.414
Where it's going to store it is
that storage location that I had

464
00:25:04.414 --> 00:25:05.590
already created.

465
00:25:05.590 --> 00:25:09.610
Azure, sorry, AD in Azure, remember,

466
00:25:09.610 --> 00:25:14.980
this is a BLOB, Binary Large OBject,
a VHD that's treated as a BLOB.

467
00:25:14.980 --> 00:25:17.680
There's my file name, you could
change it if you really wanted to.

468
00:25:17.680 --> 00:25:21.707
We're going to set a size, and
I'm just going to say 10 GB,

00:25:21.707 --> 00:25:23.940
that size is in gigabytes.

470
00:25:23.940 --> 00:25:24.640
So click 10.

471
00:25:24.640 --> 00:25:29.190
And then Host Cache Preference,
None all right?

472
00:25:29.190 --> 00:25:35.300
I want to put None on there because

works, it can't be on a drive they could
be caching information before it writes.

474
00:25:40.030 --> 00:25:43.160
It needs to be written right to that disk.

475
00:25:43.160 --> 00:25:46.830
It's just a requirement
of active directory.

476
00:25:46.830 --> 00:25:51.790
So when we take this VM and we want
to install Active Directory, I cannot

put the Active Directory database on those
default drives that we get with Azure.

478
00:25:56.520 --> 00:26:01.680
I cannot put sisfall on there, so
I need a second drive to put those on.

479
00:26:01.680 --> 00:26:02.620
So that's what I'm doing here.

480
00:26:02.620 --> 00:26:04.550
I'm going to add another ten gig drive.

481
00:26:04.550 --> 00:26:06.920
I'll click my little check mark there,

482
00:26:06.920 --> 00:26:11.250
shouldn't take it very long to
attach a new virtual disk and

483
00:26:11.250 --> 00:26:16.630
at that point we're ready go, we're going

484
00:26:16.630 --> 00:26:19.450
>> All right, well Mike you're
taking us on a long journey here.

485
00:26:19.450 --> 00:26:22.340
We're making a lot of headway

486
00:26:22.340 --> 00:26:24.540
A lot of fun and
a lot of interesting things.

487

But like you said,
we've got a little more to do.

488
00:26:26.570 --> 00:26:28.300
We've got to install the active directory.

489
00:26:28.300 --> 00:26:32.420
This looks like a really good spot for

490

come back and do a part two and

491
00:26:35.040 --> 00:26:35.590
How does that sound?

492
00:26:35.590 --> 00:26:36.430
>> Sounds like a plan to me.

493
00:26:36.430 --> 00:26:37.870
>> Excellent.
Well, thank you so much for

494
00:26:37.870 --> 00:26:39.550

495

We look forward to seeing you in part two.

496
00:26:40.790 --> 00:26:42.498
Look forward to seeing

497
00:26:42.498 --> 00:26:43.060
We're going to go ahead and

00:26:43.060 --> 00:26:45.940

>> And I'm Mike Vitry.

500
00:26:46.680 --> 00:26:47.524
We'll see you next time.

501
00:26:47.524 --> 00:26:54.534
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue working with their new replica Domain Controller in Azure. Here they finish up by creating a partition on the secondary disk and then install the Active Directory role on the server. Finally, they create a replica of the AD on the replica DC.
episodes.title: Install a Replica DC in Azure Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.055 --> 00:00:10.055
[MUSIC]

2

All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.940 --> 00:00:20.120
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:20.120 --> 00:00:23.460
we are continuing on with
our AD in Azure series.

5
00:00:23.460 --> 00:00:26.380
Been chugging away at that here for
quite a few episodes.

6
00:00:26.380 --> 00:00:30.528
Joining us back in the studio again today
is our good friend, our mentor, Mr.

7
00:00:30.528 --> 00:00:31.430
Mike Rodrick.

8

Mike, welcome back to the show, sir.

9

10

And you're right, you know,
we're getting close, right?

11
00:00:36.200 --> 00:00:37.780
We've got everything set up.

12

We're to this point now where we're
ready to install Active Directory on

13

our virtual machine, I should say,
it's not a domain controller yet.

14
00:00:47.720 --> 00:00:50.810
On our virtual machine that
we've created up there in Azure.

15
00:00:50.810 --> 00:00:55.940
And if you remember the end of
the previous episode, as we created a new

16
00:00:55.940 --> 00:01:00.460
disk, I attached a blank disk
to the VM that we have created.

17
00:01:00.460 --> 00:01:05.560
And that's because of the drives they
used by default up there in Azure

18
00:01:05.560 --> 00:01:09.650
they do a lot of caching, I can't have
that Active Directory database and

19
00:01:09.650 --> 00:01:11.680
SYSVOL located on those drives.

20
00:01:11.680 --> 00:01:14.740
We created another drive,
stuck it in there, and

21

we made sure we chose no caching

22
00:01:19.020 --> 00:01:23.460
So if you look at my screen now I can see
it successfully attached an empty disc

23
00:01:23.460 --> 00:01:25.260
to virtual machine az-dc01.

24
00:01:25.260 --> 00:01:29.420
So go a head an click OK to that and
I'm gonna go a head an connect.

25
00:01:29.420 --> 00:01:32.740
All right, so instead of connecting or
clicking the connect button down here,

26
00:01:32.740 --> 00:01:36.790
I've already saved that RDP file,
so gonna flip over to downloads and

27
00:01:36.790 --> 00:01:41.120
I will double click on
that ac-dz01 RDP file.

28
00:01:41.120 --> 00:01:46.750
And we'll go ahead and
connect up to that new AZ virtual machine.

29
00:01:46.750 --> 00:01:48.170
If i can remember my password.

30
00:01:48.170 --> 00:01:52.890
I'll say yes to the certificate warning,

31
00:01:53.950 --> 00:01:55.690
and we'll go ahead and
connect in, so there we go.

32
00:01:55.690 --> 00:01:59.400
Remember once we added that disk but
it was a black disk, so

33
00:01:59.400 --> 00:02:02.790
just like any other physical machine,
virtual machine, doesn't matter.

34
00:02:02.790 --> 00:02:04.480
You throw a new disk in there.

35
00:02:04.480 --> 00:02:06.490
It's blank, it's not usable.

36
00:02:06.490 --> 00:02:09.830
I'm going to have to initialize that disk,

37
00:02:09.830 --> 00:02:13.960
I'm going to have to partition the disk,
and format that partition.

38
00:02:13.960 --> 00:02:18.020
So I'm just going to click on file storage
services right here in server manager.

39
00:02:18.020 --> 00:02:24.080
Click on disks, and there, I can see that
ten gigabyte disk listed as unknown.

40
00:02:24.080 --> 00:02:25.490
So I'll right click on it.

41

And I'll initialize that disk.

42

Tells me I'm gonna lose
any data that's on there.

43

Well, there isn't any so

44
00:02:33.160 --> 00:02:34.260
And there we go.

45

Notice it does initialize
it as a GPT disk,

46

a GUID Partition Partition
table instead of MBR.

47
00:02:39.165 --> 00:02:43.965
Now that I've got that disk created I'll

48

And this is a standard wizard that

I will just go ahead and click on through.

50
00:02:51.925 --> 00:02:56.105
I'm gonna make one big partition to

51
00:02:56.105 --> 00:02:58.350
Drive letter F is fine with me.

52
00:02:58.350 --> 00:03:00.410
Next NTFS, default.

53
00:03:00.410 --> 00:03:03.860
I am an anti Volume Label kind of person.

54
00:03:03.860 --> 00:03:05.240
I'm just going to delete that, click Next.

55
00:03:05.240 --> 00:03:06.285
>> Michael hates labels.

56
00:03:06.285 --> 00:03:07.410
>> [LAUGH] I do hate labels.

57
00:03:07.410 --> 00:03:08.555
>> Why you gotta label everyone?

58
00:03:08.555 --> 00:03:11.460
>> [LAUGH] It's so
wrong to do that to a disk.

59
00:03:11.460 --> 00:03:13.960
I feel like it

60
00:03:13.960 --> 00:03:17.190
will never live up to it's full potential
if we label it this early in life.

61
00:03:17.190 --> 00:03:18.920
>> Don't wanna pigeonhole that disk.

62
00:03:18.920 --> 00:03:19.988
>> Yeah, we don't want to do that.

63
00:03:19.988 --> 00:03:24.718
All right, there we go, that is completed,
we'll go ahead and click Close.

64
00:03:24.718 --> 00:03:28.414
And now I've got my new volume,
and I should be able to open

65
00:03:28.414 --> 00:03:33.500
up File Explorer and I'll see that we've
got an F: supposedly, there it is.

66
00:03:33.500 --> 00:03:35.810
There is my new F drive, good to go.

67
00:03:35.810 --> 00:03:41.740
All right, so that is where we're
going to store the NTDS.DIT,

68
00:03:41.740 --> 00:03:46.350
the actual directory database as well as
SIS wall and I"ll dump the log files and

69
00:03:46.350 --> 00:03:48.920
might as well just move it all over there.

70
00:03:48.920 --> 00:03:50.780
So now we're going to
install active directory.

71
00:03:50.780 --> 00:03:54.835
This part is no different than
installing active directory locally.

72
00:03:54.835 --> 00:03:55.800
Actually, I take that back.

73
00:03:55.800 --> 00:03:59.430
There is another thing we need to check,
right?

74
00:03:59.430 --> 00:04:01.820
And this is no different
than what we normally do.

75
00:04:01.820 --> 00:04:06.990
If I'm gonna join a domain and
in this case not only join a domain but

76
00:04:06.990 --> 00:04:11.030
make a replica domain controller,
this machine needs to be able to

77
00:04:11.030 --> 00:04:14.090
find the current domain
controller right and talk to it.

78
00:04:14.090 --> 00:04:18.660
Get a copy of that database well
we should okay right because we

79
00:04:20.840 --> 00:04:22.670
published our DNS servers.

80
00:04:22.670 --> 00:04:27.037
And the first one,
the on-premesis was 10.1.1.10.

81
00:04:27.037 --> 00:04:31.880
I just wanna verify ipconfig switchall,
and we'll make sure that,

82
00:04:31.880 --> 00:04:34.690
there we go, my DNS server's listed,
first one, 10.1.1.10.

83
00:04:34.690 --> 00:04:39.180
We've already seen that
we can ping one way.

84
00:04:39.180 --> 00:04:42.710
Let's see if we can ping back 10.1.1.10.

85
00:04:42.710 --> 00:04:44.350
And we're good to go there.

86
00:04:44.350 --> 00:04:47.090
We could also test name
resolution at this point.

87
00:04:47.090 --> 00:04:51.712
I could do ping,
if I could remember his name, gnv-dco1.

88
00:04:51.712 --> 00:04:55.660
Make sure it resolves correctly.

89
00:04:55.660 --> 00:04:58.990
And it actually did not,
that's interesting.

90
00:04:58.990 --> 00:05:00.900
Let's try a fully qualified domain name.

91
00:05:02.950 --> 00:05:04.366
What is my domain name?

92
00:05:04.366 --> 00:05:08.857
Let's see, itprotvdemo.com.

93
00:05:08.857 --> 00:05:09.860
And there we go.

94
00:05:09.860 --> 00:05:14.030
So get that, get rid of that Wins or
you know, the Net Bios name.

95
00:05:14.030 --> 00:05:17.310
Just use a fully qualified domain name,
and it resolves just fine.

96
00:05:17.310 --> 00:05:19.990
So, that lets me know that,
when I go through this process,

97
00:05:19.990 --> 00:05:22.560
when I go through that active
directory configuration wizard

98
00:05:22.560 --> 00:05:26.820
Its going to be able to find
that existing domain controller.

99
00:05:26.820 --> 00:05:31.380
All right so we'll go ahead and close down
power shell and I'll do my add roles and

100
00:05:31.380 --> 00:05:32.250
features.

101
00:05:32.250 --> 00:05:36.540
We've seen this in our very first or
second episode when we went and installed

102
00:05:36.540 --> 00:05:40.350
active directory initially on the on
premise so I'm gonna go kind of fast.

103
00:05:40.350 --> 00:05:42.370
We are gonna need to make a change to DNS.

104
00:05:42.370 --> 00:05:45.240
Remember we published those DNS and
remember,

105
00:05:45.240 --> 00:05:50.255
I said my Cloud-based DNS server was
10.1.2.10 instead I've got a 10.1.2.4.

106
00:05:50.255 --> 00:05:55.310
We'll talk a little more
about that in just a second.

107
00:05:55.310 --> 00:05:57.600
But I can't click and
talk at the same time.

108
00:05:57.600 --> 00:06:00.240
It's very difficult, so
I'll continue on here.

109
00:06:00.240 --> 00:06:01.940
Active Directory Domain Services.

110
00:06:01.940 --> 00:06:06.050
I'll click next,
don't need any additional features.

111
00:06:06.050 --> 00:06:07.170
Pretty much all the defaults.

112
00:06:07.170 --> 00:06:08.810
And I'll go ahead and click Install.

113
00:06:08.810 --> 00:06:11.130
And that's gonna install that role.

114
00:06:11.130 --> 00:06:15.380
Now, while it's doing that,
let's again talk about that DNS issue, and

115
00:06:15.380 --> 00:06:18.690
IP in general with Azure.

116
00:06:18.690 --> 00:06:22.970
I think I mentioned this before, but
it warrants some mentioning again.

117
00:06:22.970 --> 00:06:27.870
The IP addresses are assigned dynamically
to the virtual machines that I create out

118
00:06:27.870 --> 00:06:32.020
there in Azure, which means I don't really
have control over what IP address it gives

119
00:06:32.020 --> 00:06:35.660
it other than I picked the subnet
that it's gonna place it on.

120
00:06:35.660 --> 00:06:38.960
And you notice it started with four, and
that's because it reserves a couple of

121
00:06:38.960 --> 00:06:42.410
those addresses for
some internal workings of that subnet.

122
00:06:42.410 --> 00:06:44.430
I'm like, the gives it a gate way.

123
00:06:44.430 --> 00:06:46.580
I think 10.102.
I think it uses one for

124
00:06:46.580 --> 00:06:48.640
the gateway if I remember correctly.

125
00:06:48.640 --> 00:06:50.530
And I can't change that.

126
00:06:50.530 --> 00:06:53.520
I can't go in and statically map this.

127
00:06:53.520 --> 00:06:58.080
I have before in the past tried to
use some static mapping techniques.

128
00:06:58.080 --> 00:07:01.100
There's actually some PowerShell
commands that you can use

129
00:07:01.100 --> 00:07:03.220
to not really statically map it.

130
00:07:03.220 --> 00:07:06.770
But force a reservation, for
a particular IP address.

131
00:07:06.770 --> 00:07:08.480
But I've never gotten that to work.

132
00:07:08.480 --> 00:07:09.480
I'll tell you, I don't know.

133
00:07:09.480 --> 00:07:13.410
If it was something that Microsoft
changed up there, the powershell

134
00:07:13.410 --> 00:07:16.670
commands are still there, but they don't
seem to do what they're supposed to do.

135
00:07:16.670 --> 00:07:20.990
And I still end up with, it picking an IP
address for me, within that subnet range.

136
00:07:20.990 --> 00:07:23.240
So, just something you
want to keep in mind.

137
00:07:23.240 --> 00:07:27.140
Remember what we said though,
it's okay that it's assigned dynamically,

138
00:07:27.140 --> 00:07:30.430
because once it is assigned,
it does create the reservation.

139
00:07:30.430 --> 00:07:33.880
And it will maintain 10.1.2.4 for

140
00:07:33.880 --> 00:07:37.160
the lifetime of this virtual machine,
unless I decommission.

141
00:07:37.160 --> 00:07:38.720
If I deprovision it or

142
00:07:38.720 --> 00:07:41.920
deprovision that subnet,
obviously that's gonna change things.

143
00:07:41.920 --> 00:07:45.680
But as long as I don't do that I don't
have to worry about that IP address

144
00:07:45.680 --> 00:07:46.318
changing.

145
00:07:46.318 --> 00:07:50.159
And that's important cuz Active Directory
needs that permanent IP address,

146
00:07:50.159 --> 00:07:51.450
like statically mapped.

147
00:07:51.450 --> 00:07:55.196
So, even though it's not technically
statically mapped, it's got a reservation,

148
00:07:55.196 --> 00:07:56.698
it will maintain that IP address.

149
00:07:56.698 --> 00:08:01.398
All right, so we're waiting for
that roll to get past that 64%.

150
00:08:01.398 --> 00:08:03.987
We'll let that chug along.

151
00:08:03.987 --> 00:08:05.695
What else can we look at?

152
00:08:05.695 --> 00:08:09.584
We can actually go and And while that's
doing that, how about we do this.

153
00:08:09.584 --> 00:08:13.953
I'll flip back over to our cloud,
as I make everybody sick there,

154
00:08:13.953 --> 00:08:16.140
flipping back and forth.

155
00:08:16.140 --> 00:08:19.938
And what I wanna do is,
I'm gonna go back over to network,

156
00:08:19.938 --> 00:08:23.048
not storage Mike,
where's my little arrows?

157
00:08:23.048 --> 00:08:27.889
There we go, there's my network and
I'm gonna go to DNS SERVERS.

158
00:08:27.889 --> 00:08:34.610
And we can go ahead and fix this while
we're here, there's my az-dc01, 10.1.2.10.

159
00:08:34.610 --> 00:08:36.630
I'm just gonna go ahead and delete that.

160
00:08:39.605 --> 00:08:41.422
[SOUND] And what does it say,

161
00:08:41.422 --> 00:08:46.015
is referenced to virtual network
az-subnet and cannot be removed.

162
00:08:46.015 --> 00:08:51.110
All right, so
we'll have to remove it from that subnet,

163
00:08:51.110 --> 00:08:54.942
which was kinda what I
thought I was doing.

164
00:08:54.942 --> 00:08:57.848

cuz now I need to use
IT Pro TV demo/administrator.

396
00:22:57.621 --> 00:22:58.689
If I can remember what password I used for
that account.

397
00:23:01.766 --> 00:23:02.741
And we'll see what happens.

398
00:23:08.054 --> 00:23:11.560
The tempt, the green bars.

399
00:23:11.560 --> 00:23:13.010
Yeah, it reminds me the,
what's that called?

400
00:23:13.010 --> 00:23:16.130
If anybody remembers, the old Heinz
commercials, the ketchup, right?

401
00:23:16.130 --> 00:23:17.385
Anticipation, yeah.

402
00:23:17.385 --> 00:23:21.790
[LAUGH]
All right, there we go,

403
00:23:21.790 --> 00:23:25.855
we are remoting back in slowly but surely.

404
00:23:25.855 --> 00:23:27.520
[COUGH] We'll get back here.

405
00:23:27.520 --> 00:23:29.150
>> It just had a major
change in it's life,

406
00:23:29.150 --> 00:23:31.580
you gotta give it a minute,
it's gathering itself.

407
00:23:31.580 --> 00:23:33.740
>> Yeah, it's one of those life changes,
all right, here we go.

408
00:23:33.740 --> 00:23:38.630
We're gonna let server manager do its
refresh, as we talked about before.

409
00:23:38.630 --> 00:23:42.320
It does slow it down when I start clicking
on things before it's ready for me.

410
00:23:42.320 --> 00:23:45.200
What we could do, though, is flip
back over to this domain controller,

411
00:23:45.200 --> 00:23:50.490
my on-premise DC, and let's open up
active directory users and computers.

412
00:23:50.490 --> 00:23:53.100
Tools, maybe.

413
00:23:54.510 --> 00:24:04.040
Active directory users and computers and
domain controllers and look there.

414
00:24:04.040 --> 00:24:07.840
There is another domain controller listed,
all right.

415
00:24:07.840 --> 00:24:09.080
That is a good sign.

416
00:24:09.080 --> 00:24:14.540
All right, so flip back over here to as
your DCO one and what was I gonna do.

417
00:24:14.540 --> 00:24:17.440
You can see there's active directory,
there's DNS.

418
00:24:17.440 --> 00:24:21.769
I should be able to do tools and
active directory users and computers.

419
00:24:23.870 --> 00:24:27.740
And sure enough we're opened up, there we
go, I go down to the main controllers,

420
00:24:27.740 --> 00:24:30.050
I can see both of those
domain controllers there.

421
00:24:30.050 --> 00:24:34.650
Another thing we might wanna do is check,
make sure I look at my F drive and

422
00:24:35.820 --> 00:24:40.970
there's windows and there's NTDS,
there's my active directory database,

423
00:24:40.970 --> 00:24:42.970
there's the associated log files.

424
00:24:42.970 --> 00:24:45.370
I jump back out, there's SYSVOL, and

425
00:24:45.370 --> 00:24:47.650
all the things that are gonna
replicate along with SYSVOL.

426
00:24:47.650 --> 00:24:52.190
So at this point, we have another
domain controller out there in Azure.

427
00:24:52.190 --> 00:24:55.170
Now we've still got a few things
that we really should do.

428
00:24:55.170 --> 00:24:57.610
Remember our availability
set is not complete,

429
00:24:57.610 --> 00:24:59.880
cuz I've only got one domain
controller out there in the cloud.

430
00:25:01.010 --> 00:25:02.560
So probably what I'm gonna do for

431
00:25:02.560 --> 00:25:05.390
everybody is before we get to
the next episode, I'll go ahead and

432
00:25:05.390 --> 00:25:08.860
run through that process again,
it'll be the exact same thing.

433
00:25:08.860 --> 00:25:11.920
Set up a second domain controller
up there in the cloud,

434
00:25:11.920 --> 00:25:15.475
probably set up second domain controller
down here on the corporate network,

435
00:25:15.475 --> 00:25:19.885
as well, just to make sure we're teaching
you and showing you best practices.

436
00:25:19.885 --> 00:25:24.165
There's no point in seeing me do that part
cuz it's just gonna be a duplicate of what

437
00:25:24.165 --> 00:25:28.085
we did in the first episode and what we've
just accomplished in these two episodes.

438
00:25:28.085 --> 00:25:31.475
So I'll get that done in the background
and then when we get back and

439
00:25:31.475 --> 00:25:36.330
we start rolling our next episodes out,
we'll start taking a look at replication.

440
00:25:36.330 --> 00:25:40.070
Making a user account,
making sure it replicates up there and

441
00:25:40.070 --> 00:25:43.960
doing some other fun things with
Active Directory in the cloud.

442
00:25:43.960 --> 00:25:45.780
>> Wow, we've definitely come a log way.

443
00:25:45.780 --> 00:25:49.410
We started with absolutely nothing,
built an environment on premises.

444
00:25:49.410 --> 00:25:52.080
Now we've connected to
an environment in Azure.

445
00:25:52.080 --> 00:25:52.990
Everything's replicating.

446
00:25:52.990 --> 00:25:58.370
We could use it as a DR if we wanted to,
or if we just needed somewhere

447
00:25:58.370 --> 00:26:01.490
out in the cloud to have our Active
Directory, it's there waiting for us.

448
00:26:01.490 --> 00:26:03.380
And data is replicating.

449
00:26:03.380 --> 00:26:06.100
Mike, I didn't think it was gonna happen,
but it did.

450
00:26:06.100 --> 00:26:09.420
You trudged through each one of
the obstacles that was put before you,

451
00:26:09.420 --> 00:26:10.000
and did with style.

452
00:26:10.000 --> 00:26:11.300
We appreciate you showing up.

453
00:26:11.300 --> 00:26:11.830
>> Any time.

454
00:26:11.830 --> 00:26:14.640
>> We're looking forward to
the next upcoming episodes,

455
00:26:14.640 --> 00:26:16.060
look forward to seeing you there as well.

456
00:26:16.060 --> 00:26:19.230
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

457
00:26:19.230 --> 00:26:20.010
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

458
00:26:20.010 --> 00:26:24.367
>> We'll see you next time.

459
00:26:24.367 --> 00:26:30.030
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike add a second domain controller in Azure to add to the availability set which helps with fault tolerance and load balancing. They also show you how to fix an improperly registered DNS server in Azure.
episodes.title: Completing an Availability Set
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.139 --> 00:00:16.601
All right greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITPROTV.

3
00:00:16.601 --> 00:00:21.530
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode where we are continuing on with

4
00:00:21.530 --> 00:00:24.330
our Active Directory in Azure's series,
and

5
00:00:24.330 --> 00:00:28.510
to further that effort we brought along
our good friends Mr. Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:28.510 --> 00:00:30.580
Welcome back to the show Mike
how you doing today sir?

7
00:00:30.580 --> 00:00:32.750
>> Doing great Daniel, thank's for
having me back and you're right,

8
00:00:32.750 --> 00:00:36.990
we're continuing on with our efforts to
extend Active Directory out in the cloud,

9
00:00:36.990 --> 00:00:38.870
which we've really come a long way right?

10
00:00:38.870 --> 00:00:40.950
We started with our local network,

11
00:00:40.950 --> 00:00:43.610
our what we would call
our on premises network.

12
00:00:43.610 --> 00:00:46.750
We got that set up,
we got internet access established for

13
00:00:46.750 --> 00:00:50.150
our on-premises network,
then we went out to Azure.

14
00:00:50.150 --> 00:00:53.480
We created our virtual network,
we created our virtual machine,

15
00:00:53.480 --> 00:00:55.830
we installed active directory on there.

16
00:00:55.830 --> 00:00:59.380
And in between there,
we set up that site to site VPN, right, so

17
00:00:59.380 --> 00:01:03.290
that our corporate network here,
our on-premises Has that VPN tunnel.

18
00:01:03.290 --> 00:01:08.270
That IKEV2 tunnel going out there to
Azure, but one of the couple things

19
00:01:08.270 --> 00:01:11.750
that we did as we went through that
setup that we want to go back and

20
00:01:11.750 --> 00:01:13.290
take a look at again.

21
00:01:13.290 --> 00:01:16.380
First one is going to be
the availability set.

22
00:01:16.380 --> 00:01:19.630
You'll remember we talked about
what an availability set was.

23
00:01:19.630 --> 00:01:24.950
When you create VMs out there in Azure,
you can create an availability set.

24
00:01:24.950 --> 00:01:26.650
That's more than one machine.

25
00:01:26.650 --> 00:01:30.990
That is part of the same availability set
and what Microsoft will do is make sure

26
00:01:30.990 --> 00:01:34.260
that there is no single point
of failure for those machines.

27
00:01:34.260 --> 00:01:36.370
In other words they are not
gonna be on the same rack.

28
00:01:36.370 --> 00:01:39.700
If there is a network switch that fails,
if a power supply for

29
00:01:39.700 --> 00:01:44.280
one of the racks fail or something like
that you are not gonna lose both machines.

30
00:01:44.280 --> 00:01:48.880
Well we created one when we created our
first VM then you'll remember after that

31
00:01:48.880 --> 00:01:52.330
it warned us, it said hey you
created a availability set, but

32
00:01:52.330 --> 00:01:57.260
you only have one machine in there, so
its not really giving that level of

33
00:01:57.260 --> 00:02:00.900
availability that you might think you
have which is It kind makes sense, right?

34
00:02:00.900 --> 00:02:04.930
One machine, it can't really do anything
about any single points of failure.

35
00:02:04.930 --> 00:02:08.120
So we need to go back and
add a second domain controller.

36
00:02:08.120 --> 00:02:10.030
Even if it wasn't for
the availability set,

37
00:02:10.030 --> 00:02:12.410
that's still going to be a best practice,
right?

38
00:02:12.410 --> 00:02:15.820
When we learn about active directory
in some of our other server classes,

39
00:02:15.820 --> 00:02:18.240
we always talk about redundancy, and

40
00:02:18.240 --> 00:02:23.470
full tolerance and we'll say minimum,
2 domain controllers per domain.

41
00:02:23.470 --> 00:02:27.290
And really what you want is two
domain controllers per site,

42
00:02:27.290 --> 00:02:28.570
per physical location.

43
00:02:28.570 --> 00:02:31.370
That way if one of them goes down,
you still have another.

44
00:02:31.370 --> 00:02:36.670
People can log on, access resources, get
those service tickets, whatever they need.

45
00:02:36.670 --> 00:02:41.600
Well, my Azure network is another site,
basically, so

46
00:02:41.600 --> 00:02:43.580
I really want two domain
controllers there.

47
00:02:43.580 --> 00:02:47.240
It's also given me that kind of
a disaster recovery, if you will,

48
00:02:47.240 --> 00:02:52.130
where if I lose my on premises
network I still have Azure out there.

49
00:02:52.130 --> 00:02:53.900
Well if there's only
one domain controller,

50
00:02:53.900 --> 00:02:59.070
I lose my site here, now I'm down to one
domain controller on my entire domain,

51
00:02:59.070 --> 00:03:00.230
that's not going to be a good thing,
right?

52
00:03:00.230 --> 00:03:02.920
That's just asking for more disaster.

53
00:03:02.920 --> 00:03:07.020
So really there's a few reason we want
to put more than one domain controller

54
00:03:07.020 --> 00:03:10.930
out there in Azure,
the other would be simply load balancing.

55
00:03:10.930 --> 00:03:15.190
That's another thing that we get from the,
not so much from the availability set, but

56
00:03:15.190 --> 00:03:21.530
from the cloud service that we
use to create these EMs as well.

57
00:03:21.530 --> 00:03:23.840
So that's the next thing we're
going to do, is set that up.

58
00:03:23.840 --> 00:03:28.090
So if we take a look at my screen here,
I'm logged back into the good old classic

59
00:03:28.090 --> 00:03:33.030
Azure portal, and I'm gonna go up to my
virtual machines where we've got one.

60
00:03:33.030 --> 00:03:37.390
And we've seen all of this so I'm gonna
kinda go through it relatively quickly.

61
00:03:37.390 --> 00:03:40.100
There's just one screen
I kinda wanna focus on.

62
00:03:40.100 --> 00:03:40.880
I'm gonna click New.

63
00:03:42.250 --> 00:03:46.330
And we're gonna go virtual
machine from gallery and

64
00:03:46.330 --> 00:03:50.670
I'll chose my 2008 sorry
2012 R2 Data center.

65
00:03:50.670 --> 00:03:52.990
We'll click on that next arrow
that's hidden down there.

66
00:03:54.240 --> 00:03:59.594
My release date, I'll give this
machine a name, this will be AZ-DC02.

67
00:03:59.594 --> 00:04:05.248
We're gonna do the same size for
the virtual machine use that same.

68
00:04:07.243 --> 00:04:11.376
Can't spell my own name,
set that nice strong password.

69
00:04:15.883 --> 00:04:20.350
Hopefully those match, and
then we'll go ahead and collect next.

70
00:04:20.350 --> 00:04:24.420
And here's the string that I really
want us to focus on, because

71
00:04:24.420 --> 00:04:28.210
we talked about when we created the first
one that you can create one cloud service.

72
00:04:28.210 --> 00:04:32.670
Remember the cloud service is
a container that stores my VM's.

73
00:04:32.670 --> 00:04:35.250
I can create a cloud service for
a single machine.

74
00:04:35.250 --> 00:04:37.760
Or you can load balance
multiple virtual machines,

75
00:04:37.760 --> 00:04:39.980
placing them in the same cloud service.

76
00:04:39.980 --> 00:04:44.510
So we could again use that one that
we already have, that I made for

77
00:04:44.510 --> 00:04:49.250
Azure DCO1, or I can make a new
cloud service for this VM.

78
00:04:49.250 --> 00:04:52.370
But the problem is if I
choose new cloud service,

79
00:04:52.370 --> 00:04:56.820
if I come down here to availability set,
I'm gonna get the option none or

80
00:04:56.820 --> 00:05:00.660
create an availability set, and
that's not what I wanna do.

81
00:05:00.660 --> 00:05:05.060
I want to put both of these demand
gators in the same availability set.

82
00:05:05.060 --> 00:05:09.560
So in that case what I need to do is
put it in the same cloud service.

83
00:05:09.560 --> 00:05:14.004
So in the point of the story is
to create an availability set,

84
00:05:14.004 --> 00:05:17.120
they do need to be part of
the same cloud service.

85
00:05:17.120 --> 00:05:19.270
So we choose the existing
cloud service there.

86
00:05:19.270 --> 00:05:21.340
I've already got my subnet selected,

87
00:05:21.340 --> 00:05:25.420
because that cloud service,
First VM was on that Azure subnet.

88
00:05:25.420 --> 00:05:27.560
You see I can't change that.

89
00:05:27.560 --> 00:05:30.620
I could change it to,
I should say, a virtual network.

90
00:05:30.620 --> 00:05:34.650
If there was more than one subnet I could
actually change it to a different subnet.

91
00:05:34.650 --> 00:05:38.370
Storage account, I'm gonna use
the existing one, AD in Azure.

92
00:05:38.370 --> 00:05:40.540
Now when I get to availability set,

93
00:05:40.540 --> 00:05:45.603
notice I have the existing
availability set az-dcs.

94
00:05:45.603 --> 00:05:48.586
Now I'll go ahead and select that.

95
00:05:50.817 --> 00:05:57.550
And now we'll go ahead and click next And
the rest of this is no different.

96
00:05:57.550 --> 00:05:59.950
I'll click Next on that,
we'll install that VM agent,

97
00:05:59.950 --> 00:06:03.560
and that's gonna begin the process
of provisioning that machine.

98
00:06:03.560 --> 00:06:06.610
Now I still have to go through and
do everything we did to that first VM,

99
00:06:06.610 --> 00:06:09.370
that first domain control
we created in Azure.

100
00:06:09.370 --> 00:06:11.050
I gotta add a blank disk.

101
00:06:11.050 --> 00:06:15.850
I gotta log into that machine and
I've got to format that disk,

102
00:06:15.850 --> 00:06:18.590
partition it, format it, and
then we would go through and

103
00:06:18.590 --> 00:06:22.460
install active directory,
which we might do in this show.

104
00:06:22.460 --> 00:06:25.330
We might leave that for
something in the background.

105
00:06:25.330 --> 00:06:29.200
We will wait and see how much time we
have since you have seen it before.

106
00:06:29.200 --> 00:06:31.610
So we'll go through that
provisioning process, and

107
00:06:31.610 --> 00:06:35.190
we'll have a second domain controller and
then our availability set will be happy.

108
00:06:35.190 --> 00:06:36.410
You know if we take a look at the,

109
00:06:36.410 --> 00:06:39.850
this machine this is the one we
set up on the previous episode,

110
00:06:39.850 --> 00:06:43.080
I still have that warning, the
availability set for this virtual machine

111
00:06:43.080 --> 00:06:48.690
only has one running instance which
affects the SLA requires at least two.

112
00:06:48.690 --> 00:06:54.970
So hopefully that will go away once we add
this second domain controller up there.

113
00:06:54.970 --> 00:06:56.380
So while we're waiting for that,

114
00:06:56.380 --> 00:07:00.830
instead of just sitting here watching
those progress bars like we love to do I

115
00:07:00.830 --> 00:07:03.150
thought we'd go ahead, and
clean up some of that DNS.

116
00:07:03.150 --> 00:07:09.430
Now, we saw in previous episodes we
registered our DNS servers in Azure.

117
00:07:09.430 --> 00:07:13.820
And we said that was because all these
machines on that Azure virtual network

118
00:07:13.820 --> 00:07:16.470
Are getting their IP address via DHCP.

119
00:07:16.470 --> 00:07:19.840
So their TCP/IP config,
IP address, subnet mass,

120
00:07:19.840 --> 00:07:23.090
default gateway,
preferred alternate DNS servers.

121
00:07:23.090 --> 00:07:27.460
So, we registered our DNS servers so that
way it knows what DNS servers to pass out

122
00:07:27.460 --> 00:07:30.600
to the virtual machines that
I create out there in Azure.

123
00:07:30.600 --> 00:07:33.390
Now the time that I did it I registered,
in fact here,

124
00:07:33.390 --> 00:07:35.340
let's just go look and see what I did.

125
00:07:36.450 --> 00:07:42.200
We'll go down to Networks And

126
00:07:42.200 --> 00:07:45.090
we'll take a look at my Azure subnet.

127
00:07:47.968 --> 00:07:49.363
And we'll go to configure.

128
00:07:50.893 --> 00:07:53.450
I should be able to see the DNN
servers that I've registered for.

129
00:07:53.450 --> 00:07:57.936
The subnet, and I used the IP address
10.1.2.10 thinking that was gonna be

130
00:07:57.936 --> 00:08:00.793
the first address available
on the subnet I created.

131
00:08:00.793 --> 00:08:04.124
Up there in Azure,
turned out it as 10.1.2.4.

132
00:08:04.124 --> 00:08:06.291
So this is actually incorrect,

133
00:08:06.291 --> 00:08:11.600
there is no machine 10.1.2.10,
so this isn't going to work.

134
00:08:11.600 --> 00:08:14.920
And so I wanna fix that, and
you can't edit this, all right?

135
00:08:14.920 --> 00:08:17.920
I can't go in, I don't think it'll
even let me change the name.

136
00:08:17.920 --> 00:08:23.080
It might change the name but I don't want
to, but I can't change this IP address.

137
00:08:23.080 --> 00:08:25.250
You know and
now it's actually letting me do it.

138
00:08:25.250 --> 00:08:30.260
I will tell you that normally it won't
let me do it this way, and as soon

139
00:08:30.260 --> 00:08:33.920
as I set it back to that name it changes
it because it's got a record, right?

140
00:08:33.920 --> 00:08:37.750
Of that name and
that IP address that's associated with it.

141
00:08:37.750 --> 00:08:42.050
So what I've got to do is actually
remove that registration and

142
00:08:42.050 --> 00:08:46.180
recreate the registration
with the correct IP address.

143
00:08:46.180 --> 00:08:49.100
And removing it is not
as easy as it sounds.

144
00:08:49.100 --> 00:08:50.660
It depends.

145
00:08:50.660 --> 00:08:51.610
>> Don't click delete.

146
00:08:51.610 --> 00:08:54.550
I mean,
that's normally how you delete stuff.

147
00:08:54.550 --> 00:08:55.490
>> You would think so.

148
00:08:55.490 --> 00:08:59.070
What I see people doing more
often than not is going here and

149
00:08:59.070 --> 00:09:03.330
then clicking on DNS server because this
is where we registered the DNS server.

150
00:09:03.330 --> 00:09:04.390
So you go here.

151
00:09:04.390 --> 00:09:06.680
You see that Azure dc01.

152
00:09:06.680 --> 00:09:08.230
And you click Delete.

153
00:09:08.230 --> 00:09:10.790
And take a look at
the warning I get down here.

154
00:09:10.790 --> 00:09:15.190
DNS server Azure dc01 is referenced
by virtual network Azure subnet, and

155
00:09:15.190 --> 00:09:16.100
cannot be removed.

156
00:09:16.100 --> 00:09:19.140
And this is something you're
gonna run into quite often

157
00:09:19.140 --> 00:09:22.600
when you're doing any kind of
reconfiguration up here in Azure.

158
00:09:22.600 --> 00:09:25.510

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike go through all the infrastructure that they've set up so far and take steps to verify that replication is occurring as expected. They show you how to check the replication schedule as well as how to adjust The schedule if needed. They also show you how to force replication when necessary.
episodes.title: Verifying Replication and Topology

it verifies that everything is
working as you expect it to.

594

Mike, great stuff so far.

Appreciate you joining us again today.

596

Is there anything else that we need

>> I think we got it taken care of there

00:32:43.780 --> 00:32:45.450
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

00:32:48.035 --> 00:32:56.020
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel show you how to configure a multi-site gateway for connecting multiple sites to Azure. They start by explaining how to crate a modified XML file that acts as a network script to prepare Azure for connecting each additional site. They they use the PowerShell to finish connecting with Azure as the web Portal doesn't support these features fully yet.
episodes.title: Configure a Multi-Site Gateway
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.255 --> 00:00:10.255
[MUSIC]

Replication is going to bring those new

So this isn't, trying to think of

So this can definitely be very beneficial,

679
00:36:24.650 --> 00:36:25.460
>> It's descriptive.

680
00:36:25.460 --> 00:36:27.590
>> It's descriptive,
that's what I'm looking for.

681
00:36:27.590 --> 00:36:29.600
So, all right, so
we'll give it a second, but.

682
00:36:29.600 --> 00:36:32.748
I mean really, as soon as you see the
authentication credentials, that means it

683
00:36:32.748 --> 00:36:35.592
reached out, found the domain
controller for that domain, said sure.

684
00:36:35.592 --> 00:36:40.345
I'll let you join if you've got the
appropriate credentials to create a new

685
00:36:40.345 --> 00:36:43.316
computer account in
Active Directory to add and

686
00:36:43.316 --> 00:36:47.290
then to map this computer to that account,
so hopefully I do.

687
00:36:47.290 --> 00:36:49.950
I am their domain admin there,
so we're good.

688
00:36:49.950 --> 00:36:51.580
Welcome to the domain, we'll click okay.

689
00:36:52.610 --> 00:36:58.130
Wait for the next message and
OK, and then close and restart.

690
00:36:58.130 --> 00:36:59.040
And we're good to go.

691
00:36:59.040 --> 00:37:01.240
So at this point, we've added a branch.

692
00:37:01.240 --> 00:37:06.180
Now it might have seemed a little bit
complex, but if you really boil it down to

693
00:37:06.180 --> 00:37:10.450
what we did, and once you've done it once,
it's extremely easy.

694
00:37:10.450 --> 00:37:11.920
I downloaded my configuration file.

695
00:37:11.920 --> 00:37:14.840
I would already have that downloaded and
saved somewhere, right,

696
00:37:14.840 --> 00:37:16.400
if this was my actual network.

697
00:37:16.400 --> 00:37:18.440
So all I did was copy and paste and

698
00:37:18.440 --> 00:37:23.610
modify a couple of entries in the config
file and then upload it to Azure, right?

699
00:37:23.610 --> 00:37:28.620
Then I ran a PowerShell command to get
the key for the new tunnel that I created.

700
00:37:28.620 --> 00:37:31.539
And then I ran that script on
my routing remote access server,

701
00:37:31.539 --> 00:37:33.910
popped in the new key,
and we're up and running.

702
00:37:33.910 --> 00:37:36.682
So I mean in the end,
it's not very difficult, and

703
00:37:36.682 --> 00:37:38.990
it wouldn't take you that long at all.

704
00:37:38.990 --> 00:37:39.600
>> No, not at all.

705
00:37:39.600 --> 00:37:42.860
I mean we're sitting here
explaining it to you and

706
00:37:42.860 --> 00:37:47.440
that little over 30 minutes now,
but that's all it took.

707
00:37:47.440 --> 00:37:49.640
If Mike wasn't trying to
tell you how to do it,

708
00:37:49.640 --> 00:37:51.894
he could have probably had
it done in about 15 minutes.

709
00:37:51.894 --> 00:37:54.410
And he'd have been live at 5, ready to go.

710
00:37:54.410 --> 00:37:57.880
Well Mike, we have done a lot in this
episode, a lot of very practical,

711
00:37:57.880 --> 00:37:58.910
good stuff.

712
00:37:58.910 --> 00:38:02.280
It was a good learning experience,
hopefully for you, it was for us as well.

713
00:38:02.280 --> 00:38:03.710
Sometimes we've gotta go back to square.

714
00:38:03.710 --> 00:38:06.530
Mike, is there anything else that we
need to talk about in this episode?

715
00:38:06.530 --> 00:38:09.780
>> I don't think so, as far as I remember,
this was all done through the classic,

716
00:38:09.780 --> 00:38:14.270
it is going to be different if
you're using the modern portal.

717
00:38:14.270 --> 00:38:17.030
But we're gonna show you that in
future episodes, so don't worry.

718
00:38:17.030 --> 00:38:18.270
>> All right, well,
we look forward to that.

719
00:38:18.270 --> 00:38:19.180
Thank you again Mike, for

720
00:38:19.180 --> 00:38:22.540
showing up and teaching us
these good skills for us today.

721
00:38:22.540 --> 00:38:23.800
Thank you guys for watching.

722
00:38:23.800 --> 00:38:25.415
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

723
00:38:25.415 --> 00:38:27.275
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

724
00:38:27.275 --> 00:38:28.086
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

725
00:38:28.086 --> 00:38:30.223
>> And we'll see you next time.

726
00:38:30.223 --> 00:38:38.190
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel show you how to setup and configure a Point to Site VPN with Microsoft Azure for connecting mobile clients. They begin by explaining how to setup the security certificates that will be required to make the connection. Then they walk you through downloading and installing the VPN client configuration for the mobile device and finally connect to Azure using the Point to Site VPN.
episodes.title: Configuring Point-to-Site VPN
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.004 --> 00:00:10.004
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.019 --> 00:00:16.860
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.860 --> 00:00:18.970
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:18.970 --> 00:00:22.570
And in today's episode, well, we are
continuing on with that active directory.

5
00:00:22.570 --> 00:00:24.600
I can't even get the word out of my mouth.

6
00:00:24.600 --> 00:00:28.470
In Azure, so AD in Azure series,
we've been working very diligently on.

7
00:00:28.470 --> 00:00:32.790
Joining us back in the studio again today,
helping us guide this lovely little star

8
00:00:32.790 --> 00:00:35.780
that we're on, is none other than
our good friend, Mr. Mike Rogers.

9
00:00:35.780 --> 00:00:37.140
Mike, welcome back to the show, sir.

10
00:00:37.140 --> 00:00:38.700
>> Thanks for having me back,
and you're right.

11
00:00:38.700 --> 00:00:41.350
We're continuing on with
Active Directory in Azure.

12
00:00:41.350 --> 00:00:42.540
And in today's episode,

13
00:00:42.540 --> 00:00:47.320
we're going to be looking at what we
call a point-to-site VPN connection.

14
00:00:47.320 --> 00:00:49.910
Now, we've seen a couple VPN's
that we've set up, right?

15
00:00:49.910 --> 00:00:53.240
We've had our corporate network,
our on-premises network.

16
00:00:53.240 --> 00:00:57.370
We've created a site-to-site VPN
out there to our Azure network, and

17
00:00:57.370 --> 00:01:00.290
then we've created a second,
like a branch office.

18
00:01:00.290 --> 00:01:03.070
And we created another
site-to-site VPN from there.

19
00:01:03.070 --> 00:01:07.450
So we ended up making a multi-site
VPN end-point up there in Azure.

20
00:01:07.450 --> 00:01:11.020
So that pretty much covers what you
would do with that kind of thing.

21
00:01:11.020 --> 00:01:12.860
Where you've got your corporate office and

22
00:01:12.860 --> 00:01:15.770
needs to replicate with the main
controllers up there at the branch office.

23
00:01:15.770 --> 00:01:17.780
You got, I'm sorry, up there in Azure.

24
00:01:17.780 --> 00:01:21.300
You've got branch offices that maybe
don't have domain controllers.

25
00:01:21.300 --> 00:01:25.310
So you setup a site-to-site VPN and
now they can authenticate using the domain

26
00:01:25.310 --> 00:01:29.440
controllers that are located out there
in Azure, acts as other resources and

27
00:01:29.440 --> 00:01:30.660
what have you.

28
00:01:30.660 --> 00:01:35.360
This next one that we wanna do, again,
the site or the point-to-site VPN, now if

29
00:01:35.360 --> 00:01:39.780
I can keep all of these straight, is
another one that's gonna be commonly used.

30
00:01:39.780 --> 00:01:42.310
When you're running resources
out there in Azure.

31
00:01:42.310 --> 00:01:45.630
And that's because you're gonna
have users that you need to support

32
00:01:45.630 --> 00:01:46.880
that are traveling, right.

33
00:01:46.880 --> 00:01:48.550
They're not at the corporate office.

34
00:01:48.550 --> 00:01:50.560
They're not at a branch location.

35
00:01:50.560 --> 00:01:51.220
They're traveling.

36
00:01:51.220 --> 00:01:52.080
They're at a hotel.

37
00:01:52.080 --> 00:01:53.420
They're at Starbucks.

38
00:01:53.420 --> 00:01:55.070
An airport.

39
00:01:55.070 --> 00:01:56.500
Whatever the case may be.

40
00:01:56.500 --> 00:02:00.320
Or as Daniel and I were talking about the
other day, you know, they might be a home

41
00:02:00.320 --> 00:02:04.760
worker, right, where we want them to
be able to set up a VPN connection

42
00:02:04.760 --> 00:02:09.060
from their computer at home into Azure so
they can access those resources.

43
00:02:09.060 --> 00:02:13.070
Now we were talking about the fact
you could just do a site-to-site VPN

44
00:02:13.070 --> 00:02:14.090
from their house, right?

45
00:02:14.090 --> 00:02:15.120
And then any computer,

46
00:02:15.120 --> 00:02:18.850
device at their home could connect
to those Azure resources or

47
00:02:18.850 --> 00:02:22.560
it might be where you don't want that and
you just want a single machine.

48
00:02:22.560 --> 00:02:26.100
You've issued them a laptop, and
that's the only one you want them using

49
00:02:26.100 --> 00:02:28.440
to connect out there to
your Azure resources or

50
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:32.170
the rest of your corporate network, so
maybe you do what we call a point-to-site.

51
00:02:32.170 --> 00:02:33.140
And that's all it means.

52
00:02:33.140 --> 00:02:34.410
Point to site.

53
00:02:34.410 --> 00:02:38.330
Instead of the entire site
having a tunnel back to Azure,

54
00:02:38.330 --> 00:02:42.590
we're going from a single point, a single
endpoint, typically a laptop usually.

55
00:02:42.590 --> 00:02:45.190
But some endpoint device up to Azure.

56
00:02:45.190 --> 00:02:47.940
So that's what we're going to do today.

57
00:02:47.940 --> 00:02:51.970
And if I put it on my drawing here just so
we can keep it all straight and kinda keep

58
00:02:51.970 --> 00:02:56.730
track of what we've done, I'm just gonna
dump one of these laptops right out here.

59
00:02:56.730 --> 00:03:01.310
And say they wanna make
a connection back into Azure.

60
00:03:01.310 --> 00:03:05.640
So we'll just kinda give him
a little connection here.

61
00:03:05.640 --> 00:03:07.540
We'll drag that guy up and

62
00:03:07.540 --> 00:03:10.530
we're basically doing,
well we'll do it like the rest of them.

63
00:03:10.530 --> 00:03:14.150
We're connecting him there, right.

64
00:03:14.150 --> 00:03:15.030
So that's what we're doing.

65
00:03:15.030 --> 00:03:19.060
So now for this, obviously it's only
going to be good for that one node.

66
00:03:19.060 --> 00:03:22.780
So if I had five different sales people
that travel that needed to access

67
00:03:22.780 --> 00:03:27.850
resources up there in Azure,
I would need five different point-to-site

68
00:03:27.850 --> 00:03:32.020
connectivities, or
point-to-site VPN tunnels, which is fine.

69
00:03:32.020 --> 00:03:33.550
Azure supports that.

70
00:03:33.550 --> 00:03:35.530
I'll look up the number in just a minute,

71
00:03:35.530 --> 00:03:38.979
I can't remember exactly how many
they support, but it's pretty large.

72
00:03:39.990 --> 00:03:44.890
All right, so to do it it's actually
really simple, believe it or not.

73
00:03:44.890 --> 00:03:47.580
You see what we've gone through
to create the site-to-site VPNs,

74
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:51.560
none of it was all that complex we
just had to figure out where to go and

75
00:03:51.560 --> 00:03:55.750
what to do and once you've seen it and
done it once or twice, it's not too bad.

76
00:03:55.750 --> 00:03:58.720
They've made this process relatively easy.

77
00:03:58.720 --> 00:04:00.020
It's pretty darn painless.

78
00:04:00.020 --> 00:04:01.200
I really like it.

79
00:04:01.200 --> 00:04:05.270
The first thing you need to do is decide
how you're going to authenticate,

80
00:04:05.270 --> 00:04:06.580
well I shouldn't say that.

81
00:04:06.580 --> 00:04:08.070
You're gonna use certificates.

82
00:04:08.070 --> 00:04:11.280
That's what you're gonna use cuz that's
what Microsoft's gonna allow you to use.

83
00:04:11.280 --> 00:04:14.940
The question you have to ask is,
where do I get those certificates, right?

84
00:04:14.940 --> 00:04:20.150
We're gonna install a certificate
on that client machine and that's

85
00:04:20.150 --> 00:04:25.015
what it's going to use to authenticate,
back up to Azure and establish that

86
00:04:25.015 --> 00:04:29.500
point-to-site connectivity, so we're
really gonna need a few certificates.

87
00:04:29.500 --> 00:04:32.520
We need one for
the Azure location itself, and

88
00:04:32.520 --> 00:04:36.130
we're gonna put a trusted
root certificate up there.

89
00:04:36.130 --> 00:04:39.260
And then we're gonna generate
client certificates for

90
00:04:39.260 --> 00:04:42.440
each one of my nodes that
needs to be able to establish

91
00:04:42.440 --> 00:04:46.010
that point-to-site connectivity and then
we install it on each one of those nodes.

92
00:04:46.010 --> 00:04:48.670
And it's really no different than
what you probably do every day in

93
00:04:48.670 --> 00:04:49.400
a corporate network.

94
00:04:49.400 --> 00:04:50.210
>> That's right.

95
00:04:50.210 --> 00:04:54.570
And Mike's used the lovely little buzz
word there that was certificates, and

96
00:04:54.570 --> 00:04:57.550
that makes me think immediately,
my mind jumps to a PKI,

97
00:04:57.550 --> 00:05:02.040
a public key infrastructure,
having all that built into place.

98
00:05:02.040 --> 00:05:05.390
If you're in a corporate environment, that
is probably already set up and in place,

99
00:05:05.390 --> 00:05:10.330
because, well, we use this kinda thing a
little bit in the enterprise environment.

100
00:05:10.330 --> 00:05:11.860
Is that what we're talking about here,
Mike?

101
00:05:11.860 --> 00:05:12.430
>> It could be.

102
00:05:12.430 --> 00:05:15.260
You actually have choices, and
it's cool that we do have a choice.

103
00:05:15.260 --> 00:05:16.350
But you're exactly right.

104
00:05:16.350 --> 00:05:19.920
Most organizations are gonna have public
key infrastructure set up already.

105
00:05:19.920 --> 00:05:24.060
They're issuing certificates to their
users, as well as their devices.

106
00:05:24.060 --> 00:05:28.460
They're using them for various purposes
to sign emails or to authenticate, or

107
00:05:28.460 --> 00:05:29.600
what have you.

108
00:05:29.600 --> 00:05:31.480
So you've already got that
infrastructure set up.

109
00:05:31.480 --> 00:05:33.340
You can definitely leverage that.

110
00:05:33.340 --> 00:05:38.410
Issue certificates for this purpose and
use them and you'll be good to go.

111
00:05:38.410 --> 00:05:42.960
But what if you don't have
an Enterprise PKI already set up?

112
00:05:42.960 --> 00:05:44.400
Right?
Maybe you've got one or

113
00:05:44.400 --> 00:05:49.300
two certificates that you've bought
from Verisign or or Equifax, or GTE, or

114
00:05:49.300 --> 00:05:53.340
one of those third-party
certificate vendors out there for

115
00:05:53.340 --> 00:05:56.675
your website and for the front end
of your exchange, but that's it.

116
00:05:56.675 --> 00:06:00.485
You don't use certificates internally,
you're not running your own PKI.

117
00:06:00.485 --> 00:06:01.635
Are you left out?

118
00:06:01.635 --> 00:06:02.975
Absolutely not.

119
00:06:02.975 --> 00:06:05.165
You could purchase certificates, but

120
00:06:05.165 --> 00:06:07.853
we can take advantage of
self-signed certificates.

121
00:06:07.853 --> 00:06:10.215
And self-signed
certificates are just that.

122
00:06:10.215 --> 00:06:13.695
Rather than being signed by
some trusted third party, or

123
00:06:13.695 --> 00:06:18.930
some trusted Enterprise PKI,
We're going to sign them ourselves.

124
00:06:18.930 --> 00:06:21.010
And, you might think,
what good is that, then?

125
00:06:21.010 --> 00:06:22.010
I could do whatever I want.

126
00:06:22.010 --> 00:06:24.070
And you could, and that's okay, right?

127
00:06:24.070 --> 00:06:29.060
It's your VPN endpoint, its your Azure
network, its your clients, they don't need

128
00:06:29.060 --> 00:06:34.880
to be trusted by anybody else, as long as
your nodes trust them, you're good to go.

129
00:06:34.880 --> 00:06:35.730
That's it.

130
00:06:35.730 --> 00:06:40.060
So, you can still take advantage of
this being a small organization.

131
00:06:40.060 --> 00:06:43.300
By using, we can create our
own self-signed certificates.

132
00:06:43.300 --> 00:06:46.800
Or if you're testing or playing around or
just trying to get used to, or

133
00:06:46.800 --> 00:06:50.840
learning your way about it with Azure,
you can use this method as well.

134
00:06:50.840 --> 00:06:53.830
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
show you that method because

135
00:06:53.830 --> 00:06:55.070
it's not something you see every day.

136
00:06:55.070 --> 00:06:58.760
I've been doing this for a long time,
and I don't know that I've ever really

137
00:06:58.760 --> 00:07:01.700
played around with making my
own certificates before this.

138
00:07:01.700 --> 00:07:04.310
We always study Enterprise PKI, right.

139
00:07:04.310 --> 00:07:08.810
Installing a certificate authority,
setting up via hierarchy of certificate

140
00:07:08.810 --> 00:07:13.530
authorities, and issuing certificates and
using group policy to issue them out.

141
00:07:13.530 --> 00:07:17.400
This is something that we don't see
everyday but it could be very useful for

142
00:07:17.400 --> 00:07:18.330
test environments.

143
00:07:18.330 --> 00:07:21.580
I can think of many places where I could
have used some self-signed certificates.

144
00:07:21.580 --> 00:07:25.580
Heck, I'm thinking right now at my own
house with my little Linksys router,

145
00:07:25.580 --> 00:07:28.480
you know, getting a certificate
installed on there and being able to set

146
00:07:28.480 --> 00:07:31.060
up a secure connection, I'm like hey,
I don't have to buy one from Verisign.

147
00:07:31.060 --> 00:07:34.350
>> That's right, and every now and
then it's fun to get away with a quick and

148
00:07:34.350 --> 00:07:37.180
dirty way to do it because,
well, A, you gotta remember,

149
00:07:37.180 --> 00:07:40.180
you're working with inside of a,
even though we're kind of transversing

150
00:07:40.180 --> 00:07:45.000
the internet, that's still okay that we're
working with our own certificates because,

151
00:07:45.000 --> 00:07:48.280
well, we're controlling all that and
we trust ourselves, at least I hope we do.

152
00:07:48.280 --> 00:07:49.040
>> [LAUGH] For the most part.

153
00:07:49.040 --> 00:07:52.170
>> You know, I've been know to
make a mistake from time to time.

154
00:07:52.170 --> 00:07:56.794
But I try to run on the assumption that
I'm doing myself a favor on any endeavor

155
00:07:56.794 --> 00:07:58.157
that I've jumped on.

156
00:07:58.157 --> 00:07:59.973
So that's kinda what
we're dealing with here.

157
00:07:59.973 --> 00:08:00.848
>> Exactly.

158
00:08:00.848 --> 00:08:03.477
So let's take a look at how
we can go about doing this.

159
00:08:03.477 --> 00:08:06.863
And this way you'll really get
both methods out of it, right?

160
00:08:06.863 --> 00:08:10.150
Because I'm gonna show you how to
create your own certificates and

161
00:08:10.150 --> 00:08:11.620
set this up using that.

162
00:08:11.620 --> 00:08:15.050
If you've got a public key infrastructure,
or access to certificates,

163
00:08:15.050 --> 00:08:18.060
then it's gonna be the same concept,
you're just not making the certificates.

164
00:08:18.060 --> 00:08:19.860
You still have to upload
them the same way.

165
00:08:19.860 --> 00:08:22.940
You still have to install them
on client machines the same way.

166
00:08:22.940 --> 00:08:24.490
So that process is not gonna change,

167
00:08:24.490 --> 00:08:26.700
it’s just where you’re
getting the certificate from.

168
00:08:26.700 --> 00:08:30.090
So I’m gonna show you this method, if
you’ve got your own PKI that’s fine too.

169
00:08:30.090 --> 00:08:32.660
Just generate your own
certificates from your PKI,

170
00:08:32.660 --> 00:08:37.129
and then use them the way we use
these self-signed certificates here.

171
00:08:37.129 --> 00:08:42.270
All right, so that being said,
let's see how we can get this done.

172
00:08:42.270 --> 00:08:46.517
The first thing we're going to need
is a way to make those certificates.

173
00:08:46.517 --> 00:08:49.970
Right, I can't just open up Notepad and
try to generate one that way.

174
00:08:49.970 --> 00:08:54.490
So Microsoft actually has a tool
called MakeCert, makecert.exe.
