00:20:49.120 --> 00:20:51.322
That's quite a few if you
had different 20 roots,

404
00:20:51.322 --> 00:20:54.126
I'd say maybe we need to rethink
your public infrastructure, but

405
00:20:54.126 --> 00:20:56.999
you know you might have a good reason for
doing something like that.

406
00:20:56.999 --> 00:21:00.801
So, maybe you do but you can upload
up to 20 certificates up here,

407
00:21:00.801 --> 00:21:01.946
more if you need to.

408
00:21:01.946 --> 00:21:04.811
If you contact them, I'm sure they'll
charge you a little bit of money and

409
00:21:04.811 --> 00:21:05.459
let you do more.

410
00:21:05.459 --> 00:21:08.711
All right, so
now the root cert is up there on Azure and

411
00:21:08.711 --> 00:21:11.650
it's associated with my Azure subnet.

412
00:21:11.650 --> 00:21:13.920
So we are halfway there.

413
00:21:13.920 --> 00:21:15.150
More than halfway.

414
00:21:15.150 --> 00:21:18.090
All right, now we go back over to
the command prompt, all right, and

415
00:21:18.090 --> 00:21:20.110
we're gonna run that makecert.

416
00:21:20.110 --> 00:21:24.560
So what I need to do now is generate
certificates that I install on the client

417
00:21:24.560 --> 00:21:26.570
machine, okay?

418
00:21:26.570 --> 00:21:33.956
So for that, we're going to use the same
command prompt here, makecert -n.

419
00:21:33.956 --> 00:21:38.879
And then in quote cn equals and
I'm gonna call this one I

420
00:21:38.879 --> 00:21:43.710
can't remember what I call
this little laptop here.

421
00:21:43.710 --> 00:21:46.760
I'm gonna say laptop01.

422
00:21:48.430 --> 00:21:50.306
I know that's not his name but
that's what we'll call it.

423
00:21:50.306 --> 00:21:55.473
I also have laptop 01 in my quotes and

424
00:21:55.473 --> 00:22:00.002
then it's -pe -skyexchange.

425
00:22:00.002 --> 00:22:05.656
Make sure I don't make any typos there,

426
00:22:05.656 --> 00:22:12.150
-m96-66my -in, and then open quote.

427
00:22:12.150 --> 00:22:18.199
And then here, I need to do AzureRootCert,

428
00:22:18.199 --> 00:22:22.294
and end my quote, all right?

429
00:22:22.294 --> 00:22:30.753
And then -is my -a sha1, all right?

430
00:22:30.753 --> 00:22:36.457
So what we're doing is we're generating
a certificate in the name of laptop 01,

431
00:22:36.457 --> 00:22:39.153
but issued by AzureRootCert, right?

432
00:22:39.153 --> 00:22:40.230
Starting to make sense?

433
00:22:40.230 --> 00:22:43.605
Especially those of you that
understand public infrastructure?

434
00:22:43.605 --> 00:22:46.100
You got that root certificate
up there on Azure.

435
00:22:46.100 --> 00:22:49.180
This certificate I'm generating
is gonna have a trust chain,

436
00:22:49.180 --> 00:22:53.120
right, back up to that root
certificate that we uploaded To Azure.

437
00:22:53.120 --> 00:22:57.580
So I'll go ahead and hit Enter,
and it succeeds, right?

438
00:22:57.580 --> 00:22:58.990
Now here's the trick with this,

439
00:22:58.990 --> 00:23:04.730
you will need to generate a different
certificate for each node, all right.

440
00:23:04.730 --> 00:23:08.720
So if I add another laptop, what I would
do is I would just come in here like this

441
00:23:08.720 --> 00:23:12.650
and I would change this to laptop02.

442
00:23:12.650 --> 00:23:14.630
All right and I would continue on and

443
00:23:14.630 --> 00:23:19.950
make as many certificates as I needed for
different devices.

444
00:23:19.950 --> 00:23:24.119
And anytime somebody says, "Hey I need
another one of those certs." I can open up

445
00:23:24.119 --> 00:23:27.933
this computer the one that has the root
certificate that I generated on it and

446
00:23:27.933 --> 00:23:29.184
I can run this command and

447
00:23:29.184 --> 00:23:32.301
I can generate more client
certificates based off that root.

448
00:23:32.301 --> 00:23:33.971
So you can generate a few at a time.

449
00:23:33.971 --> 00:23:38.647
You can wait until you need one,
come back in and issue it.

450
00:23:38.647 --> 00:23:42.052
All right now we need to,
let's go check and

451
00:23:42.052 --> 00:23:47.209
see let's do a little Microsoft
management console real quick and

452
00:23:47.209 --> 00:23:53.396
we'll add our certificate snap in and
just verify that Mike's not lying to us.

453
00:23:53.396 --> 00:23:54.395
>> At least not about this.

454
00:23:54.395 --> 00:23:56.467
>> Yeah, right [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

455
00:23:56.467 --> 00:23:58.176
>> All right, and we go on here.

456
00:23:58.176 --> 00:24:01.528
And there's my AzureRootCert
sitting right there.

457
00:24:01.528 --> 00:24:05.734
And there's my three for
laptop01, laptop02 and laptop03.

458
00:24:05.734 --> 00:24:09.552
Now I said you've got to create one for
each laptop and then install it.

459
00:24:09.552 --> 00:24:12.320
So let's say Daniel had laptop two.

460
00:24:12.320 --> 00:24:16.730
Well what I would need to do is
export this key, or this certificate.

461
00:24:16.730 --> 00:24:20.820
I'd say right click all tasks, export.

462
00:24:20.820 --> 00:24:26.030
I would click next and I'd say yes
export that private key, and next.

463
00:24:26.030 --> 00:24:30.790
And I'd create this PFX file,

464
00:24:30.790 --> 00:24:35.360
send it over to Daniel, tell him to
install it into his trusted certificates,

465
00:24:35.360 --> 00:24:39.930
or install it myself, whatever
the process that our organization uses.

466
00:24:39.930 --> 00:24:43.260
So you just export that out,
give it to the other laptop.

467
00:24:43.260 --> 00:24:44.070
Have them install it.

468
00:24:44.070 --> 00:24:46.750
The one for
laptop one is already installed.

469
00:24:46.750 --> 00:24:49.065
This is where I generated it.

470
00:24:49.065 --> 00:24:55.770
All right now that is successful or that
we were successful there I'm not gonna.

471
00:24:55.770 --> 00:24:58.620
Actually let's just minimize that
in case we want to come back.

472
00:24:58.620 --> 00:25:01.370
All right so we've got the root
certificate generated up there and

473
00:25:01.370 --> 00:25:03.100
uploaded to Azure.

474
00:25:03.100 --> 00:25:05.420
I've got the client
certificate created and

475
00:25:05.420 --> 00:25:09.338
installed in my certificate
store on my laptop.

476
00:25:09.338 --> 00:25:13.550
We've enabled point-to-site
connectivity in Azure.

477
00:25:13.550 --> 00:25:16.780
The only thing we have left to do
is establish the VPN connection now

478
00:25:16.780 --> 00:25:19.230
from the client to Azure.

479
00:25:19.230 --> 00:25:21.550
How do we do that, well, watch.

480
00:25:21.550 --> 00:25:25.850
Remember that little script we used to set
up our VPN server that Microsoft was so

481
00:25:25.850 --> 00:25:27.100
nice to give us?

482
00:25:27.100 --> 00:25:28.530
Let's see what they do for this.

483
00:25:28.530 --> 00:25:30.730
I'm going to back over to
the dashboard actually,

484
00:25:30.730 --> 00:25:32.310
that was a little misclick there.

485
00:25:32.310 --> 00:25:35.630
I'm on my Azure subnet,
back over to dashboard,

486
00:25:35.630 --> 00:25:37.830
and you'll see things have
changed here already.

487
00:25:37.830 --> 00:25:39.549
There's my ITPRoTV LAN.

488
00:25:39.549 --> 00:25:44.950
This one is for my point to site
connectivity, I've got zero clients.

489
00:25:44.950 --> 00:25:47.800
I scroll down though our
quick glance has changed.

490
00:25:47.800 --> 00:25:54.180
It used to be download VPN device script,
now I've got a couple extra links here.

491
00:25:54.180 --> 00:25:56.760
Because we checked the check mark for
the for

492
00:25:56.760 --> 00:26:01.199
point to site connectivity I'm going to
download the 64-bit client VPN package.

493
00:26:04.470 --> 00:26:06.800
And we'll let that process run just for
a second.

494
00:26:06.800 --> 00:26:11.100
So it's basically downloading
a little VPN configuration.

495
00:26:11.100 --> 00:26:13.330
And I could save it and then run it.

496
00:26:13.330 --> 00:26:14.840
I'm just gonna run it from right here.

497
00:26:14.840 --> 00:26:20.690
All right, and
it tells me that Windows protected my PC.

498
00:26:20.690 --> 00:26:22.840
Thank you, Window, for keeping me safe.

499
00:26:22.840 --> 00:26:25.530
So I'm gonna click More info,
and run it anyway.

500
00:26:27.770 --> 00:26:33.090
And then yes, do I wish to install
a VPN client for Azure Subnet?

501
00:26:33.090 --> 00:26:34.650
Yes I do.

502
00:26:36.780 --> 00:26:39.194
And that's it, right.

503
00:26:39.194 --> 00:26:44.535
It flashes, it whirs, and
let's see what happened there.

504
00:26:44.535 --> 00:26:47.120
Gonna go ahead and minimize everything.

505
00:26:47.120 --> 00:26:49.990
And we'll take a look at my networks,
and take a look.

506
00:26:49.990 --> 00:26:53.650
There is my VPN connection for
Azure subnet.

507
00:26:53.650 --> 00:26:55.660
And before I connect,
let's just see something here.

508
00:26:55.660 --> 00:27:00.900
If l take a look, this machine,
in fact, let's close this guy.

509
00:27:00.900 --> 00:27:03.630
This is a virtual machine
that I am running.

510
00:27:03.630 --> 00:27:05.440
And it's not on any of my networks, right?

511
00:27:05.440 --> 00:27:10.940
It's not on my corporate network,
the 10.1.1 network.

512
00:27:10.940 --> 00:27:12.504
it's not on Azure, 10.1.2.

513
00:27:12.504 --> 00:27:15.429
It's not in the Tokyo office, 10.1.3.

514
00:27:15.429 --> 00:27:19.080
So it really has no connectivity
other than Internet access.

515
00:27:19.080 --> 00:27:24.090
So this would be just like a laptop
sitting at the hotel or at the airport.

516
00:27:24.090 --> 00:27:28.655
If I do a little ip config,
you'll see my ip address is

517
00:27:28.655 --> 00:27:33.936
actually [SOUND] 192.168.238.135, right.

518
00:27:33.936 --> 00:27:39.790
I do have internet access
from this machine.

519
00:27:39.790 --> 00:27:41.870
I'm getting now behind it a NAT device so

520
00:27:41.870 --> 00:27:44.270
I'm able to go out and
get internet access.

521
00:27:44.270 --> 00:27:48.060
But if I tried to ping 10.1.2.4
that DC up there in azure,

522
00:27:48.060 --> 00:27:51.730
that's not going to work, right?

523
00:27:51.730 --> 00:27:57.140
It's a private IP address, has no idea
where that is or how to access it.

524
00:27:57.140 --> 00:27:59.392
>> Not even on the same network if it did.

525
00:27:59.392 --> 00:28:02.500
[INAUDIBLE] completely separate networks,
this is just like any, your home,

526
00:28:02.500 --> 00:28:06.720
just like a network at home,
just like a network in a coffee house.

527
00:28:06.720 --> 00:28:09.200
Or at, like Mike said,
an airport, something like that.

528
00:28:09.200 --> 00:28:11.540
These private networks are all over the
place and we can connect to them a lot.

529
00:28:11.540 --> 00:28:13.820
Especially if we're mobile users.

530
00:28:13.820 --> 00:28:17.600
Nothing dissimilar from anything you've
probably encountered in the past.

531
00:28:17.600 --> 00:28:20.960
>> So we'll go here and
click on that azure subnet.

532
00:28:20.960 --> 00:28:21.750
And click Connect.

533
00:28:24.100 --> 00:28:27.970
And it tells me to click Connect to begin
connecting, to work offline click Cancel.

534
00:28:27.970 --> 00:28:29.600
Well, we're going to click Connect.

535
00:28:30.710 --> 00:28:33.860
And tells me I can
update my routing table.

536
00:28:33.860 --> 00:28:35.690
It will update my routing table, right.

537
00:28:35.690 --> 00:28:39.350
Because again,
here I am with this laptop at a hotel.

538
00:28:39.350 --> 00:28:44.430
Even once I establish this connection,
does my computer know, hey anything going

539
00:28:44.430 --> 00:28:49.580
to the 10.1.2.0 network, my Azure subnet,
send it through this particular tunnel.

540
00:28:49.580 --> 00:28:55.720
So I'll say continue, and
then I'm going to select my certificate.

541
00:28:55.720 --> 00:29:00.690
Because I have multiples, all right,
I could export those other two out.

542
00:29:00.690 --> 00:29:03.690
And then remove them from
my certificate store so

543
00:29:03.690 --> 00:29:05.800
that I wouldn't get this
message every time.

544
00:29:05.800 --> 00:29:08.580
Just leave the one for
this particular laptop.

545
00:29:08.580 --> 00:29:11.338
But I'll select that one, I'll click OK.

546
00:29:14.856 --> 00:29:19.227
And then, like magic,
nothing happens, right.

547
00:29:19.227 --> 00:29:22.350
Now, you guys know how it is,
I always love teasing people with that.

548
00:29:22.350 --> 00:29:26.180
It's not like people always confuse
VPNs and remote desktop, and they do

549
00:29:26.180 --> 00:29:30.620
a VPN connection, they expect a desktop
to open up or a different background.

550
00:29:30.620 --> 00:29:34.910
A VPN connection is just like taking
a cable from your machine and

551
00:29:34.910 --> 00:29:36.380
plugging it into a switch.

552
00:29:36.380 --> 00:29:38.650
Nothing changes on your machine per se,

553
00:29:38.650 --> 00:29:42.520
other than the fact that you should now
be able to access new resources, right.

554
00:29:42.520 --> 00:29:49.570
Let's see, ping 10.1.2.4 and
there's my reply.

555
00:29:49.570 --> 00:29:54.970
So this point, I'm sitting at a hotel,
yet I'm connected to that Azure network.

556
00:29:54.970 --> 00:29:57.730
So if I needed to access domain resources.

557
00:29:57.730 --> 00:30:00.660
If I needed to, if they had file servers,

558
00:30:00.660 --> 00:30:06.090
print servers, SharePoint sites, whatever
the case was, I'm now connected to Azure.

559
00:30:06.090 --> 00:30:10.090
I've got a secure tunnel
that's being encrypted

560
00:30:10.090 --> 00:30:11.900
all the way up to that Azure site.

561
00:30:11.900 --> 00:30:16.320
And I could be anywhere that has Internet
access and I can establish that.

562
00:30:16.320 --> 00:30:19.070
That's the key, right, I don't have
to be at the corporate office.

563
00:30:19.070 --> 00:30:21.620
I don't have to be at the branch office.

564
00:30:21.620 --> 00:30:23.530
All I need is internet access and
I'm good to go.

565
00:30:23.530 --> 00:30:25.950
And you saw it,
not to terribly difficult to set up.

566
00:30:25.950 --> 00:30:27.370
>> Yeah and I like your analogy.

567
00:30:27.370 --> 00:30:29.650
It's basically like you
took that lovely and

568
00:30:29.650 --> 00:30:32.930
blue cable you plugged in your computer
and plugged it into the wall and

569
00:30:32.930 --> 00:30:36.570
it magically connected you
to your corporate network.

570
00:30:36.570 --> 00:30:37.912
Giving you access to all those resources.

571
00:30:37.912 --> 00:30:43.140
That's the beauty of VPN and now we're
being able to marry the the Azure,

572
00:30:43.140 --> 00:30:45.671
using Azure as another resource and

573
00:30:45.671 --> 00:30:49.990
saying, I've got a data center
on this side of the world.

574
00:30:49.990 --> 00:30:53.280
Maybe I've flown across the country and
I'm in California.

575
00:30:53.280 --> 00:30:57.240
And now I can access the data center that
we have already there in Azure, right.

576
00:30:57.240 --> 00:31:01.320
It's a quick, fast connection, secure to
the VPN, and I've done it straight from

577
00:31:01.320 --> 00:31:05.430
the laptop when I'm sitting in my
hotel room, accessing resources.

578
00:31:05.430 --> 00:31:07.110
Lovely, lovely way to fly.

579
00:31:07.110 --> 00:31:09.880
And a lot of people do this,
I've seen this,

580
00:31:09.880 --> 00:31:11.810
I've had to implement this
kind of thing before.

581
00:31:11.810 --> 00:31:16.630
So get ready because it is
something you will do if this is

582
00:31:16.630 --> 00:31:18.550
the job description that you sign up for.

583
00:31:18.550 --> 00:31:21.829
Mike, is there anything else that
we need to cover as far as these,

584
00:31:21.829 --> 00:31:24.831
not multisite but
point to site VPN again, very confusing.

585
00:31:24.831 --> 00:31:28.277
>> I don't think it is it's just the key
to remember is you'll need different

586
00:31:28.277 --> 00:31:29.600
certificates for each one.

587
00:31:29.600 --> 00:31:34.530
Now technically that certificate is
not tied to my lap top in anyway.

588
00:31:34.530 --> 00:31:39.580
And I could use that one certificate
across multiple laptops, but best

589
00:31:39.580 --> 00:31:44.380
practice says issue a separate certificate
for each one because I can control access.

590
00:31:44.380 --> 00:31:48.460
I might revoke one of those certificates
if I don't want that person using that

591
00:31:48.460 --> 00:31:50.640
laptop to connect anymore,
maybe they've left the company.

592
00:31:50.640 --> 00:31:53.940
In other words if I start sharing
certificates across machines

593
00:31:53.940 --> 00:31:56.740
I lose all of that control, right.

594
00:31:56.740 --> 00:32:00.160
So, even though you could, best
practice says different certificate for

595
00:32:00.160 --> 00:32:01.440
each laptop.

596
00:32:01.440 --> 00:32:03.750
Not the root,
only one root that we uploaded, but

597
00:32:03.750 --> 00:32:05.660
each laptop get's a different certificate.

598
00:32:05.660 --> 00:32:08.570
>> All right, well thank you so much
Michael for showing us how to do this.

599
00:32:08.570 --> 00:32:13.800
Obviously it's a very handy feature set
to have in our tool kit for us as admins.

600
00:32:13.800 --> 00:32:16.180
Hopefully you've enjoyed it,
I sure had a good time as well.

601
00:32:16.180 --> 00:32:17.360
We thank you for watching.

602
00:32:17.360 --> 00:32:20.410
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

603
00:32:20.410 --> 00:32:21.220
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

604
00:32:21.220 --> 00:32:23.106
>> And we'll see you next time.

605
00:32:23.106 --> 00:32:29.940
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel walk you through the new Azure Portal. Here they show you the differences in the look and function of the new Azure Portal from that of the Classic Azure Portal. They also show you how to use the new Portal to access certain features of the Classic portal.
episodes.title: The New Azure Portal
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.019 --> 00:00:10.019
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.238 --> 00:00:16.560
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.560 --> 00:00:18.400
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

4
00:00:18.400 --> 00:00:22.500
in today's episode we are moving
on with our AD and Azure series.

5
00:00:22.500 --> 00:00:25.816
Joining back in the studio again today
is none other than our good friend Mr.

6
00:00:25.816 --> 00:00:26.530
Mike Roger.

7
00:00:26.530 --> 00:00:28.120
Mike, welcome back to the show sir,
how you doing?

8
00:00:28.120 --> 00:00:29.020
>> Doing great Daniel.

9
00:00:29.020 --> 00:00:29.970
Thanks for having me back.

10
00:00:29.970 --> 00:00:33.340
And today we're gonna be
kinda changing gears.

11
00:00:33.340 --> 00:00:37.520
We've been working in what
we call the classic mode or

12
00:00:37.520 --> 00:00:41.120
the classic portal for
all of these episodes.

13
00:00:41.120 --> 00:00:42.530
And I did that on purpose.

14
00:00:42.530 --> 00:00:45.060
Because one it's been around for
a long time.

15
00:00:45.060 --> 00:00:49.160
This is the original interface
that we used to work with Azure.

16
00:00:49.160 --> 00:00:52.790
So if anybody's out there has already
been working with Azure you're

17
00:00:52.790 --> 00:00:56.610
gonna be familiar with this probably
where you spend a lot of you time.

18
00:00:56.610 --> 00:01:00.870
And it really is I won't say complete cuz

19
00:01:00.870 --> 00:01:03.885
that would imply that the other one is
not, but the other one is not complete.

20
00:01:03.885 --> 00:01:07.500
[LAUGH] So maybe there's nothing
wrong with implying that.

21
00:01:07.500 --> 00:01:10.840
But no, this is the classic portal but
things are changing.

22
00:01:10.840 --> 00:01:15.020
Microsoft is moving to what they call,
their new portal.

23
00:01:15.020 --> 00:01:18.880
This one is being rebranded
as the classic portal and

24
00:01:18.880 --> 00:01:22.390
the new portal is just

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel show you how to create a Site-to-Site VPN using the new Portal in Azure. Starting in the new Azure Portal, they walk you through creating a Resource Group. Next they explain how to create a storage account, a virtual network, subnets for the virtual network, and gateway subnet. Finally they request a public IP address and register the DNS servers.
episodes.title: Create a Site-to-Site VPN

so it is static maybe.

450
00:24:17.790 --> 00:24:21.273
>> So it's a static address
that' been dynamically assigned.

451
00:24:21.273 --> 00:24:23.056
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, there you go, all right so

452
00:24:23.056 --> 00:24:27.960
as counter-intuitive as it might seem,
we're gonna choose dynamic for this one.

453
00:24:27.960 --> 00:24:30.180
Idle time out I'm not going to change.

454
00:24:30.180 --> 00:24:36.383
DNS name label,
I'll call this my ADN Azure

455
00:24:36.383 --> 00:24:41.420
gateway, or something like that.

456
00:24:41.420 --> 00:24:43.900
And, resource group, select existing.

457
00:24:43.900 --> 00:24:47.880
Not configured, so I click on that,
choose that AD in Azure, oops.

458
00:24:47.880 --> 00:24:50.350
Is that the one I've been creating?

459
00:24:50.350 --> 00:24:51.810
You know, I've been using
that one this whole time and

460
00:24:51.810 --> 00:24:55.420
I thought we created a different one.

461
00:24:55.420 --> 00:24:58.670
I was using RG, I'm going to have and
change some of those guys.

462
00:24:58.670 --> 00:25:01.300
I've been using this old test one
that I started, you know what?

463
00:25:01.300 --> 00:25:02.490
I'll just continue to use that.

464
00:25:02.490 --> 00:25:05.750
I'll show you how to change the resource
group later on, how about that?

465
00:25:05.750 --> 00:25:09.940
Because everything I'm doing so
far is AD in Azure test.

466
00:25:09.940 --> 00:25:13.037
We'll go East US, and I'll click create.

467
00:25:16.312 --> 00:25:20.061
And it's gonna go through the process
of requesting a public IP address to be

468
00:25:20.061 --> 00:25:20.890
assigned to me.

469
00:25:20.890 --> 00:25:24.610
So let's see what we've got here.

470
00:25:25.760 --> 00:25:27.300
And there is my Gateway IP.

471
00:25:27.300 --> 00:25:33.990
Now you might think I can see
the actual IP, but it's blank.

472
00:25:33.990 --> 00:25:34.630
All right.
And

473
00:25:34.630 --> 00:25:39.070
that's because really what you've done
is you've created the request for

474
00:25:39.070 --> 00:25:43.730
the IP address but until you associate it
with a resource, it's not going to create.

475
00:25:43.730 --> 00:25:48.250
It's not actually going to
generate the IP address.

476
00:25:48.250 --> 00:25:49.350
I know, I'm telling you, it's odd.

477
00:25:49.350 --> 00:25:50.130
It's different.

478
00:25:50.130 --> 00:25:51.590
>> It's gonna take some getting used to.

479
00:25:51.590 --> 00:25:52.480
[LAUGH]
>> It's different, and

480
00:25:52.480 --> 00:25:55.530
that's why I thought it
would be worth going through

481
00:25:55.530 --> 00:25:59.480
this new portal because this is the way
they want you to do things now.

482
00:25:59.480 --> 00:26:01.780
All right, so we're getting closer.

483
00:26:01.780 --> 00:26:05.920
Now we're going to choose
a Virtual Network Gateway and

484
00:26:05.920 --> 00:26:09.160
we'll see how close we
can come to finishing.

485
00:26:09.160 --> 00:26:11.730
We'll click Add.
And the nice thing about this though,

486
00:26:11.730 --> 00:26:14.840
if you've noticed is if I get
into something and I realize,

487
00:26:14.840 --> 00:26:19.650
I didn't get that public IP address yet, I
can just close that little blade, go back,

488
00:26:19.650 --> 00:26:22.360
get the public IP address and
try it again, right?

489
00:26:22.360 --> 00:26:25.620
It doesn't balk at me,
it doesn't scream, lock anything up, so

490
00:26:25.620 --> 00:26:27.720
it's pretty nice there.

491
00:26:27.720 --> 00:26:29.470
So now, what do we call this one?

492
00:26:29.470 --> 00:26:36.584
Let's call this my Azure NAD Gateway.

493
00:26:38.906 --> 00:26:43.150
All right and my virtual network that
I'm creating as gateway to is VNET 01.

494
00:26:43.150 --> 00:26:45.510
Notice it's not one of the subnets.

495
00:26:45.510 --> 00:26:47.720
It's the actual virtual network.

496
00:26:47.720 --> 00:26:50.060
Public IP address.

497
00:26:50.060 --> 00:26:50.580
Well, there it is.

498
00:26:50.580 --> 00:26:51.550
Notice it says unassigned.

499
00:26:51.550 --> 00:26:53.310
So I'm gonna select it.

500
00:26:54.630 --> 00:26:57.490
Gateway type is gonna be VPN.

501
00:26:57.490 --> 00:27:00.490
Remember this,
route base versus policy base,

502
00:27:00.490 --> 00:27:06.010
to do a site to site VPN it
must be a route base VPN.

503
00:27:07.320 --> 00:27:09.750
Resource group, not configured.

504
00:27:09.750 --> 00:27:12.390
We'll go in and we'll choose that same
resource group I've been using for

505
00:27:12.390 --> 00:27:13.960
everything else.

506
00:27:13.960 --> 00:27:17.656
Location needs US,
pin it to my dashboard, click create, and

507
00:27:17.656 --> 00:27:22.285
then you wait for it to either bounce it
back to it or say yeah, you did it right?

508
00:27:23.355 --> 00:27:27.415
>> Now Mike why doesn't that policy
based VPN work with what we're doing?

509
00:27:27.415 --> 00:27:30.665
>> Because it's specific to
that particular protocols.

510
00:27:30.665 --> 00:27:34.477
You create a policy says I wanna
allow this traffic to go through.

511
00:27:34.477 --> 00:27:38.747
Well if we're gonna put Active Directory
and basically our infrastructure up there

512
00:27:38.747 --> 00:27:41.847
and create a site to site,
it is to allow all protocols.

513
00:27:41.847 --> 00:27:44.507
So rather than having to try and
create a policy for each and

514
00:27:44.507 --> 00:27:47.277
every one,
it allows everything to go through.

515
00:27:47.277 --> 00:27:51.727
Now we can still control and
do filters on the VPN tunnel and

516
00:27:51.727 --> 00:27:55.220
stuff like that to control the traffic,
but it does have to be that route based.

517
00:27:56.700 --> 00:28:02.020
All right, so let that go for just a
minute, it'll deploy that network gateway.

518
00:28:03.430 --> 00:28:08.410
And remember, that's not the actual
gateway, that's the gateway network that's

519
00:28:08.410 --> 00:28:14.000
been created within our gateway subnet
that's part of our virtual network.

520
00:28:14.000 --> 00:28:16.170
>> Yeah, that makes a whole lot of sense.

521
00:28:16.170 --> 00:28:17.180
>> Right.
>> I'm there with you and

522
00:28:17.180 --> 00:28:18.405
hopefully you guys are there as well.

523
00:28:18.405 --> 00:28:22.330
[LAUGH] It can seem a bit complex,
that's for sure.

524
00:28:22.330 --> 00:28:23.910
That's a good way to put it.

525
00:28:23.910 --> 00:28:28.400
But again it's just like anything a lot of
times with these types of systems you just

526
00:28:28.400 --> 00:28:32.110
have to continue to work with them and
see what works and what doesn't work.

527
00:28:32.110 --> 00:28:34.500
Thank goodness Mike has
done the legwork for us, so

528
00:28:34.500 --> 00:28:38.390
far he's showing us all the pitfalls and
hurdles to get around so

529
00:28:38.390 --> 00:28:41.380
that we can implement this a whole lot
quicker than if we were just trying to

530
00:28:41.380 --> 00:28:45.840
stumble through it and figure out how
this system actually works in reality.

531
00:28:45.840 --> 00:28:47.230
>> Yeah, you know, and

532
00:28:47.230 --> 00:28:51.920
another thing that I've found after going
through this new portal a few times is,

533
00:28:51.920 --> 00:28:56.260
you know, like I said, they really want
you to use Power Shell, and I'm ready.

534
00:28:56.260 --> 00:28:59.100
After doing this three or
four times to prep for this show, and

535
00:28:59.100 --> 00:29:02.650
get all this stuff set up so
that we could do it together, I realized,

536
00:29:02.650 --> 00:29:05.410
I don't want to have to
do this all the time.

537
00:29:05.410 --> 00:29:07.500
You know, this is something where
I want a script waiting and

538
00:29:07.500 --> 00:29:10.000
I can just run a script anytime I need to.

539
00:29:10.000 --> 00:29:13.160
So, and we are going to take
a look at doing that as well

540
00:29:13.160 --> 00:29:14.500
at some point in this show.

541
00:29:14.500 --> 00:29:17.180
So I'll show you how to do
all of this via PowerShell.

542
00:29:18.220 --> 00:29:19.982
All right, so that is still deploying.

543
00:29:19.982 --> 00:29:21.510
What else can we look
at while we're waiting?

544
00:29:21.510 --> 00:29:25.300
We've really got most of it ready to go,
right?

545
00:29:25.300 --> 00:29:29.970
The only thing we've got left to do
is create the gateway itself, and

546
00:29:29.970 --> 00:29:31.700
I'd really like to get to that.

547
00:29:31.700 --> 00:29:34.640
Right before we run out of time on this
show because remember from the previous

548
00:29:34.640 --> 00:29:37.250
episodes that's that 30 minute task,
right.

549
00:29:37.250 --> 00:29:38.910
There's just no getting around it.

550
00:29:38.910 --> 00:29:43.460
You click on create the actual gateway and
it takes it, almost to the tee,

551
00:29:43.460 --> 00:29:46.762
I think that every time, or the last time
that I did it it was like 34 minutes.

552
00:29:46.762 --> 00:29:50.740
But it's almost right at
30 minutes on the nose.

553
00:29:50.740 --> 00:29:52.120
It does take a little while.

554
00:29:52.120 --> 00:29:59.740
As soon as this finishes, we should
be able to create our little gateway.

555
00:29:59.740 --> 00:30:00.756
[CROSSTALK]
>> You can refresh the page.

556
00:30:00.756 --> 00:30:01.278
>> Yeah.

557
00:30:01.278 --> 00:30:02.180
[LAUGH]
>> Sometimes that works.

558
00:30:02.180 --> 00:30:05.900
>> You know they were actually
having an issue this morning.

559
00:30:05.900 --> 00:30:09.410
I came in and
there was a blue dot right here and

560
00:30:09.410 --> 00:30:12.080
when I went to click on that
to see what's happening,

561
00:30:12.080 --> 00:30:16.140
there was some informational messages in
East U.S. was actually having a problem.

562
00:30:16.140 --> 00:30:19.230
Here I can see the latest
messages that it was resolved.

563
00:30:19.230 --> 00:30:23.300
What was happening was, any time you
spun up a new machine in East U.S.,

564
00:30:23.300 --> 00:30:26.550
the machine would spin up if you
built a new virtual machine.

565
00:30:27.830 --> 00:30:31.080
But your tile would not show it.

566
00:30:31.080 --> 00:30:33.930
And so I tried to just to see what
would happen and I got a tile for

567
00:30:33.930 --> 00:30:34.550
the new machine.

568
00:30:34.550 --> 00:30:37.000
But it said, deployment failed.

569
00:30:37.000 --> 00:30:39.330
But if I went over here and
went to virtual machines,

570
00:30:39.330 --> 00:30:42.340
you saw the virtual machine and
I can remote into it, it was fine.

571
00:30:42.340 --> 00:30:45.620
But the tile itself is
not updating properly.

572
00:30:45.620 --> 00:30:50.068
So they had an issue and
looks like they have resolved that issue.

573
00:30:50.068 --> 00:30:55.510
But I thought it was pretty impressive
that within 30 minutes of the problem

574
00:30:55.510 --> 00:30:59.040
being discovered they had messages out
letting everybody know what was going on.

575
00:30:59.040 --> 00:31:01.530
They put up messages
every two hours I think,

576
00:31:01.530 --> 00:31:03.670
keeping people posted on the progress.

577
00:31:03.670 --> 00:31:06.140
And as soon as it was resolved,
they posted another message,

578
00:31:06.140 --> 00:31:09.760
so pretty cool that they
keep us informed like that.

579
00:31:11.430 --> 00:31:13.420
All right.
Back out here, it is still deploying so

580
00:31:13.420 --> 00:31:17.840
I guess we could take a break here,
come back,

581
00:31:17.840 --> 00:31:20.910
we'll see that it has deployed and
move on from there if you want.

582
00:31:20.910 --> 00:31:22.300
>> All right.
That is perfectly fine.

583
00:31:22.300 --> 00:31:24.460
That's the great thing
about our show format.

584
00:31:24.460 --> 00:31:26.381
As we can do what we want.

585
00:31:26.381 --> 00:31:29.530
[LAUGH] So Mike, I look forward to
seeing you there and thank you for

586
00:31:29.530 --> 00:31:31.480
showing us what we've learned so far.

587
00:31:31.480 --> 00:31:33.510
How to work with this new Azure portal.

588
00:31:33.510 --> 00:31:37.140
There is a couple new little hiccups
since you got to be familiar with.

589
00:31:37.140 --> 00:31:41.090
But once we get there and Mike's doing
a great job of leading us down that road,

590
00:31:41.090 --> 00:31:44.308
we'll be able to use that new
portal as well as the classic.

591
00:31:44.308 --> 00:31:45.830
So Mike, I look forward to
seeing you in the next show and

592
00:31:45.830 --> 00:31:47.930
look forward to seeing you there as well.

593
00:31:47.930 --> 00:31:48.504
Thanks for watching.

594
00:31:48.504 --> 00:31:50.582
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

595
00:31:50.582 --> 00:31:51.767
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

596
00:31:51.767 --> 00:31:52.787
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

597
00:31:52.787 --> 00:31:53.658
>> We'll see you next time.

598
00:31:53.658 --> 00:32:02.960
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel finished creating the Site-to-Site VPN. They pickup by creating local network gateway and create the VPN connection. Then they make sure they can establish the connection. Finally they create a virtual Machine which will be the host for the Azure side replica Domain Controller.
episodes.title: Create a Site-to-Site VPN Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.369 --> 00:00:13.458
All right.

3
00:00:13.458 --> 00:00:17.510
Greetings, everyone, and welcome to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.510 --> 00:00:18.911
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:18.911 --> 00:00:20.151
And, in today's episode, well,

6
00:00:20.151 --> 00:00:23.980
we are moving forward with our
Active Directory in Azure series.

7
00:00:23.980 --> 00:00:28.130
Back again today to join us to help
continue that train down the tracks is

8
00:00:28.130 --> 00:00:29.600
our good friend, Mr. Mike Roderick.

9
00:00:29.600 --> 00:00:31.100
Mike, welcome back to the show, sir.

10
00:00:31.100 --> 00:00:32.430
>> Thanks for the engineer position.

11
00:00:32.430 --> 00:00:33.710
I am guiding us down the tracks.

12
00:00:33.710 --> 00:00:35.850
All right.
Thanks for having me back, and yes,

13
00:00:35.850 --> 00:00:39.970
excited, we are continuing on using
that new portal, right, to rinse and

14
00:00:39.970 --> 00:00:44.850
repeat, to create that site-to-site VPN
between our on-premises network and

15
00:00:44.850 --> 00:00:47.990
our Azure network so
we can extend Active Directory out there.

16
00:00:47.990 --> 00:00:49.630
Host domain controllers.

17
00:00:49.630 --> 00:00:51.380
Not Azure AD, right?

18
00:00:51.380 --> 00:00:53.050
Not just an identity management solution,

19
00:00:53.050 --> 00:00:58.530
but actual copy of our Active Directory
out there in our Azure network.

20
00:00:58.530 --> 00:01:01.140
We can use that for disaster recovery.

21
00:01:01.140 --> 00:01:04.970
We can use that to support branch offices,
deploying Cloud apps.

22
00:01:04.970 --> 00:01:06.450
You know, Cloud based apps,
things like that.

23
00:01:06.450 --> 00:01:10.360
So, mobile users, traveling people
that are traveling, working from home,

24
00:01:10.360 --> 00:01:15.000
all kinds of great benefits from extending
active directory out there into the Cloud.

25
00:01:15.000 --> 00:01:19.250
So as we went along we
got a lot of the pieces,

26
00:01:19.250 --> 00:01:21.870
parts put into place to
create that site to site VPN.

27
00:01:21.870 --> 00:01:23.050
We went through and

28
00:01:23.050 --> 00:01:27.460
created our resource group to associate
all the resources that were deploying.

29
00:01:27.460 --> 00:01:29.050
We created a storage account so

30
00:01:29.050 --> 00:01:32.910
that we had some place to put all of
this resources that we are creating.

31
00:01:32.910 --> 00:01:37.856
We created out virtual network, we created
a subnet within that virtual network,

32
00:01:37.856 --> 00:01:40.540
we created a gateway
subnet that Microsoft or

33
00:01:40.540 --> 00:01:45.216
Azure users at the edge of our network to
allow us to create that site to to site.

34
00:01:45.216 --> 00:01:48.544
And then the last thing we did was we
created the virtual network gateway in

35
00:01:48.544 --> 00:01:52.410
that previous episodes, remember that
the one that takes 30 minutes right about,

36
00:01:52.410 --> 00:01:55.384
this time was actually quick Daniel,
it took 26 minutes or so.

37
00:01:55.384 --> 00:01:59.478
>> Yeah, we were screaming right along and
we thought that was gonna be in the next

38
00:01:59.478 --> 00:02:02.350
step but it actually turned
out to be that actual step.

39
00:02:02.350 --> 00:02:06.070
>> I misspoke a little bit there
probably at the end of that last one.

40
00:02:06.070 --> 00:02:06.880
But we did.

41
00:02:06.880 --> 00:02:10.078
When you created that
virtual network gateway,

42
00:02:10.078 --> 00:02:14.950
that's what they used to in the classic
portal call just the gateway.

43
00:02:14.950 --> 00:02:17.820
So that virtual network
gateway is the gateway.

44
00:02:17.820 --> 00:02:19.860
So at this point,
if we take a look at my screen,

45
00:02:19.860 --> 00:02:23.440
it did finish up right
here Azure in AD gateway.

46
00:02:23.440 --> 00:02:27.160
If I click on that, you'll see I
have my virtual network gateway,

47
00:02:27.160 --> 00:02:31.530
and it has a public IP
address assigned to it.

48
00:02:31.530 --> 00:02:35.090
That's what I need so
that I can establish that tunnel.

49
00:02:35.090 --> 00:02:39.680
When I configure my on premises VPN
server, that's the address I'm gonna use.

50
00:02:39.680 --> 00:02:41.770
That's what we're connecting to.

51
00:02:41.770 --> 00:02:46.200
But if I look at connections,
well, I don't have any yet.

52
00:02:46.200 --> 00:02:49.350
Now I could click this add button right
here, and go ahead and add the connection.

53
00:02:49.350 --> 00:02:54.910
But what's gonna happen when I do that
is it's gonna want to know about my,

54
00:02:54.910 --> 00:02:56.780
what have we got here?

55
00:02:56.780 --> 00:03:02.640
Pre-shared key, resource, location,
first gateway we've got access to.

56
00:03:02.640 --> 00:03:06.790
If I change this to site to site,
which was what we're trying to do right.

57
00:03:06.790 --> 00:03:10.000
This first option which we really
didn't see in the classic portal,

58
00:03:10.000 --> 00:03:15.950
you can do these in classic portal but
you can do a VNET to VNET type tunnel.

59
00:03:15.950 --> 00:03:18.590
So if you had two separate
virtual networks you could tunnel

60
00:03:18.590 --> 00:03:19.410
between those two.

61
00:03:19.410 --> 00:03:23.020
If I change this to site to site which is
what we're doing, one of the things that

62
00:03:23.020 --> 00:03:27.260
it's going to need is my local network
gateway, which we haven't created yet.

63
00:03:27.260 --> 00:03:31.890
Now if I click here it would give
me the option to go ahead and

64
00:03:31.890 --> 00:03:33.610
it's gonna say I don't have any.

65
00:03:33.610 --> 00:03:36.980
And it usually will give me
the option to create one and

66
00:03:36.980 --> 00:03:38.500
I can't even create it here.

67
00:03:38.500 --> 00:03:43.560
And like I said earlier I really
like to create things prior to

68
00:03:43.560 --> 00:03:46.910
needing them in those wizards cuz I've had
a couple times where it just glitches.

69
00:03:46.910 --> 00:03:50.320
If I try to add it during the wizard,
it seems to add it.

70
00:03:50.320 --> 00:03:53.240
But the wizard itself doesn't
recognize that it's been added.

71
00:03:53.240 --> 00:03:55.900
And so I end up cancelling the wizard and
starting over anyway.

72
00:03:55.900 --> 00:03:58.500
So I like to just go
back to the beginning.

73
00:03:58.500 --> 00:03:59.770
And that's what we're going to do here.

74
00:03:59.770 --> 00:04:02.990
I'm gonna click local network gateways.

75
00:04:02.990 --> 00:04:06.480
Again, it's gonna show me that I don't
have any, and I'm gonna go ahead and

76
00:04:06.480 --> 00:04:07.510

>> [LAUGH] So, we'll reload that page, and

00:17:15.380 --> 00:17:17.572
But, odds are, it actually is connected.

The interface just hasn't

If you remember in the classic, it had

[LAUGH]

As you're into the gateway.

Connections.

You can do it.

When I went to this router,

347
00:18:51.260 --> 00:18:52.780

00:18:52.780 --> 00:18:57.592

00:18:57.592 --> 00:19:01.970
40.114, but the virtual network 10.2.1,

00:19:01.970 --> 00:19:07.180

00:19:07.180 --> 00:19:11.130

00:19:24.070 --> 00:19:26.580
We're not running Rip, or
anything like tha,t where these

00:19:26.580 --> 00:19:31.030
VPNs can share their routing information,

00:19:31.030 --> 00:19:33.620
So what I'm going to do-

00:19:33.620 --> 00:19:34.480

So all you do is you come

and for my interface I'm

And I'm going to actually,

super knit this, I don't think

>> Yeah.
>> To add more networks to your-

367
00:19:55.435 --> 00:19:56.243

Instead of doing a 24-bit,

00:19:57.795 --> 00:20:01.623
I know there's more than one 10.2.1,

>> Yeah, you can-
>> I can add a route for 10.2.0.0.16.

371
00:20:04.543 --> 00:20:06.545
>> Right.
>> Is that supernetting?

372
00:20:06.545 --> 00:20:10.647
>> Supernetting is if you want to add
more hosts than [CROSSTALK] kind of doing

373
00:20:10.647 --> 00:20:14.547
the opposite of subnetting which is
that it's taking from the host to

374
00:20:14.547 --> 00:20:15.568
add to networks.

375
00:20:15.568 --> 00:20:17.220
The opposite of supernetting.

376
00:20:17.220 --> 00:20:19.603
>> So I'm just adding a single route.

377
00:20:19.603 --> 00:20:24.164
I could add individual routes,
like if I had a 10.2.1.0 network and

378
00:20:24.164 --> 00:20:27.550
a 10.2.2 virtual network
up there with a /24.

379
00:20:27.550 --> 00:20:32.384
I could add individual routes for each one
of those, or I could add one route for

00:20:32.384 --> 00:20:38.340
the 10.2.0.0/16, because anything
10.2 is going through this tunnel.

381
00:20:38.340 --> 00:20:41.260
All of the subnets up there
are going to be 10.2 something.

382
00:20:41.260 --> 00:20:42.395
So I'm going to add it that way.

383
00:20:42.395 --> 00:20:44.950
I'll click OK, and there we go.

384
00:20:44.950 --> 00:20:47.090
I now have a route.

385
00:20:47.090 --> 00:20:51.610
Now, we won't be able to test
this until we throw out some

00:20:51.610 --> 00:20:52.650
virtual machines up there.

387
00:20:52.650 --> 00:20:59.150
I don't have anything yet to ping, so
why don't we, real quick, create a VM?

388
00:20:59.150 --> 00:21:00.860
We've got a few minutes left,

389
00:21:00.860 --> 00:21:02.780
>> We do.
>> All right, then I will go ahead and

00:21:02.780 --> 00:21:07.650
do that so we can test it and
make sure Mike isn't just blowing smoke.

00:21:07.650 --> 00:21:11.840
So let's go back over here and
see how we create a virtual machine, and

00:21:11.840 --> 00:21:15.630
then in our next episode we'll look at
making this guy a domain controller, or

00:21:18.040 --> 00:21:19.310
I added virtual machines here.

Remember, this is

So they are different.

399
00:21:30.537 --> 00:21:36.620
I could also go New, and then Compute, and

00:21:36.620 --> 00:21:38.510
I'm going to choose WIndows server.

It's a little bit,

00:21:40.870 --> 00:21:47.700
Like you have recommended, you have

You can also search down there.

There's another category,

I can search for a server,
Windows, server and

Either way you want to go, find that

Again we're going to use

00:22:11.170 --> 00:22:14.830
Remember I think I mentioned this before,

So I've had a classic virtual network,

I might choose the classic

00:25:11.490 --> 00:25:16.220

This is not your daddy's portal for

That is for sure a lot more ways for

00:25:50.200 --> 00:25:52.660

Even though I'm sure that once

00:25:58.900 --> 00:26:02.320

493
00:26:30.133 --> 00:26:38.070
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel create a Replica Domain Controller on their newly created virtual machine in Azure. They begin by connecting to the VM with Remote Desktop and adjust the Windows Firewall to allow ping traffic to test connectivity. Then they join the new VM to their existing AD domain, after which they install Active Directory and verify replication with the on-premesis site.
episodes.title: Create a Replica DC in Azure

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel show you how to create a Site-to-Site VPN from your on-premesis environment to your Azure environment using Windows PowerShell. They start by connecting to Azure with the PowerShell, making sure to choose the correct subscription. Then they show you how to access the necessary Azure resources to create the VPN connection.
episodes.title: Site-to-Site VPN with Azure PowerShell

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel continue demonstrating how to create a Site-to-Site VPN from on-premesis to Azure. They pick up by verifying the provisioning of the necessary resources through the Azure portal. Then they create and configure the VPN connection from their on-premesis domain controller; finally initializing the VPN connection and verifying connectivity.
episodes.title: Site-to-Site VPN with Azure PowerShell Part 2

00:09:46.260 --> 00:09:48.330
And you see the first three
I've already run and succeeded.

191
00:09:48.330 --> 00:09:51.730
The last one is now running,
it's creating that connection.

192
00:09:53.670 --> 00:09:57.140
So we'll give it just a second to finish
that up and then we can go and check and

193
00:09:57.140 --> 00:09:58.990
see if I succeeded.

194
00:10:00.550 --> 00:10:01.530
And then we've got a command.

195
00:10:01.530 --> 00:10:04.540
I'll show you now to verify it,
as well, from PowerShell,

196
00:10:04.540 --> 00:10:07.550
cuz again, you might be doing
everything through PowerShell.

197
00:10:10.341 --> 00:10:12.875
All right, so
it's thinking about it, whirring and

198
00:10:12.875 --> 00:10:14.573
grinding there in the background.

199
00:10:16.935 --> 00:10:19.299
Gonna give it just a minute
to generate that guy.

200
00:10:20.570 --> 00:10:22.870
And again, down here is what
I was talking about earlier.

201
00:10:22.870 --> 00:10:26.702
You can see it says running
script / selection.

202
00:10:26.702 --> 00:10:28.890
Ctrl+Break to stop.

203
00:10:28.890 --> 00:10:32.280
So lets me know that it is running,
at least.

204
00:10:33.650 --> 00:10:37.050
Cuz I don't get the spinning cheerio or
the hourglass or any of that good stuff.

205
00:10:37.050 --> 00:10:39.213
>> What's the break key on
your Mac keyboard, Mike?

206
00:10:39.213 --> 00:10:40.875
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's called a hammer.

207
00:10:40.875 --> 00:10:42.055
[LAUGH]
>> It is broken.

208
00:10:42.055 --> 00:10:47.400
[LAUGH] You know, I've run into that
more than once with the good old Mac,

209
00:10:47.400 --> 00:10:48.550
not having enough keys on it.

210
00:10:50.192 --> 00:10:52.690
I need, I have to bring up the onscreen

211
00:10:52.690 --> 00:10:54.930
keyboard sometimes to
type some of that stuff.

212
00:10:54.930 --> 00:10:57.050
>> Mac doesn't think you need that,
Apple says hey man,

213
00:10:57.050 --> 00:10:59.730
don't need that stinking break key,
it's useless anyway.

214
00:10:59.730 --> 00:11:00.550
Why I tell you.

215
00:11:00.550 --> 00:11:05.070
>> One of my favorite key that pause break
key is one that I used on a Windows key or

216
00:11:05.070 --> 00:11:06.610
Windows keyboard quite often.

217
00:11:06.610 --> 00:11:07.670
What was it?

218
00:11:07.670 --> 00:11:12.380
I can't remember, that's been so

219
00:11:12.380 --> 00:11:15.150
long since I actually been
on the Windows machine.

220
00:11:15.150 --> 00:11:17.470
To get to my system properties,
there was a pause break key.

221
00:11:18.580 --> 00:11:19.830
Keystroke combination.

222
00:11:19.830 --> 00:11:20.730
All right.
There we go.

223
00:11:20.730 --> 00:11:22.340
It has finished.

224
00:11:22.340 --> 00:11:27.080
So I can see all the information and
the main thing I'm looking for there.

225
00:11:27.080 --> 00:11:29.530
It does that every time to me.

226
00:11:29.530 --> 00:11:31.990
Is the provisioning state.

227
00:11:31.990 --> 00:11:34.848
That's really what I'm looking for,
succeeded.

228
00:11:34.848 --> 00:11:38.760
You know, PowerShell if it didn't
get a bunch of red text on there,

229
00:11:38.760 --> 00:11:41.050
letting me know that something went wrong.

230
00:11:41.050 --> 00:11:44.430
And I will say, PowerShell's pretty good
about telling you what went wrong and

231
00:11:44.430 --> 00:11:46.010
you have to read through the error.

232
00:11:46.010 --> 00:11:47.580
Sometimes it can be difficult but

233
00:11:47.580 --> 00:11:49.920
they usually do a good job of
telling you what exactly went wrong.

234
00:11:49.920 --> 00:11:54.710
All right at that point we
should be connected, right?

235
00:11:54.710 --> 00:11:55.290
Let's check.

236
00:11:55.290 --> 00:11:58.490
So I'm going to flip back over
here to my local network.

237
00:11:58.490 --> 00:12:01.240
And we're going to refresh
this screen real quick.

238
00:12:01.240 --> 00:12:04.190
But I can already see
recovery is connected.

239
00:12:04.190 --> 00:12:08.270
I have to go down to general,
I take a look at recovery.

240
00:12:08.270 --> 00:12:11.300
And I can see some bytes have
actually been sent back and forth.

241
00:12:11.300 --> 00:12:12.770
I am showing connected there.

242
00:12:12.770 --> 00:12:15.140
So pretty good sign, right?

243
00:12:15.140 --> 00:12:16.590
We'll flip out to Azure.

244
00:12:18.330 --> 00:12:20.730
We can also verify here.

245
00:12:20.730 --> 00:12:25.750
There's my connection that
succeeded in provisioning.

246
00:12:25.750 --> 00:12:27.640
Click on it,
take a look at its properties.

247
00:12:29.450 --> 00:12:31.370
And it still says not connected.

248
00:12:31.370 --> 00:12:34.590
So it is
>> We've seen that before though.

249
00:12:34.590 --> 00:12:37.700
Every time it's been,
you just gotta give it a little more time,

250
00:12:37.700 --> 00:12:38.950
and then it'll show up.

251
00:12:38.950 --> 00:12:39.630
>> Yep, exactly.

252
00:12:39.630 --> 00:12:42.920
So in fact, let's just close out all of
these blades that I've got going here.

253
00:12:44.020 --> 00:12:47.250
We'll just jump all the way back to
the beginning, close all that app,

254
00:12:47.250 --> 00:12:48.810
go back out to my dashboard.

255
00:12:48.810 --> 00:12:50.090
>> New portal's a little blade happy.

256
00:12:50.090 --> 00:12:51.290
>> It is a little blade happy.

257
00:12:51.290 --> 00:12:54.560
You can end up with quite a serious
bread crumb trail up there.

258
00:12:54.560 --> 00:12:58.430
So I'm going to go to my resources.

259
00:12:58.430 --> 00:13:01.400
Of course there's different ways
you can navigate around in here and

260
00:13:01.400 --> 00:13:03.690
I'm just gonna find my gateway.

261
00:13:07.559 --> 00:13:11.310
All right, and there is my gateway,
we're gonna go to connections.

262
00:13:13.877 --> 00:13:16.286
And still showing as not
connected on this end but

263
00:13:16.286 --> 00:13:19.224
I imagine it's just like Daniel
was saying just a little bit

264
00:13:19.224 --> 00:13:23.120
behind because it's definitely
showing connected on my router.

265
00:13:23.120 --> 00:13:25.590
So most likely we are good to go.

266
00:13:27.020 --> 00:13:28.020
What else?

267
00:13:28.020 --> 00:13:28.770
In fact, you know what?

268
00:13:28.770 --> 00:13:29.840
Let's try.
Let's see if

269
00:13:29.840 --> 00:13:31.650
PowerShell's ahead of the game here.

270
00:13:31.650 --> 00:13:33.800
Cuz again, you might be doing
everything through PowerShell and

271
00:13:33.800 --> 00:13:35.120
not using the GUI at all.

272
00:13:35.120 --> 00:13:37.770
So how would I verify that that
connection was established?

273
00:13:37.770 --> 00:13:42.820
I'm just gonna run this command, Get
-AzureRmVirtualNetworkGatewayConnection

274
00:13:42.820 --> 00:13:44.730
with a debug switch.

275
00:13:44.730 --> 00:13:47.140
So I'll run that command.

276
00:13:47.140 --> 00:13:47.960
Now it's gonna ask me,

277
00:13:47.960 --> 00:13:52.340
are you sure you wanna run this operation
cuz I am doing some debug there.

278
00:13:52.340 --> 00:13:56.170
I'll say yes to all otherwise it's
gonna stop on every single response and

279
00:13:56.170 --> 00:13:58.030
ask me if I wanna continue
with that operation.

280
00:13:59.390 --> 00:14:01.590
And then I'll scroll back through
the results here for you.

281
00:14:03.000 --> 00:14:04.110
Slide that up a wee bit.

282
00:14:06.500 --> 00:14:08.310
And as I scroll up, there we go.

283
00:14:08.310 --> 00:14:11.220
So there's my command and
you can see getting the virtual network

284
00:14:11.220 --> 00:14:14.750
gateway connection command to begin
the processing of the parameter set.

285
00:14:14.750 --> 00:14:19.090
All parameter sets, so
it goes through my account information.

286
00:14:20.820 --> 00:14:23.420
What else exciting do
we get to see in here?

287
00:14:23.420 --> 00:14:27.090
Really just a lot of info that
some of it might be useful,

288
00:14:27.090 --> 00:14:31.430
some of it might not be useful,
depending on what you're troubleshooting.

289
00:14:31.430 --> 00:14:37.060
But down here is what I'm really
getting at, ConnectionStatus.

290
00:14:37.060 --> 00:14:41.020
Gosh darn, every time I switch focus,
where did we go?

291
00:14:41.020 --> 00:14:44.760
There we go,
connection status connected, right?

292
00:14:44.760 --> 00:14:49.700
So that verifies that I actually do have
my site to site connection is up between

293
00:14:49.700 --> 00:14:55.070
my on-premises router and
that network out there in Azure.

294
00:14:55.070 --> 00:14:55.910
We're up and running.

295
00:14:55.910 --> 00:14:59.640
>> Mike I gotta be honest with you,
you're really selling me on Azure.

296
00:14:59.640 --> 00:15:01.558
Using the Azure Power Shell.

297
00:15:01.558 --> 00:15:03.651
[LAUGH] It's faster,
it works better, it's more efficient.

298
00:15:03.651 --> 00:15:04.990
[LAUGH] It's easier to work with.

299
00:15:04.990 --> 00:15:06.290
>> It is.
>> More straight forward.

300
00:15:06.290 --> 00:15:09.180
>> Yeah, you know the GUI is still waiting
to tell me whether I'm connected or not,

301
00:15:09.180 --> 00:15:10.745
the power cell,
you're connected you're good.

302
00:15:10.745 --> 00:15:12.470
[LAUGH] And it did it in seconds, right?

303
00:15:12.470 --> 00:15:13.410
>> Yeah.
>> So,

304
00:15:13.410 --> 00:15:16.120
it is a pretty impressive
way to do things.

305
00:15:16.120 --> 00:15:18.550
And that my friends is really she wrote.

306
00:15:18.550 --> 00:15:21.830
We went though the entire process,
and we'll just refresh this,

307
00:15:21.830 --> 00:15:26.580
we'll give it
>> The GUI one more chance to catch up.

308
00:15:26.580 --> 00:15:29.190
It did say connected there, didn't it?

309
00:15:29.190 --> 00:15:30.490
Connected and connected.

310
00:15:30.490 --> 00:15:32.940
So finally the GUI caught
up with PowerShell.

311
00:15:32.940 --> 00:15:35.125
>> Well welcome to the show, GUI.

312
00:15:35.125 --> 00:15:37.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, awesome, Mike.

313
00:15:37.100 --> 00:15:40.580
Is there anything else that we need to do,
or is this basically it?

314
00:15:40.580 --> 00:15:41.650
We've got a connection.

315
00:15:41.650 --> 00:15:43.410
Everything's working as it should.

316
00:15:43.410 --> 00:15:45.950
And we can off rough the races.

317
00:15:45.950 --> 00:15:49.290
>> Yeah our next step would be to
actually create our virtual machine.

318
00:15:49.290 --> 00:15:52.000
Set up our VM,
add that second data drive, and

319
00:15:52.000 --> 00:15:54.320
install active directory, get it going.

320
00:15:54.320 --> 00:15:57.030
We can do that with Power Shell as well.

321
00:15:57.030 --> 00:15:58.210
Which I think we should do.

322
00:15:58.210 --> 00:15:59.530
>> I think definitely we should do.

323
00:15:59.530 --> 00:16:01.350
That would be an excellent show.

324
00:16:01.350 --> 00:16:02.760
Learning every which way.

325
00:16:02.760 --> 00:16:04.760
I love having options, right?

326
00:16:04.760 --> 00:16:06.250
If I want to use the new portal.

327
00:16:06.250 --> 00:16:08.520
I can use the new portal if I'm
comfortable with that it's fine.

328
00:16:08.520 --> 00:16:10.470
Like the classic portal I know Mike does.

329
00:16:10.470 --> 00:16:12.540
Jump in there, use that, it's fine.

330
00:16:12.540 --> 00:16:15.500
If I like Azure,
I'm obviously now a huge fan.

331
00:16:15.500 --> 00:16:16.810
I can't wait to see what else we can do.

332
00:16:16.810 --> 00:16:18.450
How we can make that happen?

333
00:16:18.450 --> 00:16:21.390
I'm gonna use that having options
is the best thing for us.

334
00:16:21.390 --> 00:16:23.310
And they've given us
three really good ones.

335
00:16:23.310 --> 00:16:25.190
Pick the one you like and run with it.

336
00:16:25.190 --> 00:16:26.480
So Mike, I look forward to those shows.

337
00:16:26.480 --> 00:16:28.386
I think you've probably got
a little extra something.

338
00:16:28.386 --> 00:16:29.450
>> Yeah.
There's one more thing

339
00:16:29.450 --> 00:16:32.120
I want to say about the script
itself that we were writing.

340
00:16:32.120 --> 00:16:36.400
It looked a little bit complex,
because I had broken out each command,

341
00:16:36.400 --> 00:16:39.180
commented it up so we would know
exactly what we were doing and

342
00:16:39.180 --> 00:16:41.190
I could run those commands one at a time.

343
00:16:41.190 --> 00:16:45.710
And I was defining variables
along with the commands.

344
00:16:45.710 --> 00:16:48.420
What you'll find,
when you start writing these scripts,

345
00:16:48.420 --> 00:16:51.930
really the best way to do it is at
the beginning of the script you've got a,

346
00:16:51.930 --> 00:16:55.340
you create a block of
variable assignments, right?

347
00:16:55.340 --> 00:16:58.660
And you just go through and
you assign names and IP addresses.

348
00:16:58.660 --> 00:17:01.270
Or whatever it is those
variables are going to store.

349
00:17:01.270 --> 00:17:04.960
And then down below, you've got all your
code that executes the actual scripts.

350
00:17:04.960 --> 00:17:06.750
Because, that way, let's say tomorrow,

351
00:17:06.750 --> 00:17:10.940
I need to set up another site to
site to a different branch office.

352
00:17:10.940 --> 00:17:12.300
Where I can just take that script and

353
00:17:12.300 --> 00:17:14.530
write at the top of
the scripts all my variables.

354
00:17:14.530 --> 00:17:16.640
And I just change branch
one to branch two.

355
00:17:16.640 --> 00:17:17.170
Right.

356
00:17:17.170 --> 00:17:21.390
Change the name of my connection
from gateway one to gateway two or

357
00:17:21.390 --> 00:17:22.020
whatever it is.

358
00:17:22.020 --> 00:17:22.834
You see what I'm saying?

359
00:17:22.834 --> 00:17:26.385
You just update those variables and
run that script again and you're done.

360
00:17:26.385 --> 00:17:29.335
Where you have them scattered throughout
your script like I've got now

361
00:17:29.335 --> 00:17:31.895
it can be easy to miss one or
two variables.

362
00:17:31.895 --> 00:17:34.735
You don't change it like you should, and
then what happens is you end up with

363
00:17:34.735 --> 00:17:38.325
a duplicate name error or something gets
put in the wrong resource group, you know?

364
00:17:38.325 --> 00:17:39.035
Or something like that.

365
00:17:39.035 --> 00:17:42.215
So, if I was writing these scripts for
a production environment and

366
00:17:42.215 --> 00:17:46.900
not to demo I would probably segregate
out a lot of the variable smart,

367
00:17:46.900 --> 00:17:50.820
it's just a wise way to create
your scripts to make it easy for

368
00:17:50.820 --> 00:17:53.050
yourself down the road
to reuse those scripts.

369
00:17:53.050 --> 00:17:55.510
And we call that portability or
reusability.

370
00:17:55.510 --> 00:17:56.460
It's good stuff.

371
00:17:56.460 --> 00:17:59.490
Good tips, Mike, and we look forward
to seeing your upcoming shows and

372
00:17:59.490 --> 00:18:02.340
what else we can use with
the Azure PowerShell.

373
00:18:02.340 --> 00:18:04.270
That being said,
thanks again for joining us.

374
00:18:04.270 --> 00:18:07.326
Thank you guys for watching, we're gonna
go ahead and sign off for ITProTV.

375
00:18:07.326 --> 00:18:08.627
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

376
00:18:08.627 --> 00:18:09.568
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

377
00:18:09.568 --> 00:18:11.716
>> And we'll see you next time.

378
00:18:11.716 --> 00:18:19.489
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel show you how to use the PowerShell to create a Virtual Machine in Azure. They begin by connecting to Azure using the PowerShell, after which they create a storage account and availability set. Then they create the VM and show you how this can be done with a script. They then modify that script to create another VM.
episodes.title: Create a VM with Azure PowerShell
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.111 --> 00:00:17.340
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.340 --> 00:00:19.460
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.460 --> 00:00:23.500
well, we are continuing on with
our series on AD in Azure.

5
00:00:23.500 --> 00:00:27.600
Joining us back in the studio today is
our friend that's been guiding us, Mr.

6
00:00:27.600 --> 00:00:28.120
Mike Rodrick.

7
00:00:28.120 --> 00:00:29.190
Mike, welcome back to the show, sir.

8
00:00:29.190 --> 00:00:30.100
>> Thank you very much.

9
00:00:30.100 --> 00:00:33.810
That's right, today we are gonna see
how we can roll out a virtual machine

10
00:00:33.810 --> 00:00:34.830
using PowerShell, right?

11
00:00:34.830 --> 00:00:38.480
Or I should, more correctly,
say Azure PowerShell.

12
00:00:38.480 --> 00:00:40.630
We've already used it to
do a lot of the work.

13
00:00:40.630 --> 00:00:44.640
We've created a virtual
network up there in Azure.

14
00:00:44.640 --> 00:00:49.160
We created the gateway, we set up the site
to site VPN, all through PowerShell.

15
00:00:49.160 --> 00:00:52.970
Now that we've got all that set up,
the next logical step then is to start

16
00:00:52.970 --> 00:00:56.520
rolling out some VMS, and we want to
use PowerShell to do that as well.

17
00:00:56.520 --> 00:00:59.179
We've already shown you we can
do it using the classic portal,

18
00:00:59.179 --> 00:01:01.420
we can do it using the new portal.

19
00:01:01.420 --> 00:01:05.210
But if I want to start automating this,
if it's something that I'm gonna be doing

20
00:01:05.210 --> 00:01:08.890
often, having that PowerShell script
available is definitely the way to go.

21
00:01:08.890 --> 00:01:13.360
So let's take a look at what we're
gonna need to do to get this done.

22
00:01:13.360 --> 00:01:15.340
Let's take a look at my screen here, and

23
00:01:15.340 --> 00:01:17.330
the first thing that we're gonna
have to do is authenticate.

24
00:01:17.330 --> 00:01:21.580
Like we did before when we created our
virtual network, I need to log into Azure,

25
00:01:21.580 --> 00:01:26.340
so that my PowerShell session knows
where to connect up to Azure.

26
00:01:26.340 --> 00:01:34.160
And this command is simply
Login-AzureRmAccount, and I'll hit Enter.

27
00:01:34.160 --> 00:01:36.585
And that should prompt me
with a little dialogue box.

28
00:01:36.585 --> 00:01:38.338
Actually, here I am working in the ISE,

29
00:01:38.338 --> 00:01:41.430
I keeping thinking that I'm
in the actual PowerShell.

30
00:01:41.430 --> 00:01:44.010
So let me run that,
that will actually make it go.

31
00:01:45.030 --> 00:01:49.740
Run that and that is going to
generate my authentication dialog box

32
00:01:49.740 --> 00:01:53.740
where I'll type in the appropriate account
information so that I can authenticate.

33
00:01:53.740 --> 00:02:00.511
If I can remember my user name and
my password.

34
00:02:00.511 --> 00:02:06.350
We'll drop down there, enter in my
password, and we should be good to go.

35
00:02:06.350 --> 00:02:09.040
That window usually flash
a couple of times and

36
00:02:09.040 --> 00:02:12.910
then you'll get a little message showing
you that you are indeed connected.

37
00:02:12.910 --> 00:02:16.790
It's got my Tenant Id and
my Subscription Id in there.

38
00:02:16.790 --> 00:02:18.440
So now I'm connected to Azure and

39
00:02:18.440 --> 00:02:21.720
I can start firing off commands
against my Azure subscription.

40
00:02:22.870 --> 00:02:23.770
So the next thing we need to do,

41
00:02:23.770 --> 00:02:28.470
if we're gonna create VMS, we're gonna
need a storage account to store that.

42
00:02:28.470 --> 00:02:32.810
Remember we created a resource
group in that new portal and

43
00:02:32.810 --> 00:02:34.640
we did it through PowerShell.
